PETITION.TITLE: Woodchip Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licenses despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:

PETITION.PARA: apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and
exclude from licences, woodchip derived from old growth forests and wilderness areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in pensioner age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.
To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant ares of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: National Anthem
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament in Canberra.

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Members of Parliament to our National Anthem/Song.
Unlike such countries as New Zealand and Great Britain there is no reference to God in the wording of the text;
As such we have no opportunity to express our wish for God's blessing upon our country; and
As the overwhelming majority of Australians believe in God we request that:
The last line in each chorus on the National Anthem/Song be amended from "Advance Australia Fair" to "God Bless Australia Fair".
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, which is now before the chamber, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Most of the amendments have already been introduced as customs tariff proposals. I will briefly outline the amendments.

Schedule one contains amendments announced by the Treasurer in the 1994-95 federal budget and have operated since 11 May 1994. The amendments give effect to the government's decision to decrease the customs duty on topped crude oil by 2.977c per litre and on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene by 1.977c per litre. These changes will lower input costs for industry and will specifically benefit coastal shipping, export oriented mineral projects and certain manufacturing operations.

Schedule two is operative from 1 July 1994. In May 1993, this government decided to reduce the coverage of the Australian system of tariff preferences from 1 July 1993 by phasing out the most developed countries from access to the developing country margin of preference for certain imported commodities. On 4 May this year, my colleague Senator Cook, announced in the Working Nation White Paper that a similar phase-out would be extended to the remainder of goods in the customs tariff with the exception of cheese, sugar, unmanufactured tobacco and certain replacement components for passenger motor vehicles.
The phase-out of the margin of preference will be achieved by freezing the developing country rate for the subject goods at their pre-first of July 1994 level.

The Treasurer also announced on budget night 1994 an increase of 1.194c per litre in customs duties on aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene for use in aircraft. This increase is a further part of the process announced by the government in the 1992-93 federal budget of a phased introduction of full recovery of the costs incurred by the Civil Aviation Authority in implementing aviation safety standards, and 50 per cent of their costs of safety standards setting and compliance.

The rate of duty on aviation gasoline is subject to further variation in respect to the duty collected and paid to the CAA to recover airways costs attributable to aviation gasoline powered aircraft. The reduction of 7.521c per litre follows the adoption by the CAA of a marginal cost basis for the pricing of services provided to operators of gasoline powered aircraft. This approach has been adopted in recognition of the fact that a large proportion of CAA facilities are put in place because they are required for regular public transport operations mostly undertaken by aviation kerosene powered aircraft.

As part of the government's policy pertaining to the automotive industry until the year 2000, tariffs on passenger motor vehicle replacement components were to be maintained at fifteen per cent from 1 July 1992. Amendments contained in this schedule redress certain anomalies which arose in the implementation of the government's policy. Specifically, a number of tariff classifications were omitted from the original PMV schedule of replacement components. There were also a small number of other classifications for which rates of duty had already fallen below the 15 per cent threshold.
These amendments introduce a consistent application of government assistance for imported replacement components for the australian automotive sector.
The Malaysia Australia trade agreement provides bi-lateral trade concessions. The amendments contained in this schedule provide a free rate of duty for unvulcanised compounded rubber from Malaysia.

Schedule three will operate from 23 September 1994. Following a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on 19 January 1994, the government's intended assistance rate of 12 per cent (now 10 per cent) for semi-finished lens blanks for spectacles was reduced to free.

The government has put in place a regimented decrease in tariff protection since July 1988. The purpose of this amendment is to restore the previous level of assistance for semi-finished lens blanks and a structured phase down for the subject goods.
This bill also contains a number of other minor technical or administrative amendments.
Summaries of the amendments contained in this bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the bill.
MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.3) 1994

The references to provision numbers in the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) in this speech are, unless otherwise indicated, references to provision numbers as they were before the renumbering of the Migration Act 1958 on 1 September 1994.

This is the second time that this legislation has been introduced into the Senate. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No 3) 1994 first passed in the other place on 11 October 1994. Regrettably the Opposition did not support the bill on that occasion and voted with others in the Senate to defeat the bill on 9 November last.

I stated at the time that the Government considered the bill of such importance that it would be reintroduced as soon as possible. The Government did not accept the refusal of the Opposition to support this vital legislation and would give the Opposition another chance to support it.

The Government welcomes the Opposition's belated acceptance of the importance of this bill and their indication that they will now support it. The bill itself is unchanged from that which the Opposition rejected last year.

This bill, through its proposed changes to section 35 and 36 of the act (which were renumbered in December 1989 to become sections 87 and 88 respectively) seeks to restore to those sections the effect they were thought to possess prior to the decision of the High Court in Chu Kheng Lim v Minister for Immigration Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in December 1992.

It was this decision which gave rise to the commencement of claims against the Commonwealth for compensation for wrongful imprisonment of a number of unauthorised boat arrivals who are usually referred to as boat people. Prior to this decision no one had questioned the use of section 36 of the act (from December 1989 to September 1994 numbered as section 88) to detain the unauthorised arrivals in question. Indeed, those sections were not challenged in the Lim proceedings.

Section 36 of the act deals with people who come to Australia by boat without prior authorisation and who may be kept in custody until the departure of the vessel from its last port of call in Australia. Up until May 1991, unauthorised boat arrivals of this kind were detained in custody under this section while their claims to remain in Australia were assessed.

In the Lim case other aspects of migration legislation involving boat people were challenged and doubt was subsequently cast upon the lawfulness of detention for a number of boat people under section 88 once it became apparent that the boats on which they had arrived would never depart Australia. This doubt turns not on the central issue of unauthorised arrival, but on the understanding that the vessel be expected to leave Australia on a further, outward and ongoing voyage.

In this instance, the Commonwealth acted on a mistaken view of what the law was, believing—like all other concerned parties—that its detention of boat people was lawful. It is significant that no-one, apparently including the boat people themselves—and their legal representatives—saw any reason to question the lawfulness of detention on the basis none of the vessels on which they had arrived had ever left Australia. Should that custody prove to have been unlawful, it is as a result of an innocent and technical breach, and no more.

This has created an artificial situation when the fact of the matter is that the boat people did arrive in Australia unlawfully, and their detention was based on the understanding of the provisions of section 36 (section 88) by the Government and the Department at that time. Nevertheless, actions for damages have been lodged by some 88 of the boat people who now maintain that their detention under section 36 (section 88) was unlawful.

New provisions to detain unauthorised boat arrivals came into effect in May 1992 with the commencement of Division 4B of the act. These provisions, under which the boat people have been detained since May 1992, were found by the High Court in the Lim case to be constitutionally valid. However, at that time the High Court cast doubt upon the use of section 88 to detain boat people. As a consequence, section 54RA was enacted in late December 1992 with the support of the Opposition. This section extinguished the right of action for damages for false imprisonment for persons found to have been unlawfully detained under section 88 prior to their transfer to custody under Division 4B of the act, replacing it with a statutory right of action limiting to one dollar per day the damages payable.

As the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Honourable Gerry Hand, declared to Parliament, ". . . It is essential to counter the possibility of significant damages claims. It would be absurd for the Australian taxpayer to be expected to underwrite compensation payments to people who arrived here without authority and who have been detained on reasonable grounds while their claims to remain were exhaustively examined".

A case challenging the constitutional validity of the compensation scheme established in section 54RA—and I would repeat that the compensation scheme in section 54RA was regarded as constitutionally valid when it was established—is yet to be heard by the High Court. The main ground for challenge is likely to be that section 54RA breaches section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution, in that it involves an acquisition of property by the Commonwealth otherwise than on just terms. A number of High Court decisions since section 54RA was enacted on the ambit of the "just terms" requirement in the Constitution have raised doubts whether the limit on damages to one dollar per day is constitutional.

As I earlier remarked, the amendments proposed seek to reflect the Commonwealth's previous understanding of sections 35 (section 87) and 36 (section 88), and their operation. Legislative amendments of this kind can be classed as "curative", which retrospectively correct defects discovered in the law or its administration, and restores what was previously thought by all parties to be the status quo.

Recent High Court judgements involving the "just terms" requirement of our Constitution have suggested that this approach of "curative" legislation is an avenue available to the Commonwealth. Indeed the courts, including the present Chief Justice of the High Court, have emphasised that it is always open for Parliament to correct developments in the law, other than in constitutional matters, where those developments do not accord with Parliament's intention.

The rationale for curative legislation is the strong public interest in the proper functioning of government. Occasional defects in administration or statutory drafting are inevitable, and it may be fairly argued that a law which seeks retrospectively to cure innocent defects does not take away rights. It merely gives effect to administrative action already taken. Action, it should be noted, which was previously assumed by all relevant parties to be valid.

This bill—the No.3 bill—is substantially identical to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994 introduced in the Senate on 8 June 1994. The Government has introduced this bill with the intention of placing the Commonwealth in the strongest possible position to defend the claims for compensation. The bill seeks only to achieve the same effect as what was intended by the enactment of section 54RA—to prevent a possible windfall of a substantial award of damages to persons who arrived in Australia without lawful authority and were held in detention for the legitimate reason of assessing their claims to stay in this country as refugees. In this way, the Government seeks to ensure that section 88 has, and always had, the effect and operation that Parliament intended.

The Opposition parties were influenced in their earlier decision to oppose the curative measures in this bill by the dissenting report of their members of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in it's consideration of the No.2 bill. That report attempts to distinguish the proposed curative steps in the bill from the dollar a day provision on the ground of retrospectivity. This is pure sophistry.

Section 54RA limits any compensation payable to one dollar per day after the cause of action concerned has already arisen. Thus the Parliament has already applied retrospective measures to substantially limit the claims of the boat people for compensation. Sufficient doubt has now been placed upon the measures taken to date, for the Government to accept the necessity of pursuing further retrospective measures of a curative nature to ensure that the Commonwealth is in the strongest possible position to defend these claims.

The dissenting report also adopted the line pursued in the submission of the Law Council of Australia before the Committee, that the curative measures would distort the relationship between the legislative and judicial arms of government. This submission ignores the well established prerogative of the Parliament to legislate so as to affect and alter existing rights at issue in pending litigation without interfering with the exercise of judicial power in a way that is inconsistent with the Constitution. Until the High Court decides otherwise, curative legislation of this nature remains a valid course open to the Parliament.
I turn now to the curative provisions of the bill.

The amendments to sections 35 and 36 (sections 87 and 88) do not seek to change the operation of those sections, but insert new provisions intended instead to reflect the Commonwealth's understanding of sections 35 (section 87) and 36 (section 88) and the manner in which they were actually administered in practice prior to the commencement of Division 4B. The Attorney-General's Department has been consulted at every stage of the drafting process. It is the view of that Department that the amendments are not inconsistent with Australia's obligations under international law.

The proposed subsection 36(1AA) (subsection 88(1A)) seeks to put beyond doubt that section 36 (section 88) authorises the custody, for a finite period, of persons who arrive without lawful authority on board a vessel that subsequently is unable to depart Australia because it has been destroyed, or for example is not seaworthy, has been impounded or forfeited, has sunk, or is otherwise unable to depart.

This amendment also permits the taking and keeping of persons in custody, notwithstanding that the vessel on which those persons departed for Australia might not necessarily be the same vessel on which those persons arrive. It is restricted to persons who arrive on vessels that have left an Australian port and returned to an Australian port without having entered any other country. This covers situations where a person arrives at a port in Australia on an Australian based vessel, to which the person was transferred from the vessel on which that person left another country, for instance to a rescue vessel when the original vessel is about to sink.

In the circumstances envisaged by new subsection 36(1AA) (subsection 88(1A)) it is not appropriate that the period for which a person may be detained should be determined by reference to the departure of a vessel from a port. The proposed amendments will, therefore, provide that custody is to be authorised until the person is granted an entry permit; or for such period as is necessary to allow for the person's removal from Australia, following a request in writing from the person to be removed, or after all applications to remain (for example, entry permit applications and applications for refugee status) and associated appeals or reviews have been finalised, or once all consideration of whether the person will be permitted to remain in Australia has been otherwise concluded; or until such earlier time as an authorised officer directs.

Under the act, a person is considered to have entered Australia once they disembark in Australia. Proposed subsection 36(1AB) (subsection 88(1B)) makes it clear that a person is taken not to have entered Australia as a result of temporarily, haphazardly disembarking—for instance, on an island off the Australian mainland, briefly and without the knowledge of the Australian authorities—after which the persons then reboard their vessel.

The proposed amendment to section 35 (section 87) similarly does not seek to alter its existing operation but instead inserts specific provisions, to avoid any doubts, as to the extent of the power under this section. Under it an officer may, to prevent a person from entering Australia unlawfully, require a vessel to enter a port and require unauthorised persons to remain on that vessel until it arrives at the port.

I repeat that these simple, common-sense amendments, curative in nature, seek no more than to ensure that sections 35 (section 87) and 36 (section 88) of the act have and have had the operation and effect that Parliament intends them to have, which is the operation and effect which the Department and Ministers previously understood those provisions to have had.

The bill also inserts a constitutional validity or "reading down" provision. This will provide, unless a contrary intention can be clearly discerned, that where a provision of the act could have both valid and invalid applications, the provision is to have every valid application and is not to have any invalid application. The provision is similar to and consistent with "reading down" provisions in certain other Commonwealth legislation.
Given the doubt over the validity of section 54RA the Government proposes to repeal that section in this bill.

By supporting the curative steps proposed by this bill the Parliament can provide the Commonwealth with the strongest possible position for the defence of the boat peoples' claims. In doing so the Parliament will not as I have outlined above be embracing retrospectivity for the first time.

Parliament has already demonstrated its will to protect the Commonwealth, and the taxpayer, from the potential burden of compensation payments to those unauthorised boat arrivals who were detained under section 88 while their claims to remain in Australia were exhaustively assessed. The Government's commitment to this position is demonstrated by the introduction of the curative measures in this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—We have canvassed the issue, obviously. We have not got the support of the Democrats, despite their previous public stance that they would prefer a prolonged investigation of this bill. The sad reality is that when it comes to the vote we will not have the numbers. This legislation, as I said yesterday, fundamentally alters the whole structure of health care in this country. It is absolutely appalling that the legislation is not to be given the scrutiny that it deserves. I know for certain that the people who are going to be most affected by this will be the patients out there in the community. None of us want to be consumers of health care but it is inevitable that every year one in seven people approach a doctor and receive some form of treatment. So one in seven people in the community listening today will need to access health care.

PARA.TAB: This legislation will fundamentally alter the contract whereby the patient becomes contracted to an insurance company, whereas at present the patient is contracted to the doctor who is looking after them. I know which position I would like to be in. I would not want to put my faith in an insurance company, but that is in essence what will occur under this legislation. The Democrats have always preached this mantra that they are going to `keep the bastards honest'. I do not want to put that mantra upon the Western Australian Greens; I do not impugn their honesty at all, but surely they would agree that there needs to be thorough scrutiny.

The reply I was given from the Western Australian Greens, and from the Democrats for that matter, was that it was some sort of trick, that it was because in this case the opposition might have a casting vote. The same thing was said about the whistleblowers committee—that it was some sort of trick. It has been fairly obvious that in the conduct of that committee that has not occurred. By bringing it to the vote we will have these people on the record.

We have already had 67 separate submissions in relation to this legislation and, despite what Senator Chamarette said, the agenda for the hearings on Friday is that they start at 10.30 in the morning, conclude at 4.20 p.m. and then resume on Monday morning for an hour and a half. So it is not two days. It happens to be two separate days on which they are sitting but the actual time given to the debate is one day. So it is a one-day hearing, albeit that it is being postponed on Friday after previous legislation is considered early in the morning—again something of serious significance, the compensation bill, the so-called double dipping when people are under workers compensation. So it is a one-day bill. It is a one-day quick and dirty operation. I believe the people of Australia deserve better than a one-day quick and dirty look at the legislation, but that is what is going to occur.

The Democrats have said that if the evidence shows that then it may need to be extended. There are 67 separate submissions on this matter from interested bodies. The only ones that are supporting it are part—surprise, surprise—of the Australian Health Insurance Association. The Medical Benefits Fund, which is the largest privately operated company in Australia representing 1.4 million people, is totally against the legislation. The Aged Care Organisation of Australia is totally against the legislation. The psychiatric service is totally against the legislation and the rehabilitation service is totally against the legislation. The only supporter, as far as I can see, is the Executive Director of the Australian Health Insurance Association and even his organisation is split.

What I would like to know is why the rush to judgment. Where is the consultation? Where is the opportunity for consumers to appear before us? This is a one day, quick and dirty operation supported by the Democrats and the Western Australian Greens. I think the Australian public deserves better than that. When this legislation comes before the parliament we will do everything in our power to expose the hypocrisy of the so-called independent groups. I think it is clear that there needs to be much more debate, much more reference to the community and much more opportunity for the organisations to appear before a Senate select committee. That was the purpose of my motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Herron's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

I look at the first of those amendments, which relates to clause 3 on page 25. It relates to the amount to be provided to the fund. The amount provided originally was $121 million. That was on a per year basis. In other words, it was a fixed sum. Our original amendment had proposed that there be an additional $3 million a year—again, a fixed sum. That would have effectively capped the amount for administration and, over time, would have meant that the amount available in real terms would have diminished over the period of 10 years.

PARA.TAB: This amendment seeks to ensure that at least $3 million is available. It allows the parliament, by means of an appropriation from the consolidated revenue fund, to increase that amount each year, presumably on an indexation basis but providing a general discretion. Having the additional funds appropriated from other legislation avoids the difficulties that are normally involved with the Senate seeking to provide for an increase in funds and avoids the necessity for a request to be pressed with the House of Representatives on the matter. It can simply be put forward in terms of an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the course of the select committee's hearings on the amendments as dealt with by the chamber the last time this was before us, there were a number of views expressed in relation to the amendments. What we have before us today are amendments proposed by the coalition which deal with concerns that were raised during the hearing. I absolutely refute any allegation that the members of this committee went into those hearings with their minds made up. That was not the case and that is evidenced by the fact that in some cases we have changed our stance in relation to the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, there is the appropriation of $3 million for administration expenses, which has previously been mentioned. That has been changed to an appropriation from a request. What is more, there is an amount of $3 million or such higher amount as is appropriated by the parliament from the consolidated revenue fund for this purpose. That simply says that there is no cap, as such. There was some concern expressed during the hearings about a cap being placed on administrative expenses. That, in brief, is the reason for that amendment.

What I would call the second amendment, which on the circular appears as 3(f), relates to the Indigenous Land Corporation making sure as best as possible that there is no native title involved in any land that it seeks to acquire. Again, there was some concern about that because in our prior wording we had required that the Indigenous Land Corporation lodge a non-claimant application pursuant to the Native Title Act. Of course, there has been some legal concern that you cannot lodge a non-claimant application if you have no interest in the land. That is, you have to have some aspect of a lease—freehold, licence. What you would have in this instance is a requirement that the Indigenous Land Corporation go along in a situation where it has no interest in a piece of land and make an application or non-claimant procedure to clear the decks.

It was thought that there might be a legal hindrance to the Indigenous Land Corporation doing this. There was also come concern expressed by witnesses that this would unduly delay any acquisition of land. So that is why you will see in what I call amendment No. 2, which is subparagraph (3)(f), the deletion of the requirement for lodging a non-claimant application. I believe that streamlines the situation and answers the concerns that were expressed to the committee.

The next amendment appearing on page 4 is subparagraph (3)(g) which deals with amendment No. 4 previously dealt with by this chamber. That is the one which dealt with the rather controversial phrase `those most severely dispossessed'. What has happened there is that the whole paragraph has been deleted. It formerly read:

SPEECH.PARA: (b)if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to those Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands;
That is now deleted and replace by new wording in what I call amendment No. 3, which states:

(b)if a conflict arises as to the allocation of the resources of the Fund, priority is to be given to those who suffer most disadvantage in relation to access to land or who are unable to gain substantive title to land.'.

That I believe clarifies the phrase `most severely dispossessed'. There was evidence given that the principle was a good one but the wording was not that good and it could be improved upon. We are indebted to the Aboriginal rights movement from South Australia for that wording. That wording was suggested during the hearing in Adelaide.

PARA.TAB: Finally, we have in subparagraph (h) the amendment which deals with consultation with traditional owners. Previously it was in amendment No. 26, that before the Indigenous Land Corporation performs a land acquisition function it should take all reasonable steps to consult with traditional owners of the land. During the course of the evidence given to this committee there was some concern as to what constitutes a traditional owner and it did cause some consternation. The coalition senators, and I believe the Greens as well, took this on board and a suggestion was made that instead of saying `traditional owners' it should be expressed in terms of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having a traditional or historic link with the land. That spelt it out a bit more clearly because that aspect needed clarification.

There we have a thumbnail sketch, if you like, of the amendments proposed by the coalition and the reasons that they came about. I would seek to address them in a touch more detail because I do think it is important for it to be placed on the record as to the evidence given during the course of this committee and why that evidence was accepted in these discrete instances. It is interesting to note that in the government's land fund bill mark II, which is in the other place, it has adopted some amendments which were canvassed by the select committee on the land fund bill. Those dealt with the disclosure of information in criminal proceedings, the native title committee having a function of review, any change in the national strategy being notified to the minister within two months and one or two other amendments that escape my memory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether, just to make the process a little more manageable, Senator Ellison and the opposition would agree that it would be better if we broke this committee stage debate up into its obvious logical components and began simply with the cap issue which is really the subject matter of amendment Nos 1, 2 and 3(a) to (e). Perhaps if we could deal with all of that together and then deal successively with amendment Nos 3(f), (g) and (h) it might just make the handling of this debate a little more expeditious and manageable.

—I would agree entirely with that. In fact, it was in that fashion that I was making those introductory remarks in relation to the proposed amendments. So really what we are dealing with is this: amendment 1 would be the cap, the $3 million expenditure; amendment 2 would be 3(f), which is the requirement to ensure, as much as possible, clearance of native title; amendment 3 would be the most severely dispossessed, which is subparagraph (g); and amendment 4 would be consultation with what was formerly traditional owners. That is how I would propose dealing with it.
—If it is the wish of the committee, it is so ordered.
—For completeness, perhaps I might speak to the additional parts in the first bracket that we have just identified, because my original remarks were confined to the first aspect of the cap.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, we have provided more discretion to the parliament to go beyond the $3 million, and we have done it by a mechanism which allows for an amendment. Secondly, there is effectively a direction as to how the $3 million is to be spent, allowing for indexation. Thirdly, there is a legal clarification to make it clear that day-to-day administrative expenses ought to be spent on just that and to ensure that land fund moneys are spent on land acquisition and maintenance; in other words, to both minimise administrative expenses and quarantine the nature of those expenses.

Finally, there is a direction to the Indigenous Land Corporation and the general manager to act accordingly—to minimise and to ensure that any administrative surplus goes on maintenance as far as practicable. In other words, we have sought to ensure not only that land fund moneys are not eaten into by excessive administration expenses but also that a positive incentive is provided to keep those expenses as low as possible so that additional funds will be left over for land acquisition and maintenance.

That seems to us to strike a very sensible balance. It will probably put pressure on the managers from the stakeholders and ensure that, as we always hope, administrative expenses are as low as possible and the substance of the legislation is what is given most attention. That deals with what I want to cover in relation to that first bracket.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment for reasons of principle, for technical reasons and for practical reasons. Let me spell all of those out. As to questions of principle, the removal of the $3 million cap in the original amendment—which we have, of course, sought—is here offset by a provision requiring the government to provide a separate appropriation for the ILC's administration expenses every year. That will require governments to find additional moneys separate from the land fund for administrative purposes. That is a new burden being created for the government which the government is not minded to accept.

PARA.TAB: Be that as it may, the larger issue of principle that underlies this is the reality that we now have a fairly extreme form of paternalism being imposed upon this corporation. Virtually all other statutory bodies—certainly every one that I have been able to think of or research so far, and certainly those with commercial functions—are given discretions as to how much of their funding will be spent on administrative costs.

It is very paternalistic, I have to say, not to trust the Indigenous Land Corporation, virtually alone among statutory corporations, to be able to manage its finances appropriately. It might not have been the motivation of this amendment—which is to provide some additional amount for administration, and no doubt I will be told that by the opposition—but it is certainly its effect. For that reason, quite apart from any of the others, there is a problem right at the threshold with this kind of amendment.

The technical problem I might try to describe in the following terms. It is a legal problem which could, in fact, prevent the land fund from being credited with any money at all during its first 10 years, with the way the legislation is crafted. The formula for credit to the land fund in each category A year includes, with this amendment, an unspecified amount of not less than $3 million to be appropriated by the parliament. That actually conflicts in its terms with existing subsection 193(5), which provides a standing appropriation for the purposes of credit to the land fund.

On one interpretation this amendment combined with 193(5) itself now purports to appropriate at least $3 million. But of course the committee is not in a position to appropriate anything or at least to initiate a clause appropriating anything. That would have to come from the House. So the amendment is improperly cast and it should be a request. I am not sure that that is a very powerful argument.

A rather more obvious and, I think, more powerful interpretation is that what is going on here technically is the negation of the standing appropriation in 193(5) by this further provision providing for the additional appropriation to be made year by year, with the result that no credit may be made to the land fund unless and until the parliament appropriates the additional unspecified amount each year. What that means of course is, in turn, that credits to the land fund would not be determined by this bill, by this legislative exercise that we are presently engaged in. The credits to the land fund itself, leaving aside the question of administration, would have to depend upon yearly appropriations being made by the parliament—and, of course, the parliament may or may not make those appropriations.

You can be absolutely sure that so long as the Labor Party remains in government we certainly would; we are absolutely totally committed to this. But I have to say, in all charity and generosity, there would have to be doubts about a similar commitment from the other side of politics to this. On our reading of what you have technically done by introducing this amendment, you have made that credit to the land fund itself, the acquisition fund, wholly dependent on the vagaries of parliamentary process and the parliamentary majority, rather than doing it now for 10 years, which is the very least that people want us to do in order to ensure the permanence or at least the first 10 years of the creation of this fund, and to achieve that here and now by the enactment of a standing appropriation that has been put at risk.

There is a third category of problems—what I describe as practical problems. We still have, of course, what is in effect a statutory cap on expenditure on day-to-day administration. The cap is not confined to $3 million; it is $3 million or such higher amount as is appropriated, but it is still, in effect, a cap on the basis of the particular amount that is appropriated each year. What that cap may prove to do in practice is prevent the ILC from operating at all for part or conceivably even for most of any given year, once that particular amount is exhausted.

It is easy enough to envisage situations in which, with the best managed corporation in the world, that could occur. There are often variations in expenditure beyond the control of a corporation, that can arise—for example, the necessity to answer any litigation brought against it. When you take into account the number of potential sources of litigation that are now available under the bill as it presently stands coming out of the Senate and as is proposed to be further amended today, this is a very real prospect. We all know the merciless impact litigation costs can have on even the best run outfits if they have to bear these costs.

So you could have a situation with the ILC and the subsidiaries having to close down for a large part of a year, with many outstanding debts owed to staff and to others. The performance by the ILC of any of its functions will always involve administrative expenditure in the form of salaries and payments of office, transport and other costs—surveying, conveyancing and so on. But I say again, it may prove quite impossible to confine this kind of expenditure to some fixed amount or fixed proportion of total expenditure.

The capacity of the ILC to operate under these circumstances when confronted with pressures of the kind that I have described will depend in turn upon the willingness of the parliament to grant further appropriate funds to carry the administrative expenditure on in that particular year. Under those circumstances, once again, you have a situation where the operations of the ILC are not only dependent on the whims and fancies of the parliament in passing the additional appropriation for the actual administrative expenditures but, in circumstances which could very easily conceivably arise where that particular quantum is exceeded in a particular year, you will depend further on the willingness of the parliament to make the appropriate further supplementary appropriation to get the organisation through.

There are all sorts of obvious practical impacts that flow from that. Far from guaranteeing the ILC funding security, we see this amendment as removing its funding security because there is ample capacity for the ILC to make its own decisions and its own judgments about the proportion of administrative expenses from the existing amount that is appropriated under the bill as it was introduced by us. We are sure there will be ample pressures upon the ILC not to expand unnecessarily its administrative expenses. As always, under pressures of that kind, this body will be under the spotlight, and properly so. I do not think that there is a need for any extra statutory discipline of the kind that is here proposed or is here necessarily involved. Quite apart from the paternalism of it all, and repeating the point with which I began, there are some very obvious practical problems about leaving this up in the air and subject to changing circumstances in the way that this does.

In summary, the net result of all of this is that the government believes that the substituted amendments are even more objectionable than the original version of the amendment on the ground that they do contain what seems to us to be a manifest legal error. They do leave the land fund operations vulnerable to funding crises, and they do impose an arbitrary interference on the autonomy and the flexibility of the Indigenous Land Corporation. For all those reasons, you will not be surprised to hear me repeat that the government will be opposing this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) about the principle that he raised. This amendment that is being referred to as a so-called cap was never intended as a cap—and well the minister knows it—but was intended as a quarantining of the administrative costs from the acquisition and management functions of the money that is being set aside for the land fund. The conversion of it from a request to an amendment was simply so that that quarantining effect could be put in place.

PARA.TAB: There are two questions—maybe there are three—that I have for the minister. Firstly, if, as you say, there is a requirement now for parliament to determine the appropriations on an annual basis, could you inform me whether you think the impact of this amendment is that the appropriation will be in excess of $3 million or whether it will be an unspecified amount that has to be appropriated? I think that is a fairly legitimate criticism of the framing of the amendment. My understanding is that it is only that amount which is in excess of $3 million which is to be determined annually by parliament; not an X figure at all, but an additional amount to the $3 million, which really was determined at the setting of the amount that the government had said it had given for administrative costs.

If you remember, the way in which the government determined the total withdrawal from its so-called billion dollar fund which would go to Aboriginal people was based on a doubling of the ATSIC allocation of $21 million which is already there, plus $3 million for administrative costs. That total of $45 million is what we have been working with as the complete expropriation that is available to our Aboriginal people every year forever from this so-called billion dollar fund. The $3 million cap was really that set by the government. The only thing that the government did not do was to endeavour to make sure that that $3 million would not encroach on the amount available for acquisition and management.

So the first question is: is it not the fact that it is the additional part to that $3 million that may be needed to be determined by parliament, and is that not, in a sense, a legitimate way of parliament checking that the administrative costs are not totally depleting the land fund?

The second question is: when will the ILC cease to function in terms of administrative costs? If there is no limitation on how much of the fund is to be used for management and there is no limitation on the amount that is to be used for administration, what is the government intending to do with the bill when the total $45 million expropriated from the fund is being used for existing management and existing administration? Will the fund then close and simply be a draw down for management, or what exactly will happen when there is no available money to either give Aboriginal people the capacity to acquire land or manage land that has been acquired or is in their possession?

The third question is: although there are some technical problems with the amendment, if the government has the goodwill to support the spirit of the amendment could it not suggest a better way in which the spirit of the amendment could be incorporated into the fund so that Aboriginal people would gain at least $3 million, or possibly more, for the acquisition and management functions so that the fund would not be limited in terms of its administrative costs beyond a reasonable means?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I fully untangled three separate questions there, but if I have not answered them please let me know whether I need to respond further when I sit down. As to the basic technical question of what is involved here, let me put it again this way: existing provision 193(5) of the bill simply says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Consolidated Revenue Fund is appropriated for the purposes of this section.

That is an easy provision to understand and apply as the proposed section is now crafted as it was introduced by the government, because the only appropriation that is being referred to is the one for the whole 10-year period of $121 million a year effectively. That is subject to these various indexation factors, as is spelt out. That is all accomplished in one hit.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty arises from the fact that the amendment now before us proposes to add to that basic formula a new formula which is of uncertain impact in terms of the actual dollar sum involved. There is no precise formula involved that sets in concrete the calculation of the additional amount for the whole period of operation here. It is $3 million, or such higher amount more than $3 million, as is appropriated each year. The amendment in terms does not actually appropriate even the basic $3 million. It leaves it up to parliament each year to appropriate the $3 million, or the $3 million plus as the case may be. It is quite proper that a plus has been built in because obviously over time administrative expenses may require more than $3 million—not with our present inflation policy, but one has to anticipate that possibility in the future.

Under those circumstances, we then have a situation where simultaneously we have what purports to be a standing appropriation pursuant to a specific concrete formula and added to that a contingent sort of provision which depends upon what parliament chooses to appropriate each year. We cannot have those two things living together without some further attention to the technicalities involved, which has not been done in the drafting here. What we are saying is that the most likely interpretation of all this by a court is that the standing appropriation here would not bite in any given year unless and until the further appropriation task is undertaken by the parliament—the task of appropriating an amount of $3 million, or $3 million plus, for this purpose. So the whole thing is to that extent thrown into technical uncertainty.

Even if we were to fix that particular technical problem, which may or may not be easily fixable, we still have the problems of principle that I have described about the paternalism of it all. If people are not moved by that, they still have the practical problems that in any given year it may just be that a swathe of demands are being made upon the corporation, particularly in the form of litigation—that is the easiest additional impost one can imagine arising—

TALK.START.PARA: —You could ask for more funds.

—The corporation would have to then ask for more funds because it could not go back into the acquisition fund itself, the basic stock of funds. It would have to go back, cap in hand, to the parliament asking for an additional appropriation.

PARA.TAB: That is all very well if there is a very sympathetic parliament and a very sympathetic government, but the whole point of this exercise was to insulate the corporation and the fund from the vagaries of the political process for at least 10 years to enable a stock of land to be built up and for the fund and the corporation to get on with the job of buying and distributing land for dispossessed Aboriginal people and not be subject to those whims of the parliamentary process.

Accountability subjection, yes, by all means; account for every last cent that is spent and be subject to every kind of spotlight of scrutiny that you want to place upon it to ensure that the job is done properly, but not be dependent, again, on parliamentary majorities that might be quite unsympathetic to all of this for any additional funds that might actually be required. What we are saying is that the original bill might not have enough money to satisfy your tastes, Senator Chamarette, and I understand that argument, but within those constraints at least you have a non-paternalistic recognition of the right and the legitimacy of the corporation making its own decisions subject to all the checks and balances of a practical kind that will be upon it, and you do not have the whole series of problems that I have identified that are associated with this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two more questions that have not been answered. I will remind Senator Evans of them. When will the ILC cease to function if there is no cap on administration, there is no more money in the fund beyond that which is already expended on management requirements and administration costs and there is no further money available of the total $45 million each year that is the draw down figure to actually acquire any land or manage any further land? Does the fund cease to exist?

PARA.TAB: In the very best case scenario, the calculations of the Greens on how soon that will be are well under the 10 years, if the administration costs are not capped in some way. So what is the government intending to do with this legislation, when we have a so-called billion dollar fund sitting in the consolidated revenue and the draw down is totally utilised by previous commitments for management and administration costs but actually has no additional money to provide for acquisition or management? That is the second question.

Is the government not capable of overcoming some of these technical problems? I did understand the answer that Senator Evans gave and I do see it as a possible chicken and egg problem. If it is true that this amendment means that the money cannot be drawn down till they are already expending it, because we do not know how much it is, then that is a problem. But surely the government has the skill of reading the spirit of the amendment, which is to quarantine the administration costs from eating away the acquisition and management sections of the fund. If the government is so concerned about the lack of sympathy on the opposition side, why is it not willing to let the opposition support this motion as a sign of its goodwill that if it were to be in a position to be requested for such an appropriation it would be on the public record as having committed itself to doing so?
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot has pointed out to me that the opposition changed its stance on migration, and I do think that is regrettable, especially as it seems to be a double dissolution trigger. But I also think it is despicable of the government to use that tactic of a double dissolution trigger to try to bully its way through with this particular bill. So it has some relevance.

PARA.TAB: My final question explains the second question that Senator Evans failed to answer. Has the government in its own mind got no limit at all that it is going to allow for the administration costs or the legal costs that come out of this fund and, by virtue of the way it is designed, deny the dispossessed Aboriginal people, who are supposed to be the beneficiaries of the fund, from gaining any acquisition or management funding?

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has made perfectly clear that we have complete confidence in the structure created and the people who will occupy the positions to behave in a responsible fashion and not to spend more money on administration than is strictly required on a year-to-year basis. That confidence is reinforced by all the scrutiny processes and accountability processes that are built into the legislation and which we have debated on other occasions.

PARA.TAB: To treat this particular corporation differently from the way in which we treat all other commercial corporations established by statute of which I am aware is to introduce a wholly new element of paternalism in our approach to the boards in question which I would have thought Senator Chamarette would agree was inappropriate. It does involve a degree of faith and confidence in the quality of the boards that we produce and their particular responsibility to the people whom this legislation is designed to help. That is essentially the answer—a combination of not wanting to be paternalistic combined with confidence in the structures and processes and confidence in the people who are likely to be appointed. There is plenty of statutory guidance on what sort of people they must be.

As to the question of when the fund would cease to operate if there was no cap, for a start, there is a draw down permitted of about $45 million a year, as Senator Chamarette says. I do not think in any conceivable scenario a significant proportion of that larger sum of $45 million would be occupied in administrative expenses. Even in a catastrophic litigation or expense environment, it is difficult to see any sort of massive invasion of that. But it is very easy to see the way in which any given amount of $3 million or $3 million plus could be exceeded in any particular year. It is for that reason that we want to give the corporation the flexibility to manage.

There is a top-up provision in the bill as it stands to cope with a situation where the investment return on the fund might have been less in practice than that which we anticipate. There is no similar top-up, I suppose, to cover administrative costs which turn out to be in excess of what we are guessing to be, on average, about $3 million a year. I guess in that exceptional circumstance, where some massive impost does arise—some major series of litigation burdens—it would always be open to the parliament in that situation to respond generously and appropriately and say, `Under these circumstances there is too much of a burden being borne by the basic fund itself, against our intentions and our expectations, and we'll make a special supplementary appropriation to deal with that.'

We can envisage that possibility. But that is very different from every year this process being dependent on that degree of parliamentary goodwill. If the fund is to be able to manage at all and not just go into massive debt to its own staff and creditors and become, in effect, non-functional if it exceeds its cap, where you have a situation where that could arise in any given year now because of the inability to draw upon the larger fund, in that event arising in any given year, the corporation would again be dependent upon the charity, the largess, the goodwill of the parliament. That is something which, with all the optimism in the world, I do not think we can rely upon.

Senator Chamarette said, finally, why do we not just sit back and enjoy the assurances we will no doubt hear from Senator Alston and other opposition senators that, of course, they will not be miserable and mean spirited. Maybe they will not be, as individuals. I cannot imagine Senator Panizza being miserable and mean spirited. He does not have a miserable or mean spirited bone in his body. He is a gentleman. But he may not be in the cabinet. He is not yet on the frontbench and he still has a bit of distance to cover; not that there are not plenty of people that he should be able to leap over but that is another story.

These bland assurances from people who may or may not be around for very much longer, in the context of a party which, with the utmost respect, does not have a terrific track record in consistency on basic policy positions, are not good enough for this kind of fund, corporation, and policy commitment that the government is wanting to make and the Australian people are clearly wanting to make to Aboriginal people. For all those complex reasons, however much you twist and turn and fiddle and fix the terms of this particular clause as proposed, we believe it is fatally flawed and we will oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe this amendment is an improvement, either. I think we all clearly understand the principle that we are talking about—the quarantining of administration costs from the purpose of the bill. We understand that, but it sounds a bit like the small government argument—the assumption that everything is automatically wasteful and inefficient. I agree that that is a rather paternalistic assumption in this case, but I want to talk about the principle because Senator Chamarette has talked about the spirit of it. I think we understand that as well. Where else does this principle apply now? Are the opposition and the Greens intending to apply this principle generally in the future? I do not know whether that might make it harder or easier to vote for, but is it an appropriate principle to apply?

PARA.TAB: Let me take an example—it is not a statutory authority, but I do not think that matters—and apply it across-the-board: think about the Liberal secretariat. What proportion of funds goes towards administration costs compared with the proportion that goes towards moneys being spent on the objective of the secretariat, which is to gain electoral success? How fixed is that amount? Where is the capacity for variation—for example, the need for extra polling because of by-elections, that sort of thing? It raises the debate that is going on in America at the moment about a balanced budget. If you are going to have a yearly appropriation, the same question applies: from where do you take that extra money?

As I heard an American senator say this morning on the radio, do you dilute the social security budget? What do you do about the need for variation? I believe that the need for variation is unpredictable. For example, look at the number of Senate committees we regularly establish here and the effect that must have on the budget of the Department of the Senate. It is not to know how many committees in response to issues are going to be established on a yearly basis. So the idea of a yearly appropriation goes against the Democrats' view that we should have greater certainty of funding. I think we should have triennial funding in a huge number of instances to allow for better planning and certainty.

So on two grounds, firstly on the grounds of the application of the principle, the assumption that automatically the administration of the corporation will be inefficient and wasteful, and on the second ground of the inappropriateness of reducing funding to a yearly appropriation dependent on the whim of parliament when I think that a triennial fund is preferable, the Democrats cannot support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are talking about paternalism, why does the government not hand over its $200 million this year and $121 million for the following nine years to Aboriginal people right now and let them determine the expropriation they are going to put for acquisition, how much they are using for management and how much they are using for administration? The Greens would have no difficulty with leaving totally free how much was expended on administration and available to Aboriginal people themselves to determine within their own priorities if it were a larger amount. But the reality is that by giving them only $24 million beyond what ATSIC already utilises, the amount used on administration will actively intrude upon what is made available in the fund.

PARA.TAB: I do not know of any organisation in the community that, if it is given a fund for a certain purpose, can use up the entire amount of that fund for the administration of the fund and not be accountable for how much is available to the people who are supposed to be the beneficiaries of the fund. If that accountability has to come via a parliamentary expropriation, my view is so be it. It is irresponsible of the government to say, `We have set up a fund. We do not want to be paternalistic apart from fact we are only giving $45 million a year instead of the $200 million a year we are keeping in government funding' and then to say, `and we do not mind whether it all gets taken by administration or legal costs such that there is nothing available to be used for the fund.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of matters that I would like to raise. Firstly, I will respond to Senator Kernot's comments. We are all very interested in the principle and we certainly will not for a moment accept the concept of paternalism. What we are anxious to do is ensure that as much as possible of the funds appropriated by the parliament are there for the real purpose which is land acquisition and maintenance. The analogy you draw about the Liberal Party is quite misplaced and I will tell you why. It is not substantially relying on moneys appropriated by the parliament as much as you might depend entirely on public funding. For our part, we use that money as best we can. If we misuse it then those who suffer are the members of the party at the polls and the people—
—What proportion is spent on administration; that was an example.
—Your underlying principle was that if we do not provide a strict limit for a political party why should we set one for an indigenous land corporation.
—I was talking about the need for variation.

—I think it would vary quite substantially depending upon your position. If, for example, you were 30 per cent ahead in the polls and this mob were dead in the water you might spend a lot less than if it was very close. The amount that you could afford to spend on administration would vary accordingly. For our part, we might not object if you then decided to spend a lot more on so-called administration or improving the quality of the premises.
—But you have the capacity to vary it, don't you.

—Precisely, but that is because those funds are used in an entirely private and discretionary manner whereas these funds are appropriated by the parliament. If what the parliament seeks to do is to ensure that as much as possible is used for land acquisition and maintenance, then I would have thought that if you are going to come back to the parliament to ask for an increase you would be much better off coming back asking for more in administration. If you found, for example, that they were subject to a whole swag of very expensive court cases then you have the capacity not just to ask for $3 million plus indexation but to ask for a lot more for administration. Whereas, if you went down the other path, you have to come back and ask for the real moneys to be appropriated.

PARA.TAB: Given that the government presumably does not have any target in the mind, it seems to be quite relaxed about the possibility of substantial portions being eaten up by those sorts of special claims being made on the fund. If that is the case, it would then ultimately be left to the vagaries of the parliament to try and top up the process after the event. This at least gives you the opportunity to decide whether or not you think administration expenses are under control and to provide for the funds accordingly.

Does the minister agree that 121 plus zero equals 121? If it does, as I think it does, then I cannot see how you could ever be in a situation where no funds could be appropriated until the parliament had identified the precise sum in excess of $3 million. I do not think we need to canvass what might happen down the track with a change of government other than to say that this legislation makes it perfectly clear that the parliament is expected to appropriate that money—it does not say `may appropriate' it says `to be appropriated'; that is a command—and I think any reasonable person looking at the legislation would assume that what would happen is that, as a matter of course, an amount of least $3 million would be appropriated. As I say, there is the discretion to go well beyond indexation if the circumstances warrant. I would like the minister's view on the basis on which he would argue that 121 plus zero does not equal 121.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must have missed something there because 121 plus zero does equal 121. The problem is that section 193(5) talks about the consolidated revenue fund being appropriated for the purposes of this section. You cannot appropriate an uncertain amount. You can appropriate in accordance with a formula, as the existing clause does, but once you add the additional element in that formula about an appropriation of an additional $3 million plus a year—and the plus is an uncertain factor, as it needs to be for good policy reasons—then you cannot have an appropriation which actually bites here in terms of the actual bill or act as it will be. It can only bite subject to a contingency being satisfied each year.

PARA.TAB: That is the technical reason. We can argue until the cows come home about the technical reasons, but it is still a policy flaw that I have described in terms of the practical limitations that your scheme proposes. I do not think we are going to reach agreement about that so we may as well put it to a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just provide a concluding comment, if we are reaching the conclusion of the debate on this amendment. During the committee's taking of evidence, a great deal of support was found for this quarantining of administrative costs. Page 14 of the committee's report refers to evidence given by Mr Noel Pearson:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have reservations as well about too much of the funds being consumed by an alternative bureaucracy rather than being applied towards the central purpose [of land acquisition]—

There was a good deal of evidence given, which is not quoted there, where people said that they were concerned that administrative costs would unduly eat into funds available for land acquisition and management. So the primary aspect of quarantining administrative expenditure met with the approval of a majority of those people who appeared before the committee.

PARA.TAB: The concern we found was that there was a cap. That has been addressed because we have now ensured that at least $3 million be provided. To that extent I believe the coalition's amendment has met the concerns of a vast majority of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, and that has been gauged after a wide ranging consultative process by a select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a proposal. I actually am not totally convinced by the minister's arguments against this amendment. However, if he feels that it is a real problem, I would ask the opposition to consider my proposed amendment. I have not fully written it, so I will just say it and then write it. I would like the opposition to give this consideration. I foreshadow an amendment to the clause that Senator Gareth Evans is concerned about; that is, 193(5), to have the words `except in respect of administrative expenses' put in immediately prior to the phrase `the consolidated revenue fund is appropriated for the purposes of this section'. I seek the opposition's response to that amendment and perhaps also the minister's because it may well overcome his technical problems with this amendment.

—I suppose for our part we would like to consider the implications of that. No doubt the government would as well because I am sure it is acting in good faith and is wanting to be of as much assistance to Senator Chamarette and the Senate as possible. On that basis, we would be happy to have that matter considered at a later time. I acknowledge what Senator Chamarette is trying to achieve and, if it does achieve that purpose, we would be quite prepared to consider it further.

—Can I just say that, while subject to further advice that might well go to solve part of the problem, it does not by any means go to some of the larger drafting problems that seem to leap out from the opposition's amendment. I have just been a given a note about some discussions that have taken place this morning in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel about some other technical problems that are associated with this amendment. In particular, they stem from the fact that ILC money is supposed to come by way of draw-down from the land fund, and the money is appropriated from consolidated revenue into the land fund rather than being appropriated from consolidated revenue directly to the ILC. Now we have amendments which in terms are saying, in effect, that the money is coming from the consolidated revenue fund. That is the way in which, I am advised, your amendments are drafted. That is a clear implication of them.
—The $3 million plus consolidated revenue. That does not stop the $121 million coming into it.

—But the combination of having moneys coming from different sources in this way apparently, I am told, creates a whole series of further drafting problems, in particular in your amendments 3(b), (c), (d) and (e). The drafting, with utmost respect to whoever advised you, is described by parliamentary counsel in the note in front of me as one of the most bizarre provisions he has ever seen.
—How long has he been there?

—I would have thought if he has been there even for a year you ought to hang your head in shame, but I think the gentleman in question has been there rather longer than that. My point is that I genuinely think you have got yourselves into all sorts of tangles here and I doubt very much if they are going to be fixable by a relatively simple amendment of the kind Senator Chamarette suggests.

PARA.TAB: I would like to get this out of the way, but if you want to consider that for an hour or something or get someone considering it while we are debating other matters and come back to it at a later stage, I will not resist that. But I do make the point that, however much you move yourselves around in order to solve a technical problem, you still have a basic practical problem and principled problem, from the government's point of view, and you are not going to satisfy us at the end of the day unless you abandon this whole scheme.

We still have ourselves in a degree of difficulty and I think that degree of difficulty is shared by Senator Kernot. The technical problems that I have identified and which may or may not be fixable are only part of the problem. So you might like to bear that in mind as you ponder your further course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, from what you have just said, it does not seem to me that simply having to have moneys come from two separate sources

SPEECH.PARA: constitutes any insuperable obstacle. That seems to be a distinction without a difference, as far as I am concerned. Therefore, we certainly would not acknowledge that there are technical problems that render the purpose unachievable, simply that what you are doing in the best way possible, in a classic example of casuistry, is finding technical objections. As was once said of Mohammed Ali, he was always able to find a difficulty with any solution. I am quite sure that most of what you have foreshadowed here would be utterly theoretical and would not constitute any problem in practice.

PARA.TAB: There does seem to be distinct lack of goodwill on the part of the government to make this work. There is no suggestion that anyone else would not want to make it work. In those circumstances, we would still take the view that the amendment does the job. Certainly in deference to Senator Chamarette we would be prepared to reflect on the further form of words and see whether that does in any way take the matter further.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be happier to leave the consideration of my amendment to a later time to see whether it does actually create more problems than it solves, go onto other sections of the amendment that we have under consideration and come back to my amendment at a later time after these amendments have been dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That being the case, we move on to amendment 3(f), which I called amendment 2 of the package. That is the amendment which states:

SPEECH.PARA: " `(4) In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take reasonable steps to inform itself whether any interest to be acquired in land is subject to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 of that Act.'.".

We saw recently in South Australia the rather tragic circumstances of an Aboriginal person being killed in a dispute over land. There have been some other incidents of disputes over land and there have been assaults and rather violent confrontations. This amendment purports to avoid that situation arising.

PARA.TAB: Originally, the coalition thought it would be wise for the Indigenous Land Corporation to make a non-claimant application in an area where it thought there might be native title in order to clear the slate, to make sure there were no existing native title claimants who might come along at a later stage, after the land had been acquired and given to another Aboriginal group, and challenge that.

What it seeks to do is avoid confrontation between those Aboriginal people who cannot maintain a claim for native title and those who can. There are areas on the fringes of regional centres and the more remote parts of Australia where this could well be the case. In fact my state of Western Australia has, I would suggest, great tracts of land where you could possibly have the ILC going to acquire a station, for instance, for Aboriginal people under this scheme and find that there are native title claimants in the area. In fact there are presently native title claims—the Miriwoong-Kadjerong, for instance, which covers a good many pastoral leases which the Indigenous Land Corporation might otherwise be interested in obtaining for other Aboriginals who cannot make a native title claim. So that was the rationale behind this.

But as I said, during the course of evidence it was indicated for two reasons that a non-claimant application was not a good idea. The first was that it would unduly tie up the Indigenous Land Corporation in sorting out the question of native title; that is, a non-claimant application under the Native Title Act could take many, many months and there would be no action in the interim and you would not get anywhere.

The other aspect is perhaps a more fundamental concern and touches on the legality of it; that is, in order to make a non-claimant application there is a body of opinion which is developing, and I believe so in the Native Title Tribunal, that you must have an interest in the land before making a non-claimant application. This is where I think the Native Title Act is going to have to be looked at because the non-claimant application was brought in for someone who is going to do something in an area where there were no native title claims pending. The person intending to do something could bring on the issue, bring it to a head so to speak, by making a non-claimant issue and asking, `Is there any native title claimant out there?'
