That was basically the purpose of it. That could then result in clearing the decks or flushing out any claimants in the alternative.

There is a concern that you just cannot willy-nilly make a non-claimant application. You have to have some sort of nexus with the land in question, some sort of legal interest. Of course, the Indigenous Land Corporation would not have that necessary tie with the land where it is approaching the land ab initio and is about to purchase it or lease it in some way. That might then preclude it from making a non-claimant application. So the modification to this amendment was done in relation to evidence received during these hearings. I commend the amendment to the chamber. I believe it is in a preferable form to that which was hitherto couched.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support the amendment but let me say quickly that we do agree with the opposition that it is no longer appropriate to make this reference to the ILC making a non-claimant application. It is the case, as quickly became apparent when we all went back and looked at the provisions in the Native Title Act, that the ILC would simply not be able to make a non-claimant application in most of the situations here in contemplation because of the need for anyone making such an application to have an interest in the relevant land. As such, we completely agree with what Senator Ellison says. There is not much point in keeping a reference in those terms if it was not going to have any practical utility.

PARA.TAB: We only agreed to that particular phrase going in, in fact I think suggested originally that it go in, in order to do something to try and improve the text of a basic amendment moved by the opposition which we felt uncomfortable with. We still feel uncomfortable with that basic text. We feel even more uncomfortable with it standing alone without the possibility of a capacity to go to the tribunal on a non-claimant application basis for the reasons that I will now set out and which reasons lead us to now oppose the amendment as a whole.

The problem is that you are, in the guise of doing something that is a model of sweet reason, obliging the ILC to go down a path that will place unnecessary and onerous burdens upon it and, in particular, potentially expose it to quite a lot of litigation and certainly an enormous amount of delay in the performance of its functions. What exactly are reasonable steps that the ILC must take in determining whether the land is subject to native title rights or interests is uncertain in the nature of things and the nature of language. What constitutes reasonableness is a matter about which people can and do argue. Moreover, they can argue about it in court, because that is a question that would certainly be justiciable.

What we are talking about here is not just taking reasonable steps to determine whether someone has some claim that they want to make which the ILC ought to take into account as part of its general cautionary approach to making sure that it is acting consistently with the philosophy of the legislation. What you have got in the way in which the provision is drawn is an obligation on the corporation to inform itself whether any interest to be acquired in land is subject to native title or native title rights. That is an immensely difficult thing to establish.

We all know how complex the whole business of determining native title is. It is not just whether someone is making a claim or whether there is a potential complication in the acquisition; the corporation has to take steps to inform itself whether the land is subject to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 of the act. That is no short or limited inquiry. That is an absolutely major exercise.

Now, it is qualified—it says `reasonable steps'. But, as I have already said, what are reasonable steps in all the circumstances is very much a matter to be resolved by the courts, and it will certainly be the subject of a process of litigation to establish just what that means. We need a further process of litigation impacting on the corporation like a hole in the head.

The other thing that needs to be said is that the ILC itself and its immediate staff cannot be expected necessarily to have the expertise and resources to perform this kind of investigation. If it starts acquiring the body of expertise and resources to do it, it will add very substantially to the administrative expenses that we have been discussing under a previous amendment. Moreover, as a further practical problem, the requirement that a competing native title claim be effectively decided prior to the acquisition of land means that opportunities for the purchase of land are bound to be lost while that process is undertaken.

Moreover again, there is a further practical problem. By flagging, as this process would, the ILC's interest in a particular parcel of land, the investigation of title would almost certainly lead to vendors thus armed and informed demanding a higher price for the land in question, thus generating less value in the land fund dollar as a result. Each of those matters I have mentioned might individually have only a small impact. That is perfectly possible, but cumulatively, or in some cases individually, they might well have a very major impact indeed.

Again, you have a situation where, at first blush, you look at this amendment and it looks reasonable. Of course the ILC should have regard to some likely claim that may be hanging around, because the basic point of this exercise after all is not to trespass in the area dealt with philosophically and practically by the Native Title Act. This is to enable the acquisition of other land which does not necessarily have any traditional connections at all in order to meet other objectives—to meet the land needs of the dispossessed.

On the face of it, it does not look unreasonable, and I acknowledge that. That is one of the reasons why we wrestled in the last committee stage of the debate to give some content to this particular clause which would make it a bit more workable in practice.

But when we strip out the reference to the ILC itself going down that track—as we have to, for reasons that Senator Ellison has explained—we really do strip out the last relatively straightforward mechanical route by which this matter could be resolved, we create a whole new layer of uncertainty and we still have all the problems of delay and expense that are associated with a provision of this kind. The government is genuinely concerned about these kinds of provisions littering the bill. They are among that series of provisions which I have previously elsewhere identified as `the seven deadly sins of the legislation', because their cumulative impact on making the bill unworkable in practice is simply immense.

No doubt the opposition will not be moved by anything I have just said about this. But I do ask those opposite to take seriously the genuineness of the government's concern about this provision and others like it. They will make the practical operation of this legislation immensely difficult. We oppose the amendment in its stripped down form still for that reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Gareth Evans's concern as to what steps the Indigenous Land Corporation should take to inform itself as to whether any interest in land to be acquired is subject to native title, he did concede that the steps must be reasonable. Of course, that is the aspect that the coalition looked at. It is not an absolute obligation that the corporation must clear the slate, so to speak; it is simply that it must take reasonable steps to inform itself.

PARA.TAB: We now have a register of claims that have been lodged and decisions that have been made being accumulated by the Native Title Tribunal. A quick reference to the Native Title Tribunal could reveal what claims are pending in the area and what decision has been made. We can also, I believe—and this is by inquiry that the joint native title committee has made with the Native Title Tribunal—ascertain whether there might be any intended claims. What it has are situations where someone has come in and said, `Look, we want to claim this area' and it has referred them to one of the representative bodies or sent them away to rejig their application. It is able to tell us whether a claim has been or is yet to be accepted or not. Nonetheless, the Native Title Tribunal now has at its disposal a wide range of information as to claims which are in the offing, claims which have been accepted and claims which have been decided.

There is the question of what reasonable steps should be taken; they are readily ascertainable. What this simply says is that the ILC goes to the Native Title Tribunal, makes an inquiry, and perhaps makes one or two inquiries in the area where the land is. It would have to do that anyway because it would want to know if the government had any plans to put a highway through the land or whether there were any town planning arrangements which might affect it.

In the normal course of events, individuals purchasing a house make inquiries as to what the local council has planned for their area. It is a normal process of inquiry that, when purchasing land, a person make these sorts of inquiries. This is an inquiry which is no more onerous than ascertaining what town planning has developed for an individual's area, or what the shire council has designated, or whether there is any easement over the property an individual is about to purchase. Those sorts of inquiries are made in Australia day in and day out.

These reasonable steps, which have now been watered down by the exclusion of a non-claimant application, simply would involve the ILC in making such inquiries. These could be done at the same time that, if it is to function efficiently, it has to make due inquiry as to the land it is about to purchase or lease. In other respects, it has to do those other things that any individual would do in a commercial sense, and this can be done at the same time. I do not see how it adds to the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison always puts the most reasonable, gentle and benign face possible on a lousy case. The truth of the matter is that those opposite are stuck with the terms of their own amendment. The amendment does not say we have to take such reasonable steps as are necessary to establish whether any native title claim has been endorsed by the tribunal; it does not say we have to take such reasonable steps as are necessary to establish whether any native title claim has been registered by the registrar; it does not say we have to take such reasonable steps as are necessary to establish whether a native title claim has been lodged with the registrar but not yet registered. What it says is that you have to take such reasonable steps as are necessary to establish whether any native title rights actually exist.

PARA.TAB: In terms of your own legislation, you have got to go to the underlying legal reality, not just what has been registered and not just what is extant as a claim. You have got to look at whether the actual right exists within the meaning of section 223 of the Native Title Act—the right or the interest and concern. So you are stuck with the terms of your own legislation. If all it involved were the ILC informing itself of what is actually around and it taking that into account in its own judgment as to whether to proceed or not, there is no hassle about that. I am sure the ILC in practice would do just that before acquiring a piece of land. As a practical matter, it would inform itself in that easy way by going to the registers and asking what is before the registrar that may not have been on the former register at this stage. There is no reason why it should not do that, and I am sure that, as a practical matter, it is a very simple inquiry. It is just like going to the titles office and seeing what is on the list. But that is not what your amendment says. So you are stuck again with some lousy drafting. Lousy policy follows from lousy drafting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Evans where he sees that there is this obligation on the Indigenous Land Corporation to make the decision whether native title exists. This is saying that it is a lesser standard. All the Indigenous Land Corporation has to do is take reasonable steps to inform itself whether interest to be acquired in land is subject—
—Is subject to—
—To native title.
—No, not native title claim; is subject to native title.

—To inform itself is of a lower standard than the absolute, which is to make a decision whether it exists or not. That was why it was included—to inform itself. When you purchase a house and you want to make sure that there is no town planning—say, there is a restrictive covenant on second stories—you make an inquiry to inform yourself, and that is it. You might incorrectly inform yourself. This allows for the ILC to take the reasonable steps to inform itself. If it takes reasonable steps but still incorrectly informs itself, it is okay because it has taken the reasonable step, and that is a lower standard.

—I am sorry, it is not like the analogy of looking up a Torrens title certificate. Native title is not contingent for its existence on its being certified or on its being recorded. Native title is out there subject to recognition by appropriate process. If it were the case that anything that constituted native title, or a right or interest under native title, had to be already recorded and registered somewhere—as is the case with ordinary land law systems—then I would not have too much difficulty about agreeing with you that that was the meaning of the section. But you have got to inform yourself, not just of what is on the books as already having been recorded and registered as native title; you have got to inform yourself as to what is native title—whether this land is subject to native title or whether it is subject to native rights and interests.

PARA.TAB: I am not being cantankerous or difficult or in any way introducing issues which are not real issues. The truth of the matter is that, literally read and construed and knowing what we know about native title, you are creating a very onerous obligation on the ILC. It may be that, through some process of court adjudication, the court will say that reasonable steps, in the context of this particular clause as drafted, means doing what you are talking about—going to the registrar and looking at what has been registered because it would be unreasonable to ask the ILC to do more than that. But you cannot make that assumption now. I cannot make that assumption now. And certainly we know that getting to that point would require a process of litigation which is absolutely, unnecessarily burdensome. I do not want to prolong the argument. I will not contribute any further. I think that I have outlined all the points that I possibly can.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments we just heard from Senator Gareth Evans really go to show that the flaws are not with Senator Ellison's drafting; the flaws we have to deal with are conceptual flaws that were created in the first place by virtue of the Native Title Act. This was one of the concerns that coalition senators had some 14 or 15 months ago when the Native Title Bill was brought before the parliament: the unworkability of ascertaining whether or not something was or was not native title.

PARA.TAB: But Senator Evans also makes a mistake because he fails to understand what Senator Ellison is really saying. Senator Ellison is saying it will be for the ILC to take reasonable steps to ascertain that land is not native title land. In that context, taking reasonable steps can only mean making such inquiries as to ascertain whether land is registered as native title land or whether it is likely to be native title land.

That is a commonsense process which can be confused by only somebody like Senator Evans. It is a commonsense process. It is commonsense wording. On the face of the wording of the amendment that Senator Ellison has, everybody understands what it is. Senator Evans wants to run around, he wants to obfuscate the issue and he wants to try to find whatever pitiful excuse he can for not accepting this amendment.

This amendment is perfectly commonsense and the fact that Senator Evans is trying to run away from it only demonstrates two things: first of all, the government does not have good faith in this matter; and, secondly, any problems that are encountered in this are problems which arise by virtue of the confused nature of the Native Title Act, and for that the government ought to be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a little hard hearing these two lawyers debate across the chamber, each sounding quite persuasive. I do not think we should take the issue of opportunities for litigation as the only premise on which we decide whether or not to support this amendment. I support the principle of what Senator Ellison is trying to achieve. Perhaps the government could find another way to do that, although I am hearing that it cannot be done. From what Senator Evans is saying, I think he understands that, too. He does not think it is a bad thing but thinks the way the opposition is doing it is totally inappropriate.

—I do not know where our responsibility begins and ends to fix up the sort of trail of wreckage that the opposition is perpetrating. In terms of making the point that I made, it is a relatively simple matter to draft that the ILC would be required to inform itself of any native title claims registered or pending through the proper processes. If those opposite are prepared to accept a redrafting in those terms, I personally—I am saying this completely without instructions—could not have any difficulty with that because I think in practice that is exactly what the ILC will do.
—What would you accept?

—I would accept something along the lines of `inform itself to the extent of looking at what is registered native'—I will not try to draft this now. Let me start again. There are three levels. Level one is the potential claims which are actually lodged with the registrar but have not yet been accepted by the registrar. That is easily ascertainable. Those claims have no status whatsoever but the ILC ought arguably to be aware of them. Level two is claims which have been accepted by the registrar as having some prima facie status and certainly ought to have regard to by the ILC. That is easily establishable. Thirdly, of course there are native title rights that have been recognised by the Native Title Tribunal and certified to exist as such by the Native Title Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: Those three categories of things are easily checkable. I have no disagreement whatsoever that they ought to be checked. Whether we need a legislative obligation to do that is another question. But, if an amendment being cast in those terms would satisfy those opposite, I think we can readily accept that. I am happy to get something like that drafted. But to go beyond that in the way those opposite are proposing—I think Senator Ellison can understand the point; I do not know about Billy O'Chee—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, really—come on Gareth!

—I am trying to be gentle with Senator O'Chee. I could be a lot rougher. Senators can understand what I am getting at: there is a real problem about having to penetrate the mists of all this area of native title rights that may exist but have not yet been subject to any of this kind of process. There are plenty of those around, and that is a very onerous obligation. If opposition senators are serious about making life a bit easier for the corporation, they would accept that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister saying that he will actually support that amendment if it is rephrased that way? We have been down this street before because you actually, in a very skilful and adroit way of drafting on the floor of the chamber, amended it such that the government agreed with it last time. Now the government has withdrawn its support of it. I would consider supporting it if the government were saying that it is supporting it, but only if it has some kind of seriousness about it.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Evans is merely trying to play with something about which he has no genuine will to improve the legislation and is not intending really to support the spirit under which the amendments are being placed. So we should not waste the Senate's time by mucking around with phrasing that the government may or may not agree to for one amendment if it is not proposing to take the whole matter seriously of improving the bill to such a point where it will support it. I would like to say why we are putting these amendments up. If people had bothered to refer to the committee report, they would have seen on page 15 the concern expressed in our consultations. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The principle of ensuring that the rights of traditional owners be protected was strongly supported by many witnesses. The issue of the potential for conflict where due consultation with traditional owners does not occur is considered in the discussion of Amendment 26 below.

It is that reason for which this particular amendment was put in. It is a response to concerns. I was there and repeatedly we heard people say that, while they do want to benefit from the land fund, they do not want to benefit at the detriment of people who may be found to have a legitimate native title right. By specifying those three things we are stating the obvious. It is perfectly possible for any court that is in dispute over this to refer back to the minister's words to ascertain what these reasonable steps might be.

PARA.TAB: I think the spirit with which the people raised the concern was that there should be some onus on the ILC to actually be informed about any people who have even the potential to make native title claims. So I would rather support the original amendment. If the government is so persuasive that, for its purposes, it wants support for its amendment, then it can put that up and I will be prepared to look at it; but I ask the government to scrutinise its motives in this.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are jumping ahead a bit here, but it may assist the debate if we knew the government's attitude to amendment 4 in this package which says that, before the Indigenous Land Corporation performs a land acquisition function, it must take all reasonable steps to consult with those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having traditional or historic links with the land. In that process you are going to refine or sift through those which might have a native title claim. If you consult with those people who have their traditional and historic links with the land, you are soon going to get an idea as to whether any of them are going to mount a native title claim.

PARA.TAB: This is perhaps the second arm of the process of trying to ward off any potential conflict between potential native title claimants and those who cannot claim native title for which this land fund is designed to help. So if you had the suggestion that Senator Evans has given that, in ascertaining under proposed subsection 191D(4) this rather mechanical process of looking at the native title tribunal on the one hand and, on the other hand, having the aspect that before it does anything it must consult with those who have these traditional links, then you could perhaps cover the field. You might then allay the concerns that the committee heard of the sorts of potential conflicts between native title claimants and those who cannot make a native title claim.

For instance, in a given area, say the Kimberley area, just around Kununurra, there would be people who would have traditional and historic links. There would also be some people living on the outskirts of town who are not living in a traditional way, who have perhaps moved from another area and do not have that historic or traditional link with the land.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The ILC in that case, if it wants to get a pastoral lease for those who cannot make a native title claim, would check with the Native Title Tribunal to see whether there was any claim pending. If there is a claim pending, it knows to stay away until that matter is resolved; that is easy. But if there is no claim registered with the native title registry, nor is there one in the offing, it still has to consult with the people in the area who have traditional links. So it makes the inquiry, `Are there any people in the area who have that link?' Perhaps there is a clan of people who say, `Yes, we have lived here all along. We don't know anything about native title. We haven't given it a moment's thought but now that we know about it, we might make a claim.'
—It doesn't say `in the area'. It says `people generally who have traditional or historic links with the land'.

—It relates back to the land acquisition. Senator Kernot has asked: with regard to the consultation with the people formerly known as traditional owners—and we have jettisoned that description—the people who have traditional or historic links with the land, are we referring to any land or are we referring to the land in question? That must be tied back to a land acquisition function. So if you are performing that function with respect to a piece of land, by that drafting you must consult with the people who have traditional links with that land, not with other land, which would be irrelevant. So that consultation process is very important.

PARA.TAB: If the government were to agree to amendment No. 4, we would have the two limbs. We would have the mechanical check and the consultation with the traditional people. In that way we would overcome the concerns expressed by Senator Chamarette. If the government says, `No, we don't agree with that,' we do have a bit of a problem, as Senator Chamarette puts it, in that we might not have that consultation with the people in the area. So I think it is important that we know what the government's reaction is to amendment No. 4 before we talk about amendment No. 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question was not about which piece of land. In Senator Ellison's explanation he talked about people with traditional and historic links with the land, but he talked about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the area. My question was: if they are not in the area how do you determine where they are, what links they might have and how you consult with them?

—Again, the reasonable steps would require us to consult only in that area. That is why `reasonable' is inserted. The fact is that there could be a group which has since moved away from the Kimberley region to the south-west of Australia. Of course, we could not really expect the Indigenous Land Corporation to spend years ascertaining the movements of the various groups and tracking them down.

PARA.TAB: Stephen Davis, in his remapping of the tribal areas, clans and subdivisions of Australia, found how one group in South Australia had basically crossed the desert, the interior, to get to the north-west of Australia. It took Stephen Davis nearly two years to travel around the country and work that out. He did that by comparing songs which he tape recorded in South Australia and played back to some traditional people in the north-west.

I do not think that proposed section demands that sort of inquiry at all. The words `reasonable steps to consult' mean that in the circumstances we would go into the area and say, `Who are the traditional people in this area? Are there any traditional people in the area?' The Broome Crocodile Farm was an instance involving the Yawuru people, and the Djugan people said that they had some involvement with the land which was the subject of the dispute with the minister.

Having been to Broome and having had some association with that area, I know that you can without much inquiry ascertain the relevant language groups and skin groups, as they are referred to. It does not take much. The Djugans had been removed some years ago. There were one or two left and they surfaced very readily. You just have to speak to one or two people in the town, a few elders, and you get to the bottom of things pretty quickly. You do not have to travel all over the state trying to find out where people have gone. You will generally get a ready history of the area. That is as far as you can go. Those are the reasonable steps you take in consultation.

If you went to some areas of the Pilbara you would find it very hard to find traditional groups because they have been absent for well over 50 years. In fact, in some areas of the Pilbara there have not been any groups at all because of reasons of taboo and the like. Similarly with Eneabba, in Western Australia. I think Southern Cross, where Senator Panizza comes from, is another area where you will not find Aboriginal people and nor will you find a history of them because traditionally it has been a no-go area for them. They have had no association with that land because of a spiritual aspect.

The reasonable steps to consult with those people are just that. You go to the area, you make inquiries with the elders in the area if there are any and you talk to Aboriginal people in the area. That is not extensive, it is quite reasonable and it is does not cast an undue burden on the ILC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, as to my and the government's motives in this matter, which were so unhappily impugned by Senator Chamarette, they are absolutely squeaky clean. We want to get the best bill possible in the shortest possible time. That has been our motivation from the outset. It remains our motivation. We are not going to accept a bill which is unworkable and which we think is wrong in principle. But if we can improve it to the point where it is workable and acceptable we will grab it because we believe we have a responsibility to the Aboriginal people to do just that. We think we have demonstrated our bona fides in this respect by having accepted 28 amendments, a number of them against our better judgment in the sense that we did not think they were strictly necessary, but very helpful. We have accepted 28 amendments with a view to getting something acceptable out of this process. So please, let us have no more of that, Senator Chamarette. It is unworthy of you.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of a redraft of Senator Ellison's amendment 3(f), we have a draftsperson with us. She has put something in my hand which I think does what was described as the mechanical job quite succinctly and quite well. What is proposed and what we would suggest as an alternative to Senator Ellison's amendment 3(f) is this language:

SPEECH.PARA: In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must search any relevant registers of the National Native Title Tribunal to ascertain whether any claims have been lodged or accepted or determined in relation to land under consideration for acquisition.

We will circulate it later, if you like. I honestly think that meets the kinds of points that emerged in our debate earlier on so far as the objects in Senator Ellison's draft of 3(f) are concerned and what is practically, easily do-able. Whether or not it needs to be in legislative form is another question, but we would accept a provision in those terms if that is helpful in getting agreement on that particular area of contention.

PARA.TAB: As to proposed fourth amendment 3(h), in regard to the sheet that is before us and the government's attitude towards that, this again is one of those amendments that has caused us some difficulty because, on the face of it, it seems another model of sweet reason but in practice would, we believe, operate to make life very difficult to the point of unworkable for the tribunal. We took the view originally that the reference to having to consult traditional owners created exactly the sorts of problems I have been talking about in relation to having to identify individual native title rights or interests, that it demanded attention to a very complex issue, would not easily be able to be satisfied as a practical matter and would open itself up to litigation.

You are proposing to modify that and not have a reference any longer to traditional owners but rather to people with traditional or historic links with the land in question. I am afraid the difficulty we see with that—and I say this again in utmost good faith—is that there is still a statutory requirement to identify certain people and consult with them. We believe that that statutory requirement will be very difficult to satisfy.

It will certainly increase the risk of disputation and legal challenge by people who claim such links if they have not been consulted or they have been insufficiently consulted—and you know the range of responses that the administrative law system is capable of delivering to those sorts of arguments these days. It certainly means that the consultation process will be even more complex. If anything, because the category of traditional historic links with the land is even wider, there will be greater delays and risks that opportunities to purchase land will be lost.

There is a further possibility—and I am really just anticipating everything I was going say in relation to amendment 3(h), and I hope we do not repeat ourselves unduly as a result—that traditional owners, strictly so-called, and those simply with historic or traditional links with the land will turn out to be different groups with different views. It is perfectly possible to envisage a course of events in relation to a particular piece of land where the traditional owners have moved off and gone to another location and some other people have come in and established themselves historically, maybe 50 or 60 years ago, and are known to have come from another part of the country but, nonetheless, established this degree of association with the land.

Whatever the facts of the matter, one can easily envisage, because of the difficult, sensitive and rather fractious nature of the issues we are inherently dealing with here, that contention can arise. There is likely to be conflict about who has the greater attachment to the land in that sort of circumstance.

Obviously, it is important to keep the basic philosophy of this legislation on track—that the ILC be wholly sensitive to the reality of possible traditional ownership claims or related claims over the land in question. We do not want this particular legislation to be crashing in in areas where it may well be possible for the Native Title Act to apply in its own terms and to create confusion. If humanly possible we want to avoid that.

That is where these regional strategies come in. There is a provision for consultation with all relevant people and the defining of a regional strategy, but it is nothing like as precisely crafted and it is not in the context of particular pieces of land and does not, as a result, lend itself to the same sort of possibility of disputation and litigation which is the problem with these kinds of provisions.

We do believe that it is appropriate that there be some consultative process and that is provided for when the regional strategies are being put together. That is exactly what the regional strategies are all about; to develop, particularly in areas like the Kimberleys and so on, an approach to land acquisition and management which will juggle and balance the competing options of action under the Native Title Act on the one hand and action under this legislation on the other. It is not likely to be an issue in Victoria or New South Wales, but it is certainly likely to be an issue, juggling and balancing those considerations, elsewhere in the country.

That is the place for that process to work itself out. We would thoroughly expect the ILC to undertake that kind of task in much the same way as ATSIC presently does. Again, however, there is no need for that more precise, more formal legislative prescription. It really will have the potential to significantly hamstring the operations of the ILC as so many of these other amendments will do.

There is nothing wrong with this in principle and I am not suggesting for a moment that there is that kind of objection to this provision or to 3(f), for that matter, in its present form. The problems with these provisions are wholly practical in character, but it does not make them any less potentially devastating in terms of their adverse impact on the legislation. That is why we will oppose that. You should take what I have said into account. I hope it does not make life unduly onerous for you in coming back and considering a change to 3(f) on its merits, but that frankly will be our position on 3(h).

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the minister. It is in two parts. Firstly, can you point to where the adoption of regional strategies involves accommodation of traditional owners in the area and, secondly, if there were to be a modification to this amendment which reduced the likelihood of litigation, would the government then review its stance on this amendment, having regard to the fact that the government has acknowledged that the principle is a fine one but the practicality is not? I think the main objection you have on the practicality is potential litigation.
—I just missed the first part of your second question. I am sorry.
—Can you point, in the regional strategy provisions, to where there is accommodation of traditional owners being consulted?
—The first part of your second question is what I missed.

—Is there any way that the government would review its stance on this amendment if there were some modification to it which limited potential litigation? You said that one of your first concerns was that this opened up the doors for litigation to ensue if the ILC did not take the reasonable steps to consult. I am listening to that point and just exploring if there is any refinement of the wording which could assist in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to your first question, the reference that I had in mind was clause 191P(5) on page 12 of the bill. I do not think this has been amended. The bill states:

PARA.TAB: In performing functions under this section in connection with a regional area, the Indigenous Land Corporation Board:
(a)must, if any part of a region is included in the regional area, consult the Regional Council for the region; and
(b)may consult such other persons and bodies as the Board considers appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no more explicit than that. Manifestly, the intention lying behind the development of those regional strategies in situations where there may well be a significant body of traditional owners or traditional owner clans is to take that into account in exactly the same way that ATSIC endeavours to do at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Equally, I suppose that leads on and gives a suggested way through your second question. It may be possible to modify 3(h) by saying something along the lines that the ILC `may consult' such persons rather than `must, taking all reasonable steps to consult,' those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having traditional or historic links with the land. The difficulty about that is that it sounds a bit weaker than, in practice, I think it would be the disposition of the ILC to do.

If you make it a stronger statutory obligation, you are immediately plunged into the problem of justiciability, the problem of potential litigation and the problem of disaffection from those who get stroppy because they think they have been left out of the consultative process or have had their interests insufficiently taken into account. You are caught in a bit of a dilemma here. We think the best way to do it is just to leave it up to the good sense and the good faith of the ILC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wouldn't you just say `must consult with'? At least there will be a requirement.

—You are making it even harder by saying `taking out all reasonable steps'. If you must consult those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having traditional historic links with the land, you are buying yourself a very significant practical problem in identifying all those people who might be regarded as satisfying that description—finding them, talking to them and building the results into your decision making processes. Argument about what consultation involves does not merely mean coming up and waving to them. It means some sort of process, and what that process is would be the subject of some litigation.

PARA.TAB: You know enough about administrative law, Senator Alston. You are constantly telling me how little I know about the real world of practice. You know enough about the practice of administrative law at the moment, and I know enough about the practice of administrative law for us to see immediately how fertile a ground this would be for people who were minded to be disputatious about these sorts of issues. I am not sure that you were listening before when I said another kind of problem that can arise is the potential conflict between traditional owners, properly so-called, and those with historic and traditional links. These are not fanciful concerns. We know from the history of the evolution of land rights arguments up until now just how many different kinds of claimants are likely to emerge once some particular piece of land is the subject of attention.

You have the further commercial problems that flow from this. Once you create these statutory obligations upon the corporation to embark upon this consultative process with various people who are defined in various ways, you build in delays, you make it that much more difficult for them to get the kinds of deals that maximise the bang for the buck in terms of available funds and you generally create obstacles left, right and centre, even short of litigation obstacles.

Those are our concerns and they are serious concerns. I do not want to have to keep protesting my genuineness about the worries we are talking about here, but they are real. We are not making them up. I would love to be able to find an accommodation on all these things and get the bill through. I would love to be able to do it and stop fooling around wasting time. We have no other agenda. We want to get a decent bill, but this is not going to work. If you are prepared to delete `must' and substitute `may' we could live with that, but I do not think we can live with anything else. As I get some further advice, that is the best we could do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not the fact that in very many areas of administrative law you have precisely that requirement? You do that with your eyes open knowing that it may be subject to challenge but, nonetheless, you do it because you think it is a very desirable principle to espouse.

PARA.TAB: Here you are going to make the grand exception and leave consultation on a discretionary basis. I would have thought it was a fundamentally important principle that the land corporation should do its very best to consult all those who might be affected by its decisions. I do not see why you would want to water that down in this instance when you seem to be otherwise content in all sorts of other areas of administrative law to have mandatory consultation requirements, despite the fact that it may lead to litigation.

What it does do in most instances is force the particular person required, in this case the corporation, to do its very best. If it does its very best and more, then the prospects of any challenge will be pretty remote. That is as it ought to be. As you know, you cannot stop frivolous claims, but if you have gone out of your way to consult as much as possible, and what you and I would regard as reasonable, then the chances of challenges will in practice be minimal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we should debate amendment 4 separately because we are beginning to tie it in. On the part of the coalition, I signify that it is prepared to accept the draft the government has put forward in relation to amendment 3(f) so that it would read:

SPEECH.PARA: In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must search any relevant registers of the National Native Title Tribunal to ascertain whether any claims have been lodged or accepted or determined in relation to land under consideration for acquisition.
I think that brings into focus the coalition's amendment. Perhaps we can debate amendment 4 separately and not get sidetracked, but we would be prepared to accept that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Ellison for that. If we had had a similar approach to all these other areas of practical difficulties we have identified during the course of this committee stage debate we might have had a more acceptable piece of legislation. It may be that you will have a further opportunity to reconsider some of those positions.
—Are you being churlish?
—I am not being foolish. I am just saying that I am indebted to you and I hope the precedent will actually mean something in future.
—I said you should not be churlish in victory.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—It will be an amendment to your amendment, Senator Ellison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw the previous amendment and replace it with the following.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

TAB.TAB: (f)For previous amendment No. 3, substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 4, at end of proposed section 191D, add the following subsection:

" `(4) In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must search any relevant Registers of the National Native Title Tribunal to ascertain whether any claims have been lodged or accepted or determined in relation to land under consideration for acquisition.'.".

TALK.START.PARA: —That is now part of the original amendment.
—Can I suggest we put that and dispose of it?
—I was just going to say that there did not seem to be any further speakers rising. We really have one motion in front of us. The committee would probably want to take that part by part.
—We agreed ages ago to take this part by part.
—I think that was for debate. The question is that amendment (f) be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move on to amendment (g). That relates to the previous amendment No. 4, which was a somewhat controversial amendment.
—I just thought we should have (h).
—We will be reaching amendment (h) shortly.
—I thought it might have been better because we have had the debate.

—We have a suggestion from Senator Kernot that we should move on to amendment (h) because it does relate in substance to amendment (f) and that we have more or less had a debate on that and we could quickly dispose of that. I have no objection to doing it that way, if that is the wish of the chamber.
—I think that would be helpful, otherwise we would be repeating it.

—With respect to (h), I will just conclude the debate and respond to some matters which have been raised. That amendment states, `Before the Indigenous Land Corporation performs a land acquisition function . . . it must take all reasonable steps to consult those Aboriginal and Torres Islander people having traditional or historic links with the land.' We originally used the term `traditional owners' of the land and that caused some consternation, as I mentioned previously, because there was difficulty in understanding exactly what a traditional owner was.

PARA.TAB: It was suggested by the Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement of South Australia that an alternative phrase could be used whereby we stated `those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having traditional or historic links with the land'. There were a number of witnesses who said, `If you talk about traditional owners, that really is not a concept which we know because we don't have ownership as such as you have it under the Torrens system and common law; we have an ongoing association with the land based on cultural and traditional links.' That is what the High Court said in the Mabo decision and it related to such things as traditional usage of the land.

Therefore, a good many witnesses thought that the principle was very good but we just did not have it right with the traditional owners. So we took that on board and we have changed that amendment to include that. I wanted to place that on the record. The evidence of the Cape York Land Council stated—

TALK.START.PARA: —What page are you reading from?
—Page 30 of the report. The council stated:

SPEECH.PARA: With our applications to ATSIC in the past, we have always had to provide an account of consultations with the traditional owners because we end up in a terrible fight afterwards if we have not done it properly. There have been some cases where a lot of grief has resulted because there has been a perception that only some of the traditional owners have been made beneficiaries of the acquisition whilst others have been missed out. . . So I have to say that there is a definite need to sort out the traditional owner question. Once you cement the wrong group or only half of a group, as the people owning the land, you need more than a shoehorn to get the others into the picture after that, you know. You can have a terrible argument.

I think that vividly put the scenario as to what you can get if you do not consult with traditional owners. I appreciate that Senator Gareth Evans has pointed to the regional strategy function in the bill. Of course 191P(5)(a) states that, in consultation with regional strategies, the Indigenous Land Corporation:
must, if any part of a region is included in the regional area, consult the Regional Council for the region—
That is straightforward. But, in 191P(5)(b) the corporation:
may consult with such other persons and bodies as the Board considers appropriate.

The committee showed an overwhelming support, after hearing the evidence, for consultation with people with traditional or historic links to the area, and by leaving that in that form—`may consult with such other persons and bodies'—it was just too nebulous.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate that Senator Evans has mentioned that we are casting an onus on the Indigenous Land Corporation, but it is done for a good reason: there has been concern expressed that there should be some directive—that these people who have these traditional links should be consulted. So that is why we state that the Indigenous Land Corporation must take all reasonable steps—and `reasonable' has been included to alleviate the onus—to consult with those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having a traditional link with the land. If you leave it up to the ILC just to consult such other persons and bodies as it sees fit, you are not addressing the concerns that we heard before the committee that you should have this directive there.

Therefore, the coalition sticks to this amendment. It is one which I believe the government recognises as a principle, and Senator Evans has said that he has great difficulty with the efficacy and practicality of it. I think I understand Senator Evans correctly when he says that the principle might be fine, but the practicality is not.

I might say that this principle is one of the most serious principles in the land fund bill, because what you are doing is ensuring as much as possible that there is not this conflict between those who cannot claim native title and those who can. What we are endeavouring to achieve here is that you do not have those altercations such as we had in northern South Australia when someone was tragically killed, you do not have the confrontations that might develop and you do not get into the mess that the Cape York Land Council has said that you can get into if you do not consult with traditional owners.

I note that the Cape York Land Council says that it even gives an account of its consultation. It might run things very well, but there is differing opinion across the country. I base this on evidence taken over the course of 10 hearing days while travelling 12,000 kilometres around the country to capital cities and regional centres. It is not always done that way. People are saying, `We want some directive to be given that the traditional people are consulted in an effort to avoid this potential confrontation.' The tragedy would be if this land fund bill effectively were to work to cut across the bows of the Native Title Act in the way that by this confrontation it possibly could. The coalition is saying that this consultation is essential.

If the ILC did not take those consultative steps, then I believe that it should be held to account. I believe that the traditional people should be allowed to say, `Well, look, this body disregarded a directive contained in the legislation; it should be brought to account.' There is nothing wrong with a group or body, such as the ILC, being held accountable to the Aboriginal people themselves. It would be only traditional people who would bring this action; it would be those people who had not been consulted. What it would effectively result in is an Indigenous Land Corporation, ostensibly for the benefit of Aboriginal people, being held accountable to Aboriginal people.

Litigation is always to be avoided. It is always undesirable to have litigation. But it is a fact of life. It occurs in our day-to-day life, it occurs in our society, and we make provision for it in our judicial system. What this does, though, is provide accountability to the people which this bill is intended to help. If there is lack of consultation, those people who are aggrieved by it can take that action. I think it is no bad thing that that take place. I am not saying that I relish it—I do not. I am not saying that it will necessarily happen, because if the ILC takes those reasonable steps it will not be subject to challenge. It is as simple as that. The whole thrust of it is one of prevention rather than cure—to prevent the possible conflict as much as possible. I think, as a principle, it is one of the basic ones that should be found in this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a couple of questions to Senator Ellison, keeping in mind the way he has stressed the principle of avoiding conflict. I ask: does he agree with the point that Senator Gareth Evans made that the opposition, in changing its definition from traditional owners to people having traditional or historic links with the land, is creating the opportunity for conflict because it has created two distinct categories—traditional owners versus people with traditional links—and he is being perhaps asked to decide who has the greater attachment to land? Does he see that as a problem or not? I have not heard him address that.

—No, I do not. The amendment is framed, I think, quite simply and explicitly. It says that it must consult with those people having traditional or historic links with the land. There may be some people in the area who have traditional links, and we should consult with them. There may be people, however, who have historical links with the land. There is a difference between `traditional' and `historical'. In some areas we might have a group which has had an historical association with the land which has been brought about perhaps by white settlement in that they were shifted into the area—
—Yarrabah.

—Senator O'Chee has just given me an example—and that is an historical aspect. There may be other cases—and there are—where they are more traditional. That is, the group has lived there; it has had sites of cultural significance; it has hunted there; it has a spiritual association with the land. That comes more under the traditional aspect, that term of `traditional usage' which was found in the Mabo decision.

PARA.TAB: What this amendment seeks to do is to include both. If we said `traditional and' we would be making it much too restrictive. We would be saying that we would have to have both. That would be a hard bill to fill. By making it in the alternative, we do not have to choose one or the other. We can have a variety. We can have perhaps one traditional group and two historical groups. If we are dealing with a large tract of land—say, a pastoral lease of some thousands of square kilometres—we might have at one end a group that was moved there by, say, a mission or that there had been some resettlement; and at the other end we might have a group which has traditional ties.

This allows us to take both into account. It does not require a decision that one has a greater claim over the other. All it requires is that we have to look around and see whether anyone fits the bill of either traditional or historical. If there is, we must take reasonable steps to consult with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison knows that I would be the last person to pick nits about drafting in these matters, but he has not addressed the title of the subsection which still reads `Permission of traditional owners'. Since we are no longer talking about traditional owners and we are no longer talking about permission, it would seem that you had better delete that and substitute an expression like `consultation'. Perhaps you can move accordingly.

PARA.TAB: As I have previously indicated, the government does have a basic problem with this. It is not a problem of principle and it is not a problem of believing that the ILC should not have regard to the views of people that satisfy these descriptions. Of course the ILC should inform itself in the best possible way it can, particularly when plunging into a land acquisition in some sensitive area where there may be competing claims of this kind. That is exactly the same point I made before. But it is much better, I suggest, to rely on the good sense of the people that we put on the ILC board to engage in those consultations, to the extent that they think is appropriate, helpful or workable in the particular circumstance, rather than to create a statutory obligation.

I do not disagree with what Senator Ellison said about people with both historic and, alternatively, traditional links with the land being part of the relevant pool of people whose views may ultimately be very relevant. I acknowledge that there is a distinction between historic associations and traditional associations. I do not disagree with any of that. I disagree, and the government still fervently disagrees, with putting all this in the form of a statutory obligation. Once you do that, you create a situation where this becomes a subject, potentially, of endless legal disputation. The very breadth of the range of interests that you talked about as potentially being in competition with each other indicates the extent to which there might be an encouragement to actual litigation in situations of this kind. If people do see an historic interest at odds with someone else's traditional interest, that is the kind of context to which they are more likely than not to want to take such legal remedies as they perceive are open to them. Every time you draft these things in statutory form, you create the capacity for that kind of effort to occur and kind of inhibition on the ILC's performance of its functions.

A lot of the business of property acquisition involves swiftly taking advantage of a market opportunity. What you almost completely deny with these sorts of provisions is any capacity in the ILC to do just that. You have got to give some credence to the good faith and the capacity of people like Lois O'Donoghue sitting up there in the gallery—as she so often is, listening intently in these debates to what we are all saying. You have got to give some credence to the good faith, the goodwill and the good sense of people like this who have been living and breathing these issues for years and who will be sitting on the board in one capacity or another making these decisions. We can afford to do that. We do not need to put it in statutory terms knowing, as we do, the downside risks of it. If you do want to have some sort of touchstone or benchmark in the statute, the most that the government would be prepared to accept is language saying that the ILC may—not must take all reasonable steps—in its absolute discretion, consult those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having traditional and historic links. That is there for legal reasons in those terms in order not to create a justiciable obligation.

Presentationally, it is not very attractive. I can see Senator Harradine squirming at that. He does not like that at all. Maybe he is not even thinking about this, but he probably will not like it very much.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just written about it.

—You do not like it very much. I am not sure that I like it very much presentationally. I would prefer to leave it all out and leave it to the good sense and the discretion of the people who are likely to constitute the board. But I think that is as much as I can say. If your position is dug in on this, so be it. But it is just one of those things that will make the bill unworkable. I acknowledge that in some respects, having gone away from the language of traditional owners to this language, you have solved one problem but only at the expense of creating another. That is our position and there we stand.

—I seek leave to amend the heading of this amendment, so this will be an amendment to the amendment. The current heading reads `Permission of traditional owners'. I take Senator Gareth Evans's point that it should really be `Consultation'. But Senator Evans was also saying that, in the traditional owners sense, perhaps we should have `historic and traditional links'.
—Just consultation. You don't need to put all that, otherwise the title would be longer than the clause.
—In that case, I seek leave to amend that heading so that it reads `Consultation with traditional owners'.
—We can't have `traditional owners', because you've changed the definition.
—You could put `reasonable consultation'.
—I think `Consultation' on its own would be sufficient.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit `Permission of traditional owners'; insert `Consultation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address Senator Gareth Evans's remarks, not least of all because I did question the efficacy of administrative law which he chose to take as a comment rather than a question. Maybe he could respond to what I say this time.

PARA.TAB: I noticed with interest that at one stage Senator Evans talked about needing to move quickly to take advantage of a market niche. I would have thought that that would be the last thing the government should be seriously regarding as a priority in this area. In other words, the whole essence of Aboriginal culture, I would have thought, is not simply to rush in and make a fast commercial buck. It is to ensure that as many people as possible are comfortable with the decision made, and their forms of consultation and decision making may well be a lot slower than ours and may ultimately be a lot more enduring as a result. Therefore, I would not have thought that speed was of the essence. What is important is getting it right.

The underlying concept is to consult as widely as possible. In picking up Senator Kernot's point, consultation with those with traditional or historic links would generally be a wider group than owners. To the extent that we were wanting to ensure that both owners and others were consulted, this form of words allows us to do that. There should not be any need for conflict between those two groups. Above all it is seeking to make it clear, not just to the ILC in some sort of heavy-handed fashion but to the community at large, that we expect good faith and we expect consultation to be as widespread as possible.

One of the real concerns I have is that, for example, the ILC might think that it needs to act quickly. It might therefore think—after having spoken to an eloquent and persuasive spokesperson, representative, trade union official or whoever else it might be—that this has the flavour of having to consult with only those with traditional or historic links and that it does not need to consult with the rest of the community.

One of the lessons that would have come out of Senator Ellison's inquiries is that, just as there is a great deal of concern about ATSIC running its own race rather than taking enough time to consult with all those at the bottom of the pile—it is like the frontbench being accused of not consulting the backbench—we ought to go out of our way as much as possible to ensure that we take everyone with us. We do not want a situation where we might simply be consulting with a spokesperson who purports to represent a large number of those with traditional or historic links. We want to make it clear that we expect the ILC to take all reasonable steps to consult as widely as possible. If we do it in that fashion and the ILC acts in good faith, as undoubtedly it would, we would absolutely minimise the prospects of litigation or legal challenge.

What puzzles me is that, as I understand Senator Gareth Evans, who has alway been an enthusiastic advocate of administrative law, in relation to the concept of reasonableness he is quite comfortable with that in other contexts. The ability to bring a challenge where people are able to establish that not all reasonable steps were taken is one that ought to be there, not only as a last resort avenue to seek redress but in the first instance to put the onus on the body in question to do what we would expect it to do.

If that is the case and everyone acts in good faith, as they do 99 per cent of the time, they would not be likely to be facing massive and regular litigation. So I find it a trifle odd that, although in every other area Senator Evans is comfortable with the concept of reasonableness, which goes to the heart of administrative law because it gives ordinary citizens the opportunity to go in and simply argue whether or not they did the right thing—it is not some arcane legal notion—suddenly here he raises this spectre of massive and endless litigation. I have not heard Senator Evans respond to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you must have me respond, let me just simply say that of course it is a general administrative law principle that, whether or not there is some explicit statutory reference, administrative functions have to be performed in accordance with a standard of reasonableness. There is a general overriding rule and I have never contested the utility or the efficacy of that. What I would contest is the necessity or, in this instance, the utility of multiplying invitations to people to challenge the exercise of administrative discretions in areas where there are sufficient safeguards, we believe, in the way in which the institution itself is constructed and the way in which its obligations are framed, to make that unnecessary.
—But you may as well let us assume all bureaucrats act reasonably.

—I am not going to get into a philosophical argument, particularly with you, on this particular matter. But since you wanted me to say something, I have said it, and maybe we can move on. On your more specific point about this particular proposal and the desirability of there being some sort of consultative process before this provision takes effect, let me say with the upmost respect that I am not sure you have carefully read what this particular provision is or carefully noticed where it fits in the scheme of the legislation as a whole.

PARA.TAB: This is a provision which requires consultation before the corporation performs a land acquisition function. It is not about consultation before the vesting of land so acquired; this is only before acquisition. While there may well be a case in practice—and it is in this context that I was largely acknowledging it before—for the ILC to be as well as informed as it can be before making an actual vesting function determining who is going to be given the joint title or whatever to the land in question, while there may well be a case in that context for it informing itself as best it can, there may equally well be a case for it to move very swiftly to take advantage of a market opportunity in order to buy a particularly obviously attractive piece of land and then sort out later precisely in whom that land might most appropriately vest.

You are imposing much too difficult an obligation upon the corporation to have it embark upon this potentially very wide-ranging consultative process before the acquisition itself occurs. I have acknowledged previously that of course it is desirable for the corporation to have regard to what the kinds of interests are likely to be in that part of the country. I would envisage in the development of regional strategies it would take that into account and it would certainly be sensitive to possible conflicts between traditional owners who may well have a right under the Native Title Act itself and other people who may at best have only a possible access to land under this. Of course it will be engaging in that kind of balancing act in practice. But, again, subject to formal statutory provision and the possibility of endless amounts of disputatious litigation flowing from that, to require it to go down this particular path is not to go down a path that is going to be workable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot resist saying that I was precisely concerned about the pre-acquisition stage, because the overwhelming temptation would be to act quickly, to do a bit of hasty consultation and to grab the opportunity while it was there. Once you concede the need for some degree of consultation or some opportunity for consultation, then you are arguing about degree. The last thing you want is to have an acrimonious taste in the mouths of a substantial proportion of those who might have had an interest in the issue because you happened to rush in and say, `I've got the views of the key people in the community. Bang! We'll spend $5 million on it.'

PARA.TAB: It is a very substantial decision. You buy in haste, you repent in leisure. As you understand, the politics of that would simmer on endlessly if people felt that they were not adequately consulted. I would have thought you would err on the side of caution. It is much better not to go ahead with the acquisition at all rather than to rush in, consult a few leaders, put your money on the table and then find out that the whole thing blows up. It is not simply about getting best commercial value for money; it is about ensuring that you take the community with you. That is why I find it very difficult to understand why in other contexts you are the essence of reasonableness. You do not for a moment suggest that ADJR should be dispensed with and we should rely on the good sense and good nature of the bureaucrats. There are very many situations where reasonableness is of the essence and, particularly in a situation such as this where we are going into new territory, I would have thought that the ILC itself would want to move cautiously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the minister a simple question. I do not want to get into any of the legal argument that is going on. The minister has made a big play out of the fact that if an opportunity arises in the market, you cannot jump in quickly if you have to consult. Why does not the ordinary commerce take place that occurs when any property comes on the market? If you believe you have a reasonable chance of purchasing it, you go in and grab an option—if the vendor gives you the option—and then you can consult. By consulting with people—
—You are making a nice old mess of Senator Alston's argument.

—No, I am supporting his argument. The minister said that a person must move quickly when there is an opportunity in the market. I agree with that. I am not knocking Senator Alston's argument. His argument concerns the insertion of these consulting conditions. If you take out an option, as occurs in everyday affairs, you can then start to consult. For a start, you generally consult your bank manager to see whether you can proceed any further. You can have all the other consultations.
—You consult your co-purchasers.

—That is a good point—in my case I would need to consult my partners. The point is that, by consulting, you make other people aware that the property is on the market. It may not be very common knowledge. Of course, they might become interested as well. But if you are holding an option, you can have consultation as well as having your foot on the property. Then you can move in. So I am supporting Senator Alston's argument. I cannot see why it cannot work in this case.
—The trouble is that you must have a good legal brain as well as a good commercial brain to understand the mysteries of all this.
—Which do you have?

—I am not claiming more than a passing acquaintance with either, but enough to be able to respond to all these sorts of arguments. There is a short answer to Senator Panizza—that is, the acquisition of an option in the terms that he describes would be a land acquisition function within the meaning of the act as it is now crafted. The particular clause in front of us states that, before the corporation performs a land acquisition function, it has to consult. So on Senator Panizza's reading of it, he would have to consult before he acquired his option. Once he has got his option, that is an interest in land within the meaning of the legislation. There is no doubt about that—even his mate Senator Alston agrees with that. So it is a nice idea but it does not work.

—We are saying everybody is acting in good faith. It is being assumed that, when it becomes common knowledge that the ILC wants to make an acquisition, the land is not going to become unavailable or it is not going to be then offered at inflated prices. I do not think one can assume that about vendors. That is why I understand the difficulty of the pre-acquisition stage that is being imposed.

—I do not want to delay the proceedings but I am afraid I cannot resist. The requirement here to do the proper consultation can be as early in the piece as possible. In fact, that is one of the benefits of having it written into the legislation because it puts the ILC on notice that it will be held to account if it has not consulted. If the ILC does its job properly, as long as it is provable under any challenge by the people who may be likely to benefit from such a challenge—that is, those who claim they have not been consulted—then it should not have any problems. To have it ahead of time allows it freedom from that concern, rather than the capacity for anybody to challenge that it has been done properly if it is not stated.

PARA.TAB: The other point that has been omitted is that the ILC has two capacities. It can buy up land for its own purposes because that is written into the bill for other reasons. But this is referring to land that is being acquired for a particular group of people. That is why it is very important that the consultation with any other people who may be likely to have interests in the land be done ahead of time.

The economic constraints will be overcome if, within the regional strategy, that requirement is met early on and it is available right throughout Australia. If there is adequate consultation with people who may have interest, that may determine how we use this meagre amount of money. The ILC may well say that, because it knows there is a dispute over a particular area of land, it may well be better to choose an area of land for acquisition that has no dispute in that regard. It is a precautionary principle that if written into the legislation could assist the ILC. If it is unspoken, it may well bring it unstuck in any event.
Amendment (h) agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment (g) deals with previous amendment No. 4, as put by the coalition. As I said earlier, this was a controversial amendment. It dealt with objects and principles of the bill. It contained the term `most severely dispossessed', which really did cause some comment during the hearing of the committee. It is worth recalling the original amendment, which read:

SPEECH.PARA: (b)if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to those Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands;
The key phrase here is `most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands'. What people overlooked was the outset of this subsection, which stated:
(b)if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources . . .

It is only in that situation that you would have reference to the question of most severely dispossessed. The principle behind this is that funds are not unlimited. They are indeed limited, as was heard by the committee. When you come to a conflict of competing interests as to how you allocate your resources, you should be given some guidelines. The Indigenous Land Corporation, in the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers, should be given some principles.

PARA.TAB: The government quite correctly recognised that there would be principles which the ILC should adhere to. This is nothing unusual. In fact, it gives the ILC a charter to work to and it makes its job a whole lot easier. The coalition has changed its view of the wording of `most severely dispossessed'. Our amendment before the chamber reads:

(b)if a conflict arises as to the allocation of the resources of the Fund, priority is to be given to those who suffer most disadvantage in relation to access to land or who are unable to gain substantive title to land.

SPEECH.PARA: During the hearing of evidence, the committee heard that, whilst those individuals and organisations appearing before the committee had no problem with the principle, they did have problems with the wording. Some suggested that the ILC may not be the competent body to work this out with complete discretion; that is, if we leave it entirely up to the ILC to work out where it goes when there is a conflict of funding. The suggestion was that we refine that phrase.

PARA.TAB: Peter Yu—I quote from page 18 of the committee's report—stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the reality [is] that there are varying levels of disadvantage . . . throughout the country.

He pointed out that it would be sensible to assist `those who are suffering the most disadvantage in terms of access to land'. The phrase `access to land' is incorporated in the coalition's revamped amendment.

PARA.TAB: Mr Pearson, the executive director of the Cape York Land Council, told the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is a substantial fund available under New South Wales legislation, so we have to query whether funds ought to be made available in that state. They have a fund that, at the end of the day, is going to equal what the rest of us have together . . . In Queensland, the board may take into account the fact that some people have had some of their traditional lands gazetted as available to claim, so they do have an avenue. They would be reasonable things for the board to take into account.
