In other words, some people do have title to land by virtue of it being gazetted and some people already have a land fund available to them in New South Wales. This is what the wording says as it now stands. We take into account those who suffer most disadvantage in relation to access to land or an inability to gain substantive title to land.

PARA.TAB: It gives a marker to the Indigenous Land Corporation as to how to exercise discretion when it reaches the dilemma of a conflict arising as to the allocation of resources. We see it continually in government. When government does not have sufficient funds to go around, it has to make the very difficult decision of where money will be allocated. There is perhaps no greater dilemma when one is attending to the funding for a person which is given by virtue of legislation. I suggest that a minister comes across this daily in the exercise of his or her duties, so the ILC no doubt will as well. This seeks to give the ILC some guidance as to how to address this conflict.

Other alternatives were suggested. At page 18 of the committee's report, Helen Skiadas and Katina Law of Perth, who appeared before the committee, said that one could look at those most in need spiritually, culturally or economically, those with the least access to land and those who will be most advantaged by access to land. They went on with a raft of other criteria that could be taken into account.

We are trying to distil the main concerns that were expressed as to how one addresses this conflict of interests. I believe that the wording, which has been taken directly from the evidence given to us—in one instance, by the Kimberley Land Council—achieves this.

The government may say that this might again result in administrative action and litigation. But we have to give a body of this sort some type of guideline; it would be irresponsible of us not to. More so, it would be irresponsible of us to give it guidelines that are hazy and ambivalent and open to interpretation. What we have done in a very succinct way is give this body a coherent direction as to how to apply funds when there is this conflict.

I commend the amendment to the Senate. I do not think it will pit Aboriginals against Aboriginals. It has a good deal of support. There is a majority of support by those people who appeared before this committee for this principle. It is just a question of getting it right. This modification to the amendment is much more preferable to our former amendment. The coalition has quite rightly jettisoned the term `most severely dispossessed'. It brought into argument the fact that some people might not be dispossessed while other people might.

The evidence that we received in this committee was that all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have been dispossessed. That was the starting point, but from there on you might have degrees of disadvantage, and it was perhaps divisive to talk in terms of degrees of dispossession. That is why it was jettisoned.

These terms are not divisive. They do not excite controversy. I do not believe they in any way go to excite conflict between people. It is reasonable to say,` Let us look at those who have suffered most disadvantage in relation to access to land. If there is perhaps another land fund available, that could then be taken into account.' In some areas of this country you would have Aboriginal people who do not enjoy the benefit of having such a land fund available to them. That is what Noel Pearson said. He has also said that some people have had land gazetted to them. That is something to take into account quite properly. It relates to the ability to gain substantive title to land.

We have taken away that question of dispossession. I believe that takes the emotional aspect out of it, quite rightly. We now look in a very matter of fact way at how we allocate the limited dollar we have in difficult circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison is right in saying that the original amendment was seen as the centre of controversy and caused great divisiveness. He is correct to draw attention to the evidence given by all organisations that we are all dispossessed. I know that his motives in seeking to change that wording from `most severely dispossessed' to `disadvantaged' are that it is going to work more efficiently and fairly. But I wonder whether the `most disadvantaged' test is at least equally incapable of objective measurement, as is `most severely dispossessed'. In the land fund minority report on page 199 an example is given:

SPEECH.PARA: To demonstrate the inherent unworkability of this formula, take the example of an Aboriginal community living by some form of agreement on another person's pastoral lease. On one view, they are not very disadvantaged at all in terms of `access to land' compared with, say, an indigenous commune in a densely populated part of a city.
That is one interpretation of severely disadvantaged—
On another view, however, the group on the pastoral lease can be seen as disadvantaged in the extreme, because they are so agonisingly close to the unfettered enjoyment of their heritage.
I guess we are saying that perhaps the word `disadvantaged' is potentially as loose a word as `dispossessed' when it comes to interpretation.

PARA.TAB: I understand that in the committee hearings those who suggested words like this as possible circuit-breakers emphasised that the principle should be a discretionary one, not a statutory one, and that the board should take into account, if they are talking about land as one of the criteria, the existing and likely land holdings, for example.

We have to ask, too, an equally important question: how does your advocacy of this new category `severely disadvantaged' rest with your previous amendment 25? How does it link with the health, education and housing principle? Are you taking that into account? Are you going to read the two together and, if you do, what is the result of that link? How do you determine degrees of disadvantage, given that you already have amendment 25 in place? Any formulation which attempts to distinguish between former degrees of dispossession, this time degrees of disadvantage, levels of financial hardship or whatever on that long list that you quoted earlier is still bound to produce unnecessary conflict between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I find it very hard to see it as a substantial improvement which I could subsequently vote for.
Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year is the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War. It is being commemorated through Australia Remembers and quite rightly so. It is a fitting way to pay tribute and remember the enormous sacrifices made by Australians at home and overseas both in uniform and out of uniform.

PARA.TAB: Australia Remembers is not a celebration of war, far from it. It is a celebration of heroism, courage and sheer determination, a time to think about the terrible suffering inflicted through war and a time to give our thanks to those who served our nation and helped to protect those very things which we take for granted today. It is something which can unite us all in remembrance and reflection. As we remember the suffering and misery that war can inflict on ordinary people we should reflect beyond our own shores.

It saddens me that the dignity and respect engendered by Australia Remembers does not seem to extend to the tens of thousands of women who suffered terrible atrocities at the hands of the Japanese army during the war. I am of course referring to the so-called comfort women. Their plight has been mentioned infrequently—usually in the context of being one of the unresolved issues of the war affecting relations between Japan and its Asian neighbours. It should be mentioned, for the story of comfort women is not one that should be swept under the carpet or consigned to history's dustbin.

This week there has been a conference in Seoul in South Korea on the subject of comfort women. I understand it has been attended by delegates from Korea, Taiwan, the Philippines and Japan. There was even some hope that North Korea would allow some delegates to attend the conference in the south—that in itself is a noteworthy and hopeful sign of improving relations on the Korean peninsula. Unfortunately, in a fit of pique at the last minute the North Korean regime refused to let the delegates attend. If anything, the potential involvement of delegates from North Korea is an indication of how widespread the abuse of Asian women was by the Japanese army and how even 50 years after the war feelings in the region run so deep as to almost overcome the paranoia which prevails on the Korean peninsula.

The Imperial Army was one of the most brutal the modern world has seen, as too many Australians well know. Aside from the terrible toll exacted on allied personnel and prisoners of war and civilians throughout the south-east of Asia and the Pacific, the Japanese army was responsible for terrible and purposeful atrocities against as many as 200,000 women who were forced to become sex slaves or comfort women for Japanese troops. Women from Korea, China, the Philippines, Indonesia, Taiwan and the Netherlands were victims of this vile and degrading treatment in front-line brothels.

I notice that the book written by one of those women, who now lives in Adelaide, is available in the Parliamentary Library. I would urge honourable senators to take the time to read it. Jan Ruff O'Herne was enslaved by the Japanese army for four years and only spoke out about the horrors she had witnessed after watching a documentary about Korean comfort women a few years ago. She was just 18 years old when she was dragged away from her family by Japanese troops in Central Java to be brutally raped and beaten by hundreds of soldiers at a brothel run by the Imperial Army.

Late last year Ms Ruff O'Herne said it was time that the Japanese accepted responsibility for what they had done and drew special attention to the plight of Asian women who were brutalised by the Japanese. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: Comfort women, especially Asian comfort women, have nothing. They lost everything—they lost their families because they were ashamed to go back to their villages—they couldn't get married. They suffered so much and had to carry the burden for 50 years.
Some people might say, `Well, that's terrible, that's history, and it happened in wartime.' But we can never allow that to be an excuse for any atrocities, in any war, at any time, by any race.

PARA.TAB: The International Commission of Jurists investigated the crimes committed against the comfort women. Last year it recommended that each of the comfort women should be paid at least $US40,000 as compensation. It published a 240 page report which detailed the systematic brutality and the vast scale on which the atrocities occurred. Forcing women into army-run brothels amounted to war crimes and breaches of international law against trafficking in women and children, the ICJ said. The allies knew about it. They did nothing after the war to bring the offenders to trial or to try and get reparations for their victims. Make no mistake—the crimes committed against the comfort women were not one-off aberrations or isolated cases. They were part of a deliberate and ongoing campaign of brutality against innocent and helpless women and girls, some as young as 13.

Before the International Commission of Jurists issued its report, I had written twice to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) in April 1993 asking what action he had taken or proposed to take to pursue justice for the victims of these crimes. In reply, the minister said that the Australian government would monitor the situation closely. He did at least acknowledge the evidence to support the claims inasmuch as the Japanese government itself had confirmed the Imperial Army's role in setting up and operating the brothels where women were forced into sex slavery. So there was no doubt about the veracity of the allegations against the Japanese, but we had a `wait and see' attitude from the Australian government.

After the ICJ published its report later in the year, calling for compensation and fully exposing the nature of the crimes against the comfort women, I again asked the minister in a question on notice what action he had taken in response to the report or what action he proposed to take. The Japanese government had already announced that it would not be providing any direct compensation to comfort women. Instead, the Japanese government was setting up a $1 billion public relations slush fund to promote exchange programs and vocational training in countries where the atrocities against comfort women were committed.

It seems that, despite overwhelming evidence and the minister's professed commitment to human rights on the international stage, this government will be letting the matter rest. It has `noted' the recommendations of the ICJ, according to the minister, but that is where it ends. I believe that is totally unacceptable. In my view, it is a total dereliction of Australia's role in the international community. It seems that an apology and expressions of remorse are all that the women victims of wartime atrocities will get.

Australia should be pressing Japan to do the honourable and decent thing by offering direct compensation to former comfort women. Instead, we are sheltering behind the terms of the San Francisco Peace Treaty of 1951 on the grounds that it renounced any further claims to compensation from Japan. We are not asking for compensation for countries or governments. It is being sought for individual women, hundreds of thousands of them, who had no voice at that treaty signing but who have every right to expect their case to be heard and fairly judged, despite the passage of time.

It was only last week that Senator Gareth Evans in a speech here in Canberra urged Japan to assume a greater role on the world stage. He said that the legacy of the war years continued to weigh heavily on some of Japan's neighbours and prevented Japan from taking a greater role in regional and global affairs.

Senator Evans said that there was a real and intense closeness between our countries that has grown up over the past four decades and that ours is beyond just an economic relationship. Let us put that real and intense relationship to work by seeking a decent resolution of one of the very issues that prevents Japan from fully developing its role in the region.

Our neighbours in neighbouring countries have spoken out strongly on this. Why is Australia's voice so silent? Let us seek as a country justice and compensation for the comfort women. Only then, to use Senator Evans's own words, will Japan's Asian critics be comprehensively disarmed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I call on the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to urgently initiate an independent inquiry into the Defence Science and Technology Organisation in Adelaide because of absolutely unacceptable activities going on there.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the defence department's Inspector-General has been told of a disappearance of some $76,000 worth of gold supplies from the South Australian Defence Science and Technology Organisation which was to be used for gold plating electronic circuitry components.

Twelve employees with the scientific and engineering services department in Adelaide have been identified as having used these gold supplies over many years to gold plate personal items including a tombstone, baby booties, bathroom fittings, watches, a chandelier and a host of other items. There are also concerns that stringent quality assurance documentation used to itemise the DSTO's highly sophisticated circuit boards may have been fraudulently manipulated to account for the disappearance of the gold supplies.

This is a disgraceful scandal involving not only taxpayers' money but also matters of national security. The scandal goes to the very heart of ministerial accountability and responsibility in this country. Here we have DSTO employees engaged in corrupt activity, stealing from the public purse and using the gold plating supplies for their own selfish purposes.

The gold plating examples I have mentioned are but a few of the personal abuses we know about. The mind boggles at how many more items may have been given the royal gold plating treatment, eventually finding their way into the homes of the relatives and friends of these 12 employees. It seems that this practice has been going on for some time and I suspect that the $76,000 identified as having being stolen is just the tip of the iceberg.

This matter has very serious implications not only because of the theft itself but also because of the method used to hide these scandalous practices. Apart from the fact that we know that at the very least some $76,000 worth of gold and radium plating supplies have gone missing and apart from the fact that we know that at the very least one batch of defective gold plating stocks has never been returned to the suppliers, I remind the minister—I welcome him to the chamber to listen to this matter—that the scientific and engineering services department within the DSTO in Adelaide is supposed to be controlled by stringent accounting guidelines because of the sensitive application of these circuitry components.

For example, circuit boards used in weapons guidance systems require a very detailed and careful itemising of all components manufactured and used. This is done, I am told, to ensure that defective components can be quickly identified in the event of any subsequent system failure. The gold plating supplies were supposed to be carefully recorded and strictly supervised, but we now know that for many years these gold stocks literally walked out of DSTO's doors.

This is the same defence department which is supposed to be controlled by strict security measures. To cover up the theft, it now appears that those who were involved corrupted the batch files and in some cases stock records simply vanished. This is a scandal which has serious implications for our national security.

I am reliably informed that should there be failure in any part of these gold plated circuit boards or components developed by the DSTO and used in our defence systems, we may never know if the gold plating techniques were the cause of the system failure because of these corrupted files.

We are talking about a department within the Australian Defence Force which is entrusted with highly secretive and sensitive technology and information. The DSTO in Adelaide has responsibility for conducting research and development in command and control, information technology, communications, cryptographic research including signals intelligence, and tactical electronic warfare. It is disturbing to learn that employees involved with this department have been involved in corrupt activity. The integrity of the DSTO and its security procedures have been called into question.

Again I ask of the minister, given that he is here in the chamber, that a full and independent inquiry be established to examine this scandal. The Inspector-General, who has the responsibility for conducting an investigation, was made aware of this matter before Christmas. The Australian Federal Police, I am told, have been called in to investigate this scandal. But what do we find out about DSTO's headquarters at Salisbury in South Australia? All of these 12 employees still have their jobs. The only employees who have since been reprimanded or forced out of their jobs would appear to be those who refused to take part in this gold plating scandal or who blew the whistle. The buck must stop with this minister. He must not try to sweep this matter under the carpet but, as I have said, he must initiate a full and independent inquiry into this scandal.

I cannot for the life of me understand how this gold theft scandal managed to escape the detection of DSTO's internal security procedures. It is quite clear that this corrupt behaviour has existed for some time, and that the matters that I have raised today may only be scratching the surface.

As I said, the records that have been corrupted to cover up this scandal are perhaps a more serious matter than the actual theft of the gold. One can only imagine what impact this corruption of files could have on our weapons guidance systems, for example; and so there is a scandal here with major national implications.

I repeat that it is important that this be fully and openly investigated, and particularly that the 12 employees who have alleged to be involved in this scandal be brought to book; but, more importantly, it is important that measures be put in place such that this sort of behaviour can never be repeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to January's current account deficit of $2.3 billion—the third consecutive month of $2 billion plus figures in our trade imbalance. I ask: are you aware that this trend of huge balance of payments blow-outs is now higher than the run of deficits which prompted Mr Keating in 1986 to warn that Australia was on its way to becoming a banana republic? Are you also aware that Australia's current account deficit, forecast at 5.75 per cent of GDP for this year, is the second highest in the OECD after Mexico—only Mexico is higher than us? Will you now tell the Senate what you are going to do about this chronic balance of payments crisis?

—The truth of the matter is that the current account deficit on this occasion is clearly within the range of market expectations. It did fall marginally in January due to a strong increase in non-rural exports and a fall in imports. The significant deterioration in the current account deficit was to be expected, obviously, given the enormously strong growth in the Australian economy over the last 12 months and the forecast of further strong growth. You had a situation with GDP increasing by 6.4 per cent as compared with the 4 1/4 per cent predicted. Investment has grown by 24 per cent as compared with the 14 1/2 per cent that was predicted and which you lot said could never be achieved. You have had a massive increase in capital imports as a result of this growth cycle as compared with earlier periods and all of that is of course going to increase our productive capacity.

PARA.TAB: We are conscious of the need for a significant tightening of fiscal policy in the May budget to boost national savings to reduce Australia's call on overseas capital. There is a very obvious and significant difference between the economic situation now and that which prevailed in the 1985-86 growth period. You had a situation then where growth was running at about 2.2 per cent as compared with over, as we know, 6.43 per cent on this occasion. You had inflation in the latter 1980s in the last growth surge period running at around 8.4 per cent; it is now sitting on around two per cent, forecast to go no higher than 3 1/2 per cent over the course of this particular cycle. You had mortgage rates running then at about 15 1/2 per cent as compared with 10 1/2 per cent now and other interest rates in a comparable position.

So the truth of the matter is the whole economy is in an infinitely stronger and more balanced shape now than it has been in the past when these sorts of figures have been accumulated. We are conscious of the necessity to deal with it in the way that we will be in this forthcoming budget. The challenge is for those opposite to come up with a similarly coherent strategy to deal with this particular situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's always our fault.
—You cannot have it both ways. You cannot just lie back and—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. On the issue of relevance, the question is: what are you going to do about it, Senator Evans? You're in government. What are you going to do about the chronic balance of payments crisis?
—Order! There is no point of order. The answer is perfectly relevant.

—I have said exactly what we are doing about it. We have had an interest rate policy which has been geared towards putting some brakes on the economy, slowing it down, with obviously significant impact and effect and hopefully not requiring any further adjustment of that kind for the foreseeable future, and we have a fiscal policy which is very much in the process of being put in place at the moment in the context of the May budget which will be designed and aimed, as I said, at boosting national saving and reducing Australia's call on overseas capital.

PARA.TAB: It is fair and reasonable to ask: what are the alternatives that are being proposed to us? We have a situation where the opposition is not prepared to commit itself to any kind of tax increases. It wipes them out completely, saying that that is totally irresponsible. It has been very critical of any suggestion of outlay reductions of the kind that we are obviously wrestling with in the context of this budget, as in previous budgets. It has wanted to put on the record commitments of a vague kind to something that we estimate is about $18 billion worth of outlay increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The line has to be drawn somewhere. The question was not about the opposition. The question was about government—
—You can't escape the debate, though.
—We will have that debate, but this is supposed to be question time. This is when we ask the government what is it doing—
—Order! Get to your point of order.

—What is the government doing in response to month after month of disastrous figures, other than to say that it is simply within market expectations? What are you going to do about it? When are you going to start governing? That is the question.
—Senator Evans, I would ask you to get to the point of the answer.

—The point is that we are not going to follow the kind of prescription that we are getting from the opposition—a prescription which says no tax increases, no outlay reductions and do nothing on the monetary policy and interest rate side. To follow any such prescription, coming from the opposition or anyone else, would be the height of absolute irresponsibility.
—You just said we didn't have any prescription.
—Your prescription is a do-nothing prescription, except lie back and enjoy whatever transient political popularity you think will come from taking those sorts of irresponsible positions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Yesterday, you provided a general overview of your trade policy discussion paper. There has been some speculation that, in the context of the recent proliferation of regional free trade agreements, Australia may have made a significant change in its trade policy in favour of a preferential arrangement for APEC. Will you elaborate on the government's thinking in respect of a most favoured nation approach or a preferential approach for APEC countries?
—What an extraordinary notion. Another bloc, eh? A bloc within a bloc.

—The great pity is that obviously Senator Hill has been listening to Mr Downer instead of Mr Fischer and he has got his line wrong. Anyway, let me try to deal with this issue seriously instead of getting down to the opposition's level on it.
—It is your cabinet; your decision.

—You do not actually know what the decision is. Yesterday, I took the opportunity to explain in general terms the purpose of the discussion paper Winning markets: the next step, which I released for comment. There has been some speculation both about what that paper says and about the cabinet decision on the issue of MFN and preferential trading arrangements. I do not intend to go to any speculation about the cabinet's decision but I am happy to talk about the discussion paper which has been distributed.

PARA.TAB: The central message of the discussion paper is that Australia's pre-eminent trade policy objective is market access for Australian traders and investors. The issue is not MFN or preferential arrangements. The key issue is: how do we win market access for Australian business, Australian trade opportunities, Australian job opportunities and Australian investment opportunities? The paper underlines the fact that Australia has had a longstanding commitment to the multilateral trading system based on the MFN principle, and we are not about to make a sudden U-turn in respect of this policy. This applies to our approach to APEC also.

What we have to emphasise is that APEC is a consensus based organisation. The fact that Australia's preference is for MFN does not mean that that will automatically happen. We are saying that, if the body of opinion in APEC is in support of a preferential approach, we will consider that. We will not necessarily stand in its way, particularly if that will deliver quicker and more comprehensive trade and investment opportunities. The public policy is not about some sort of esoteric, theoretical proposal; it is about getting the best possible result in the real world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you remember what you used to say about NAFTA?

—It is true, as Senator Hill conveniently interjected, that a lot of countries are entering into preferential agreements, including NAFTA and AFTA. In fact, three-quarters of the countries in APEC—including Australia—belong to some sort of free trade agreement at the moment.

PARA.TAB: We have to realise that Australia historically, despite its commitment to MFN which we retain, has been a party to some successful preferential arrangements—most obviously CER, but also in the South Pacific with SPARTECA and with Canada. We have begun a dialogue with AFTA on trade linkages, which the opposition has supported. If the opposition wants to say we should not do this, what it has to answer is: if at the end of the day the only way to achieve improved export access results for Australia is through a route with some preferential elements, would you close the door on these options? If our car industry can only achieve major improvement in access to the markets of Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia through a route with some preferential elements, are you advocating that we should go to those employees in the car factories and say, `I'm sorry, you can't have that opportunity because there is an esoteric principle that we hold to; you can't have those jobs because you don't agree with that'?

We are not neutral in the MFN preferential debate. Our preference is for an MFN approach. But it is too early in the discussions on implementing APEC liberalisation to lock ourselves into an entrenched position. There is a long way to go, a lot of discussion to be had and a lot of external factors—like whether there is going to be a move to a new global round of trade negotiations—to be dealt with yet.

The most important thing—without going into any cabinet discussions—is: some of the most interesting options being considered to implement the Bogor declaration fit very comfortably with an MFN approach. We may, in the end, not have to make this sort of crunch decision, and we are not going to rush into it against Australia's interests. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that, even after months of vacillation and chronic indecision, last night's crisis cabinet meeting was yet again unable to resolve vital outstanding issues, such as the forest coupe assessments, greenhouse gas emissions, land clearing and tree planting programs, and the cross-media review? Is it not a fact that Mr Keating called last night's extraordinary meeting not only in a desperate but unsuccessful attempt to achieve some progress on these issues, but also in a very unhappy attempt to revive the fast fading hopes of his ministerial colleagues and in order to try to build some bridges between the isolation of the prime ministerial office and all those others who are being kept in the dark? Why don't you come clean and admit that last night's meeting was symptomatic of a government in disarray; when is your part-time Prime Minister going to come back to work; and when can Australians expect some real action on these important issues? (Time expired)

—There is a certain sort of wistful quality about Senator Alston's rantings on this occasion—wouldn't he love to be sitting in a cabinet room somewhere, anywhere, having some opportunity to say and do something about the sorts of issues that he is referring to? He has had a long wait so far and, my God, he is going to have a long wait yet for years to come, and I doubt whether he will ever see daylight so far as that particular status is concerned. You are a very unhappy little boy at the moment because you just do not see yourself ever being in a position to exercise any influence about anything.
—Order! Senator Evans, get on with your answer, please.
—What is the matter?
—Please get on with the answer.
—It is one of the most comprehensively dopey question that I have ever been subjected to in this place, and if I cannot answer it by that kind of derision, then I am not entitled to be here at all.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Apart from the obvious disrespect of Senator Evans waving his hand at you, let alone me, the question was all about a series of very important issues. Are we not entitled to be told whether or not the cabinet even tried to grapple with them? If Senator Collins was happy to tell us what happened in cabinet the other day, why shouldn't Senator Evans be asked to respond to a serious question? I understand his extreme discomfort. If it is all getting a bit hard, there is an obvious solution. But in the meantime, the question asked about a number of serious policy issues, and you ought to direct him to answer those.
—I think it is strange that you are raising issues of disrespect to the chair, but I would ask Senator Evans to answer the question directly.

—The short answer is: what happens in cabinet is absolutely none of Senator Alston's business—is not now and never will be. The second answer is that the particular subjects he refers to are all ones in respect of which a timetable has been announced, is in process and has not slipped.

PARA.TAB: So far as woodchips are concerned, we announced some time ago that we would be making a preliminary decision about the urgent release of some coupes, and that the remaining decision would be made within eight weeks so far as all the remainder were concerned, with some possibility of acceleration if circumstances made that possible; if it did not, we would be targeting for eight weeks.

So far as the greenhouse exercise is concerned, we indicated that we would be wanting to be in a position to decide and announce a policy to take to the Berlin conference in mid-March. There has been some preliminary consideration of some of the extremely difficult policy issues that are involved in these matters. We make no apology and offer no defence whatsoever—because no defence is needed—for sensible, rational and considered government process.

We are a government that has been systematically addressing a whole series of complex issues not only with an eye to the 1950s—as your present leader has, without any capacity to think beyond the frame of intellectual reference he developed in his early childhood and adolescence—but also we have mapped some larger themes as to the future. We have been performing and delivering, and we have also been simultaneously solving a multitude of problems that are beyond your resources to even think about creative solutions to. This is a government at work, working effectively, and we will continue to do that in the interests of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Given the current publicity about the BHP steelworks in Newcastle, can the minister tell the Senate what assessment the government has made about the future of the Australian steel industry?

—I thank Senator Cooney for his question. He has always been interested in the fortunes of Australian workers in blue collar occupations. I, too, saw the article in Monday's Australian raising the issue of the long-term fate of the BHP steelworks at Newcastle in New South Wales. I understand that the issue is not that BHP is considering in any way, shape or form exiting from the rod and bar product market; rather, when it is talking about investment decisions for the steelworks, it is talking about new investment in new technology at Newcastle to ensure a long-term presence for itself in the Australian domestic and international markets. I think that is good news for BHP, and it overall fits into the very positive picture that we have seen emerge for the Australian steel industry.

PARA.TAB: Calendar year 1994 was a record year for the Australian steel industry. It was five full years after the end of our steel plan and 10 years—a full decade—since BHP itself was thinking of quitting steel making in Australia. The Australian production of crude steel was at a record 8.4 million tonnes, nine per cent higher than the previous year and 48 per cent higher than the 1983 figure. Furthermore, this result was achieved with a more productive and efficient environment. For example, the yield of finished product from crude steel has increased from around 77 per cent in the 1970s to now around 90 per cent. BHP's steel profit for the six months to November 1994 was a record $344 million, up 19 per cent on the same period of the previous year. Steel exports last year was a record 3.2 million tonnes, with some 75 per cent of that going to the Asian region.

It is also a good record of Australian technology. In 1994, Australia was the lowest cost producer of the 11 countries considered in the Paine and Webber annual survey. BHP's steel productivity has more than trebled since 1982, and the approach of total quality management is the order of the day at its steelworks. BHP's commitment to steel making in Australia is stronger than ever. For example, it is building a new $400 million blast furnace at Port Kembla and a $300 million expansion of the tin mill is committed. An expansion is under way at Whyalla and the Sydney mini-mill has environmental approval for expanded operations. BHP will unveil this complete strategy for Newcastle by July of this year.

One of the other exciting features of the entire steel industry story is that Australia is becoming increasingly regarded as a source of new technologies. CRA's $200 million high smelt project and BHP's Project M joint venture are being keenly watched by world steel makers. The prognosis for the steel industry in this part of the world is extremely good. The huge demand in China is expected to continue. The ability of Australia as a primary producer of minerals and our knowledge and capability with technology in steel making puts Australia in a position to take advantage of further downstream processing opportunities and expanding and growing our steel industry much further than it has to date. I repeat that last year was a record year for the industry. There is no doubt that this government's steel plan laid the foundations for that achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Hungary led by the Speaker of its parliament, Mr Zoltan Gal. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both enjoyable and informative. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the cabinet decision to consider a preferential free trade agreement within APEC hoping to accelerate free trade in the region but clearly while still continuing unilateral cuts to our support for Australian industry, including our car industry. Figures available through Ernst and Young's Asia-Pacific database and UNCTAD's directory of import regimes report tariff rates on cars of 200 per cent in Thailand, 100 per cent in Indonesia, 50 per cent in Malaysia, 60 per cent in China and 45 per cent in Singapore. I ask the minister: firstly, are these figures correct and, if not, what are the correct figures? Secondly, have these countries made commitments to reduce these tariffs and, if so, by how much and when? Thirdly, will the minister demand better access for Australian car exports to these countries as a quid pro quo for our own continuing unilateral tariff reductions? (Time expired)

—I thank Senator Spindler for his question. The figures are not entirely accurate. It is a situation more complex than that. I will provide Senator Spindler with a full picture of the situation as well as with regard to both cars and parts—in fact, for Australia the figure for car parts is more important. There is a very high level of protection against Australian cars in at least some of those countries and to a lesser extent against Australian automobile components. That is an important issue and an issue of continuing interest to both the industry minister and me.

PARA.TAB: Austrade and the Department of Industry, Science and Technology have been jointly investigating market access into Asia for the Australian auto industry. We are trying to focus on ways in which we can be as effective as possible in helping our industry to get that access, which it is increasingly winning because the level of exports of automobiles and automobile parts from Australia is going up very strongly.

With regard to market access Senator Spindler asked whether these countries made commitments to reduce protection. Of course they have. Under APEC they have all made commitments to free trade by 2020. Three of those countries to which Senator Spindler refers—Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia—made significant unilateral tariff reductions, not all affecting cars. In some countries they affected cars, but they mainly affected many products of importance to Australia during the last 12 months. We appreciate that, and we expect that process to continue.

I do not claim that that has been as a result of brilliant representations by Australia but because of international market pressures for competitiveness and for investment which require people to reduce their protection. I expect that to continue. We will continue in cooperation with the Department of Industry, Science and Technology to press for better access for Australian car exports and for automobile component exports, both of which are growing very strongly. But we can do better and would do better if the level of protection in these countries were not so high. That will continue to be a priority for us in APEC, as it will continue to be a priority for us in the multilateral round which we will seek to have resume as soon as possible, and in our bilateral relations with those countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer but, to my knowledge, APEC is not yet in place, it is not a binding agreement, therefore any undertakings that these countries make under APEC are so much hot air at this stage. I am really asking for a quid pro quo. The minister has not answered that question. Is he prepared to say to those countries that until they come to the party and reduce their barriers to our cars and car parts Australia will leave its current level of protection at 27.5 per cent?

—I would not brush aside so lightly commitments given by the leaders of 18 countries. Those people do not give their word lightly and do not have a track record of going back on the word they have given. So I would not brush that aside so lightly just because it is inconvenient to your argument.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of the so-called quid pro quo, we will continue to press for tariff reductions in the area. What we do with regard to our tariffs and other matters beyond the commitments we have already given in the existing plans will be a matter which cabinet will give consideration to at the appropriate time. It will be part of our discussions both about our domestic economic policy settings and about our trade settings with regard to APEC and multilateral negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is the minister aware of an incident that occurred on board the Griffin Venture—a floating production, storage and off-loading facility operated by BHP Petroleum off the Western Australian coast between Barrow Island and North West Cape in late May 1994 which could have caused the vessel to explode, endangering the lives of the 37 crew on board and potentially causing a major environmental disaster? If so, what action is the government taking to investigate this incident to ensure that the procedures that led to this potential disaster are not repeated on this vessel or any similar facility operating off the Australian coastline?

—The Minister for Transport is aware of this incident and informed me recently that he had quite a recent letter detailing these allegations. At the time of the alleged incident, the Griffin Venture was actually in production mode and it was therefore subject to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act which is administered off the waters of Western Australia by the Western Australian Department of Minerals and Energy on behalf of the Commonwealth. Because the administration of this particular piece of legislation actually falls within my portfolio, I will be seeking an urgent report on this matter, which has only recently been reported to me, with a view to addressing any corrective measures that need to be taken to avoid similar incidents occurring in the future.

PARA.TAB: Although the Griffin Venture was not actually subject to the Navigation Act at the time of the alleged incident, because it was in production mode, the Minister for Transport is also concerned about the implications for ship safety and the possibility of inappropriate procedures being followed on this vessel. He has therefore requested the Australian Maritime Safety Authority to make its own separate investigations of this incident. When both of these investigations are completed, I will provide Senator Margetts and, indeed, the Senate with the answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. Has there been any time set for a possible resolution of the investigation?

—No particular time, but I can assure Senator Margetts that, because of the fact that this was drawn to our attention only recently and the allegations indicated that it was a potentially serious incident, both the Minister for Transport and I will ensure that these inquiries are made expeditiously—in my own case, through the department and, in the minister's case, through the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. When the results of those investigations are in, I will advise the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. On 31 January 1995, in answer to a dorothy dixer, the minister told the Senate that the cost of implementing the coalition's reafforestation plan would be between $5 billion and $15 billion. The minister said, `So the government in pure fiscal terms will not be adopting that either.' In the cabinet submission which the minister leaked to the Australian yesterday, the minister is reported as being likely to ask cabinet to approve funding to implement what is, in effect, Mr McLachlan's plan. Minister, in view of your previous rejection of the reafforestation plan on cost grounds, is your latest announcement simply another pitch at getting a headline to appease the green vote when really you have no intention whatsoever of putting into effect the plan for reafforestation?

—I appreciate that additional gloss that Senator Macdonald has put on my reputation. I have never been famous for appeasing the green vote, Senator Macdonald. So I will grab that commendation with both hands. I am amazed that a coalition member would have the hide to stand up and ask this question. I will tell you who were the biggest public critics of this so-called coalition policy within 24 hours of its being released. John Anderson attacked it and Tim Fischer attacked it.

—That is right. I had the press statement which Tim Fischer put out, which he called very grandly after the town that he was standing in, the something or other declaration. This was Martin Luther Fischer nailing to the wall of the cathedral his objections to your policies. I might add that Mr McLachlan backed down immediately—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question concerned inconsistencies between what the minister said in this place and what he said in the cabinet document that he leaked. He is being asked which is the correct explanation. That is the question that he was asked, Mr President, and on the question of relevancy that is the question he has to answer.
—On the point of order: how am I supposed to reply to a question about coalition policy without talking about coalition policy?
—On the point of order: that clearly was not the question. The question was: is Senator Collins's leaking of this cabinet submission—
—Leaking again.

—Yes. Is his leaking again of this cabinet submission, and in view of what he said previously, an indication that he has no plans for reafforestation at all? There was no question at all about the coalition's policy.

—Senator Macdonald made reference to Mr McLachlan's policy, making an accusation that Senator Collins was going to steal that policy. Therefore, the opposition has invited evaluation of whether that is a worthy project to steal and whether it is really a coalition policy or just a Liberal policy. An open invitation by the shadow minister was issued. He did not mention that in his own point of order. He has redefined his question.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, you did invite that response, I must say. I must also say that provocative questions really beget provocative answers.

—Can I assure Senator Macdonald that there is no danger of me stealing this policy. You could not give it away, Senator Macdonald. In fact, the National Farmers Federation and most of the peak primary industry bodies rejected it in 24 hours, along with your shadow minister for primary production and the Leader of the National Party who, as I said, made a statement which he called the declaration.

PARA.TAB: Within 24 hours Mr McLachlan had changed the policy—and Senator Kemp will be interested to hear that. He started off by saying that the coalition would contemplate the use of the external affairs powers of the constitution to force the divestment of land by primary producers at the rate of—this is your policy that you are asking us whether we are going to steal; you have no hope of us stealing this—660,000 hectares each and every year over the next 15 years for reafforestation and that they were going to donate the land; provide their labour free of charge; plant, fence and fireproof the forest; and all the rest of it. They would do this with their own free labour, having voluntarily taken their own land out of production. This is your policy. The exchange would be—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the Nats!
—The National Party thought it was fantastic, didn't you? In exchange, the primary producers would get some tax breaks.

—How long do we have to go before the minister answers the question? He has costed our policy, but he is now taking it. The question was: how can he take the policy when he rubbished the costings of it previously? He must answer that question and not simply waffle on about a tax on what has proved to be, by all accounts, a very good environmental policy.
—There is clearly no point of order, and you know it.

—Mr President, I assure the Senate that this was not a dorothy dixer; this was a genuine question from Senator Macdonald. There is a scheme in New South Wales and South Australia which I commend. That scheme will work. As I said in the article correctly, it will cost public money. Why did I say that it was going to cost public money?
—Why did you rubbish the costings?

—I will tell you; listen. Mr McLachlan said—it is on page 4 of the coalition policy, which Senator Macdonald has clearly not read—that his proposals would be `both simple and inexpensive'. What a joke! As I pointed out, if one is going to reafforest—
—That is quite right.
—That is correct, is it?
—That is correct.

—Ha! If you are going to reafforest 660,000 hectares of agricultural land a year, direct seeding will cost $5 billion and planting it with seedlings will cost $15 billion. We know that from Greening Australia. We are actually planting one billion trees.

PARA.TAB: I commend the policies of the government in New South Wales in terms of plantations. They are excellent. There are similar plans in Western Australia. I have publicly commended them. They are so far away from what the coalition is proposing that it is not funny. In New South Wales, the New South Wales forestry commission plants the plantation and does all the work as a joint venture with the farmer. That provides a real incentive. Mr McLachlan's policy is a joke. It has already been attacked by two prominent critics other than me—John Anderson and Tim Fischer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Netherlands led by the President of the 1st Chamber of the States-General, Mr Tjeenk Willink. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be interesting and informative. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the president to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that my question will not be as good as Senator Ian Macdonald's, but it is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The resignation of the Director of the Australian Institute of Sport, Mr Robert de Castella, has been reported in the media. Is this a sign that the influence of the AIS is waning? Should supporters of sport in this country be concerned about the future of the AIS?
—I thank Senator Neal for her question, which I believe is a better one than the one Senator Macdonald asked.
—Great question!
—Why are you so red?
—Order! Speak through the chair, please.
—In fact, you are not red; you are purple. You are not embarrassed, are you?
—Order! Get on with your answer, Senator Faulkner.

—I thank Senator Neal for her very sensible question, which is unlike Senator Macdonald's question. It is with regret that the government has received the resignation of Robert de Castella from his position of Director of the Australian Institute of Sport. Robert de Castella has brought an invaluable perspective to that job and made an outstanding contribution to Australian sport as an athlete and an administrator.

PARA.TAB: During his time leading the Australian Institute of Sport there has been considerable expansion of institute sports. The AIS programs have been integrated into the broader national sports system. One of his many achievements has been the development of support services for athletes, ensuring their all-round development as individuals as well as elite athletes and role models. The commitment of Rob de Castella and the AIS to the personal development of athletes has meant that, when the crowds stop cheering, these athletes can move on to new careers and have very productive and satisfying lives.

As well as the extensive grassroots work that Rob has undertaken, his time at the AIS has helped raise the profile of the AIS, maintaining its integrity and its leadership role in elite Australian sport. He has played a major role in securing promotional funding for the institute and the programs of the Australian Sports Commission. We should all thank Rob de Castella for his great contribution to the institute and also to its athletes, its coaches, its administrators and to Australian sport in general.

I think I can say very strongly that Rob de Castella's resignation is not a sign that the AIS in any sense is on the wane. On the contrary; Rob de Castella has confirmed that he will be maintaining close links with the AIS. I am personally very keen to explore ways in which his exceptional skills and experience can continue to be available to Australian sport. Action is already under way to find a new director. The vacancy has been advertised widely and an executive search consultant has been contracted to identify a suitable field of candidates.

In keeping with its role as leader in Australian sport, the Australian Sports Commission is constantly monitoring its position both nationally and internationally. Internal review of the AIS is being undertaken with the assistance of external consultants which will firmly focus on the continuing role and functions of the institute in order to maintain its national leadership in this field—and make no mistake; it is a very strong view of the federal government that there is a crucial national role for the Institute of Sport in the development of elite athletes in this country. The government has an absolute commitment to maintain and strengthen the position of the AIS as one of the world's great sports training centres, a position that will become more important in the lead-up to the year 2000 Olympics. I hope all senators will join me in congratulating Rob de Castella for a job well done on behalf of Australian sport.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Has an agreement been reached between the CSIRO and the International Wool Secretariat regarding ownership of the properties which were proposed for sale during the recent Senate inquiry into rural research funding? If not, has this affected the normal payment of allocated research grants from the IWS to the CSIRO during the current financial year?

—I do not have before me any information on that subject from the CSIRO. I will inquire of the CSIRO and obtain the information and supply it to Senator Ferguson and the rest of the Senate. I take this opportunity to remind the Senate that the CSIRO acts under a one-line appropriation from the government with an independent board within an approved corporate strategy and for all intents and purposes beyond that is a self-running statutory authority. As a consequence, while it provides me with information about its internal dealings and goings on from an informational point of view, I do not at this stage have information before me on the question the honourable senator has precisely asked but I will obtain it and reply to him. Perhaps if he has a supplementary he might ask me so I can incorporate both issues in the same inquiry.

—Having received the invitation from Senator Cook I could hardly not respond. While you are finding that out, minister, could you find out whether or not it is a fact that the International Wool Secretariat has been withholding up to $15 million of wool research grants to CSIRO's agricultural research divisions since 1 July last year? If it is a fact that it has withheld those grants, has this late payment of funds caused the CSIRO to be involved in any unusual accounting practices in order to keep mutually agreed research projects continuing?

—I now thank you for revealing the full intent of what you embarked upon in your voyage of discovery in your first question, Senator. Thank you for putting it all on the table for us. As I said, I do not have any information before me about this matter but I will inquire. Might I say that the CSIRO is an audited body that does not engage in unusual accounting practices. Unless you have some evidence to the contrary, I think that is a slur on its otherwise enviable reputation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Did the Therapeutic Goods Administration take action recently to stop a drug company in Queensland making untested claims about a treatment for menopause? What action is the government taking to stop drug companies from making such false claims?

—When it comes to drugs and other therapeutic treatments the government is of the view that it is not sufficient to let the buyer beware. Australia has a very comprehensive system of drug registration and it is aimed at protecting consumers, stopping drug companies from making false claims and ensuring the speedy delivery of new, fully evaluated drugs. The process involves either listing or registering drugs depending on their type and what they are claimed to do. When making applications for listing or registration the companies are very well aware of the consequences of the listing or registration of drugs, in particular that they cannot promote them for other than what they are listed or registered for.

PARA.TAB: However, in the last few weeks a company in Queensland, SciNat Australia Pty Ltd, has flouted these laws in the promotion of a treatment that it brought out from Germany called Remifemin. The drug was listed on the Australian register of therapeutic goods last December for the relief of menstrual pain and pre-menstrual symptoms only. However, the company started to promote the drug, making claims which it must have known it was not authorised to make and which were totally untested in Australia, that this drug provided, in the company's words, `menopausal relief'.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration contacted the company immediately the promotional material was brought to its attention and informed its managing director that by promoting the product for this purpose the company as sponsor of the drug was liable to prosecution under the Therapeutic Goods Act with penalties up to $30,000. It was also advised that it was liable for prosecution for promoting a product with prohibited representation—in other words, making claims about the drug that were untested in this country. The TGA advised the company to immediately cease all further promotion of the product and I can say that the company agreed to that. It has agreed to run newspaper ads retracting its statements and requesting the removal of all offending material.

This is particularly important because the government is committed to ensuring consumers get information on therapeutic goods that is, in fact, verified. In this case, the TGA acted swiftly to stop the company promoting this drug in this way and provided an immediate response to the unlawful activity. If the company believes its product could be useful in relation to menopause symptoms it does have the option of submitting an application for registration or listing of the drug for this purpose and then providing the information to allow it to be tested and the scientific evaluation to be done in the usual way. That company knows it can do that and it is perfectly open to follow that course.

I think it is important for people to know the facts about this medication and to warn consumers—and I am certainly happy to take this opportunity to warn consumers—about being taken in by companies that make claims that have not been tested in this country. All senators will recall the claims made about a miraculous thigh cream just a very short while ago. If consumers have any doubts or concerns about these claims or any other product claims they can certainly confirm those with the Therapeutic Goods Administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I am sure the minister is aware of the importance of diagnostic imaging for the treatment of children's diseases of the lower brain and spine and also how these ailments can be diagnosed most effectively using magnetic resonance imaging. Currently public hospital facilities provide MRI diagnosis in the capital cities and a few regional centres like Townsville. However, the Health Insurance Commission will not pay a Medicare rebate where private MRI facilities are used even if there is no public MRI facility in the patient's home town. Does the government have any plans to change this or will children and young adults in Cairns, Darwin and Rockhampton continue to be discriminated against simply because of where they live?

—The government has a program of introducing very expensive high technology in the health area through both the public sector and some private arrangements. There is an agreement and an understanding that because of the expense of this highly expensive medical equipment, including MRIs, there should not be an oversupply of these procedures around the country. An agreement has been reached with specialists about these things.
—That's all right for you, you live in Adelaide.

—Senators, and particularly Senator O'Chee, I reiterate that there is a program that allows for the introduction of very expensive high technology equipment in a planned way and which provides maximum access as a matter of equity to patients who need these tests.
—What about up in Cairns and Darwin? You should be standing up for this mob.

—Senator, if there is information that I can find for you about the lack of access for patients in northern Queensland, I will certainly seek it. I do not have any particular information about that matter, but it is not accurate to represent the case as you have. Some people are able to get medical benefits assistance for privately provided testing of this sort, provided it is in an already approved private provision place. So we need to get those facts clear. As to what is the arrangement for northern Queensland, I will seek some information and get back to you.

—Mr President, my supplementary question is this: does the minister deny the fact that there is an MRI facility in a private hospital in Cairns, yet patients in Cairns are expected to undergo a painful five-hour trip to Townsville to get MRI and then a five-hour trip back, and if you live further away than Cairns, it is even more difficult? Does the minister deny that that is a result of the government's current policy? It is not a matter of provision of services; it is the fact that the government will not accept that that facility is available in a private hospital.

—Senator O'Chee did not listen. This government has a policy for the introduction of access to benefits in an agreed and planned way. This is not the only private facility in Australia that does not enjoy access to those benefits, so do not come the raw prawn on this one! Those arrangements are agreed between the profession, state governments and the high technology committee. If there is further information I can find for you, I will. This is not the first time the private system has introduced high-tech equipment and then tried to force the provision of medical benefits. That is the case in other situations. I will see if there is any information about this case. You are misrepresenting the facts of the case, Senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I ask: will the eligibility criteria for sole parent pension be changed to preclude those people involved in short-term domestic disputes? Is the minister aware of concerns that these changes may adversely affect people, primarily women, who are leaving or attempting to leave violent domestic situations? Given the fact that many women remain in violent relationships because they are concerned that they would have no financial support if they left, won't these proposed changes put further doubt in these women's minds? How will the Department of Social Security accurately determine what is a short-term domestic dispute and what is not?

—I thank Senator Woodley for his question which refers to a proposed amendment in the Social Security (Non-Budget) Measures Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. The purpose of the amendment is to clarify in the Social Security Act the principle that a temporary separation—for example, where people are separated from their partners due to holidays, work or study commitments—does not qualify people for the sole parent pension.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Social Security has had legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department which confirms that the law does require clarification to put this principle beyond doubt in the legislation. However, the amendment does not seek any additional discretion and is not intended to involve any changes to existing procedures. In other words, the current arrangements for women leaving a violent situation are not changed. We are aware of the concerns raised about the impact of this legislation, particularly on people separating in circumstances involving domestic violence, but the concerns are unnecessary and misleading. There is no intention in the amendment to change the current procedures or to put any additional barriers to people needing to leave violent situations.

The admission procedures for sole parents pay particular attention to the issues of domestic violence. Indeed, while we have a requirement that in order to be eligible for the sole parent pension claimants take reasonable action to obtain maintenance, if there is any evidence or case made about domestic violence then different arrangements are permitted. People can seek an exemption from the maintenance action if they are in fear.

I think it is very appropriate for Senator Woodley to raise this concern. So many of us argued and fought for protection for people, women in particular, leaving a domestic violence situation. We certainly do not want to put further hurdles in their way if it comes to seeking financial support from the sole parent pension.

The referral to a social worker comes as a matter of course if there is any evidence or any reference to violence. Where a client is at risk or has left an abusive relationship, their entitlement to the pension is usually clear cut. Sometimes, however, family breakdown is complex. It does, as Senator Woodley knows, cover a myriad of situations. There are situations where claimants may not be able to say that the relationship has permanently ended. They may indeed be going through a period of separation. There may not be any evidence or even any claim that that is a separation consequent on violence in the relationship. In those cases, it is important that the individual circumstances are examined closely and that the pension not be provided, as I said for the examples before, except where there is clearly demonstrated, real need.

The department does have procedures to verify separation. These can include contacting external parties nominated by the client. In addition, the department has domestic violence procedures which help its public contact officers to recognise it and to provide sensitive assistance to clients who may be victims of domestic violence.

I think it is very important that we do not create a public perception that could deter women from applying to claim the sole parent pension in such situations, for example of domestic violence, when it will be absolutely necessary for them to have it and when they indeed will be eligible. I think we acknowledge a significant change in the sensitive way in which such people are now assisted in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer and for the assurance given, but I must say the memorandum which I read does not have all the qualifications which the minister has indicated. I wonder whether in the legislation or in some other way the minister could make that assurance clearer.
—I will certainly raise that with the minister and seek a further clarification either in the memorandum or during the debate in this place.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the existing arrangements for the appointment by the minister of directors of the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters. Appointments are made to it by the minister in consultation with the states. Why has the minister now told the states that in future he proposes to make three of the five appointments, including that of chairman, without consultation with the states and has said that unless the states agree with his proposals he will reconsider the Commonwealth's financial contribution to the authority? Is this blatant blackmail by the minister, yet another example of his arrogant determination to exercise power to appoint political cronies to agencies within his portfolio as he has already demonstrated so amply with many of his appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal?

—It is an unfortunate fact that Senator Short either does not have the capacity to do the research or does not have an interest in it. If he did, he would see very clearly why the federal government has made this particular move. There has been a settled approach to the way in which directors are appointed. It was only a few months ago that the New South Wales government moved a motion at the previous meeting of the board that the board should be appointed by the Commonwealth minister on the advice of resolution of members. Basically, there was a move a couple of months ago by the New South Wales government to take whatever final say this government had in appointing members to the board of NAATI right out of our hands and make the minister and the federal government the rubber stamp. That is the preceding information on this.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short can say it as often as he likes, but the reality is that we pay some $380,000 in funds for NAATI. That amount is probably 10 times the amount of most of the states. New South Wales pays over $200,000, but I am not so sure what its amount is. We pay a majority of the money. Whereas at the moment we do have a say at the end of the day as to who does get appointed, the New South Wales resolution was that all this power be taken away from the federal government. Basically we provide the funds but we have no say in terms of who is appointed.

When that happened Senator Short said absolutely nothing—nothing in defence of the federal position, nothing in defence of taxpayers' money. This hijack was going on, and his mates in New South Wales would have told him about it, but there was silence from the other side and a lack of willingness to even focus on the issue. If that had not taken place we would not have had the meeting in Adelaide last week in the atmosphere in which that meeting took place. We would not have had to confront the issue.

No federal minister, whether it is me or the Minister for Finance or whatever, would allow a situation where federal government money is spent in an area where we do have a responsibility but spent with our being purely rubber stamps. I said to New South Wales and Queensland officials last week—I met with them very briefly—`If you want to go back to the previous situation, if you want to talk turkey, we are prepared to do that, but don't ask us to be the rubber stamp when federal funds are involved and involved in such a way.'

That is the background to this, Senator Short, and no matter what flavour you want to put add to it no matter how you want to spin it the reality is twofold: first, we are not going to absolve our responsibility and, secondly, it would really do debate in this area a lot of good if just for one moment you got out of the gutter and got into some policy. Put at your foremost consideration, Senator Short, the interests of Australian taxpayers. If we are going to be in a situation where we have no say as to how the funds are spent, where we are going to be rubber stamps, then obviously we have to consider how those fund are being spent. In that spirit of trying to work this out, I have had discussions already and I expect those discussions will lead to a constructive result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did he not inform the Senate in that totally misleading answer that the proposal of the states was basically that he would appoint the directors of NAATI on the `advice of a resolution of members' of which the Commonwealth is one, and what action does he now propose to take following last week's unanimous rejection of his blackmail threat to the governments, including a rejection by the Labor state of Queensland?

—A meeting of the board of directors is a meeting in which every member has one vote. In a situation where we are going to be swamped as one vote then obviously we have no say. Just focus on it, Senator Short. The states are trying to go from a situation where we had a say at the end of the day to a situation where we are one of seven and our vote can be dominated. That is the states' position and that is precisely the sort of dissipation of federal involvement that I am not going to be a party to. In terms of what is going to happen in the future, as I said to you, but once again you do not have the capacity to listen, I have already had discussions with officials and, despite your interference, despite your negative involvement, despite whatever spin you want to put on it, despite all the politics you want to play, we will get to a constructive outcome.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to provide some additional information to a question asked today by Senator Macdonald. During question time today I discussed statements that had been made by the shadow minister for primary industries and energy, Mr Anderson, and a press statement that had been issued by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Fischer) on the opposition's policy. I could not remember the town but I was in fact correct. The press release from Mr Fischer is headed `The Rolleston declaration'. The opening paragraph states:

ANSWER.PARA: A declaration made by the Leader of the National Party, Tim Fischer, at Rolleston on Tuesday, 14 February.
Mr Fischer makes the point in here about this policy, which it was alleged we wanted to steal, that `this is not a concluded policy statement.' Mr Fisher says it is not a policy.

PARA.TAB: I also table the statement made by Mr John Anderson describing the statements that Mr McLachlan had made as `totally inaccurate and a hypothetical furphy'. That was the question of using the external affairs powers to compel farmers to provide their land. I table a copy of what Mr Fischer says is the non-policy of the coalition. I got the page number wrong. I said page 4; it is actually on page 6 where he said that providing farmers with compensation for not clearing their land would be `both simple and inexpensive'. Both statements are wrong. Senator Parer asked a question—

TALK.START.PARA: —In whose view?
—In Mr Fischer's view, as I said—`Martin Luther' Tim Fischer.
