ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 November 1994, Senator Parer asked a question relating to rescinding the lifting of curfews at Sydney airport. The Minister for Transport has provided me with an answer. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard. I am happy for Senator Parer to have a copy of it now.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer the Minister to the wildcat strike held by the Transport Workers Union refuellers at Sydney Airport on 3 November. As a result of this action, six international airlines were granted at 5.00pm an exemption to operate outside the curfew time. Why did the Minister at about 7.00pm rescind this exemption at great inconvenience to the airlines' passengers and at an estimated cost of $1 million to the airlines. Was the exemption cancelled to avoid the possibility of provoking an even larger protest against Mr Keating's opening of the third runway on the following day?
The Minister for Transport has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

No. The curfew dispensations were rescinded to facilitate resolution of the refuellers industrial action. Parties should not be able to protract resolution of industrial disputes in the knowledge that curfew dispensations will automatically be granted to clear a backlog of flights. The curfew is in place to protect the community living around Sydney Airport from sleep disturbance.

On 8 December 1994 the Government announced a number of measures to minimise the number of people affected by aircraft noise in Sydney. These measures included a stringent enforcement of the curfew arrangements and the amendment of the Air Navigation (Aerodrome Curfew) Regulations to provide for financial penalties for unauthorised curfew operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the current account deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: The former finance minister in this government, Peter Walsh, used to describe the Democrats as the `fairies at the bottom of the garden' party in this parliament. I have news for Peter Walsh: that title has been well and truly usurped by his own party—this bunch of economic vandals opposite, the Keating government.

PARA.TAB: It is quite obvious from today's figures, and from Senator Evans's answer to Senator Hill's question, that Senator Evans, the third most senior member in this government and an aspirant for the job of Prime Minister, does not have a clue about the seriousness of Australia's balance of payments crisis, a crisis due directly to the disastrous failure of the Labor government's policies throughout its 12 long years in government. I point out that, for all of this time, the chief architect of those failed policies has been the former Treasurer and current Prime Minister, Mr Keating.

We now have the balance of payments figures for the first seven months of this financial year. They show the worst balance of payments results in our history. In all but one of those seven months of this financial year, the monthly deficit has been well over $2 billion. That is a huge figure that is continuing to plunge us into hock with the rest of the world—week by week, day by day, hour by hour. That is not the end of it though because, on the revised forecast of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) presented just a few weeks ago, the government expects the average monthly deficit over the remaining five months of this financial year to continue at a level of $2 billion.

We now have the second highest external deficit of any country in the OECD—that is, in the industrialised western world—with the single exception being Mexico. That is a country that is still gripped by a financial crisis brought about by its external account difficulties.The OECD's forecast for Australia of a deficit of four per cent of GDP released last year will now have to be increased in line with the government's recent upward revision—that is, a figure now for 1994-95 of 5 3/4 per cent of gross domestic product. By comparison, the United States—a country which is extremely concerned about its external imbalance—has a current account deficit forecast of 2.3 per cent of GDP, less than half that of Australia's. The OECD as a whole—that is, our counterpart countries throughout the world—is virtually balanced in its trade surpluses and deficits, much as would be expected.

Since 1970, Australia has recorded on only four occasions a current account deficit greater than five per cent of gross domestic product. On all four occasions, that occurred under Mr Keating's stewardship. This latest enormous, very damaging and very serious blow-out in our balance of payments comes at a time when a number of factors in the world are making markets less settled and more volatile. We have seen the Mexican financial crisis, the Barings collapse, the Orange County bankruptcy and so forth. The days of Australia being able to easily count on cheap foreign finance to pay for its beyond-its-means standard of living are fast disappearing.

We are in this situation irrevocably and irrefutably because of the government's economic policies. Under this government we have seen lax financial administration. As a result of that, we have seen a collapse in investment—investment which is now recovering, admittedly, but with no change in the underlying fundamentals of our economy. We have seen an eight-fold increase in our debt to the rest of the world. We have seen interest rates go through the roof to being the highest in the Western world.

Yet from the minister's reply to Senator Hill today, there was a quite breathtaking complacency about the seriousness of our situation. If that is the way the government will be tackling economic policy making in the forthcoming budget then, as a result of this government's policies, Australians will continue to suffer falling living standards, lower economic growth and, of course, a huge cost in terms of jobs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on the answer given today by Senator Gareth Evans to Senator Hill. Today's balance of payments figures of $2.289 billion, seasonally adjusted, confirm all the fears that we have had for quite some time—that the economy is out of kilter, that the economy is not being controlled properly by this government, and that we are in for a hell of a long ride down the roller-coaster to oblivion.

PARA.TAB: The interest rate blow-outs, the current account blow-outs and the dollar rises and falls are all militating against us being able to handle the problems that we have in our economy. Last month we had $2.235 billion which this government just wafted away and said, `That's not too bad; we're on the right track.' This Prime Minister that we have at the moment, who was our Treasurer for many years, has said that we are on the right track. But we are not on the right track because now it looks like we are going to have an annual figure of about $26 billion go down the hole.

If any business, household or anyone were to have a business so far out of kilter as that, they would really want to be having a good look at what was happening. But this government is not doing anything at all about it. It has forecast an approximate $18 billion annual deficit for this year with the balance of payments, and it will end up at about $26 billion.

This government claims that we are the lowest taxed country in the world. This is one of the things, of course, that militates against us being a trading nation that can compete. We will just look at some of the things that this Treasurer we had, the Prime Minister we have now, has done to us over the last few years.

In 1983 there was a fuel tax take of $2.1 billion; for 1994-95 there will be an estimated tax take of $9.7 billion being whipped out of everyone's pockets here in Australia by the government. Sales taxes have gone from $4.16 billion in 1983-84 to $10.3 billion now, and they are going to go to $11.1 billion next year. These are all militating factors against us getting our balance of payments under control. Just have a look at fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to start selling things?

—Senator Forshaw can smile and laugh about it. He should just look at what the government has done to the economy here in Australia with the fringe benefits tax. There was no fringe benefits tax when those opposite came into government, and now it has been estimated that $3.2 billion will be whipped off everyone next year in fringe benefits tax. The Medicare levy used to be about $360-odd million; it is going to be something like $3 billion in the coming years.

PARA.TAB: As for income tax, the government says that it looks after us as a country; it says that it does not overtax us. Listen to this one: in 1983-84 the federal government was taking $29 billion in income tax. What is it taking now? Income tax which is being taken from every Australian wage earner and others is $71 billion. Smile about that! Smile about the fact that at the moment we have a balance of payments deficit that we cannot jump over. I really wonder what those on the government side think about this.

Senator Gareth Evans today just gave a bland answer and said that we are on the right track and everything is going pretty well. Really, those opposite should start thinking about what they are doing to the Australian economy with their taxes and start taking note of what is happening with the balance of payments.

We are second now only to Mexico. Your Prime Minister used to say that we could become a banana republic. He successfully worked very hard at it and, over the last 10 years, he has nearly made us the banana republic. It is time that he got the bend out of the banana, straightened up his spine a bit, did a bit about our economy, took the taxes off the back of the people who are wanting to export, fixed up the balance of payments figures and did something for every wage earner here in Australia. It is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today Australia experienced one of the worst current account deficits ever. We as a nation lost $2.3 billion. The merchandise trade deficit alone was $1.23 billion. To put that into perspective, it is almost double the November merchandise trade deficit. The exports are down five per cent and imports are up six per cent. Six of the last seven deficits are now greater than $2 billion. That has never happened before in our history. This is a crisis of monumental proportions.

PARA.TAB: What is the government's response? `We are on track; we are on target.' Forget the fact that the target was changed by some $8 billion only a few weeks ago. The government usually goes back in history and refers to Fraser. It does not have any plans to resolve this issue. It does not even apologise for dragging Australia down into the mire. It simply tries to rewrite history. It actually tries to mis-state the facts. Let me just briefly state the facts. When Fraser left office 12 years ago, the foreign net liability was $23 billion; now it is over $160 billion—more than seven times under this government.

Today we had the government's response to this. It is a disaster. The response was a mixture of arrogance and conceit blended with a little bit of, `Don't blame me, I'm only the Prime Minister, Treasurer, Leader of the Government in the Senate, finance minister,' whatever the case may be. It is always someone else's fault. It is never the fault of the government—that is assuming that they ever recognise there is a problem. Usually, `We are right on track.' That is the obvious answer that Ralph Willis and Senator Gareth Evans give. They try to gloss over the fact that that target for that track was actually raised by $8 billion only three or four weeks ago.

The blow-out now is approaching some 5.75 per cent of GDP. In 1986, when the current account deficit was approaching six per cent, the then Prime Minister went on the Laws program and said, `You cannot fund $12 billion in perpetuity every year. You have to slow growth.' But when growth is less than three per cent, unemployment goes up. Then we hear those famous words which we all remember, `You have gone. You are a banana republic.' How appropriate it was here yesterday that Senator Evans was described as bananas in pyjamas. Not only is he a banana; he is in sleep mode. It is the perfect response for a banana republic. In 1986, we could not fund $12 billion a year; now it is now $26 billion a year. It is almost six per cent of GDP. So, by the government's own definition, we are on the road to becoming a banana republic.

Let us not forget that it is the worst current account deficit in the OECD, except for Mexico. We all know what has happened to Mexico recently. The government is not able to tackle these issues. All it has done is to do what it did last time—put up interest rates, slug the home owners and slug the small businessmen. Worse than that, the Prime Minister has the hide to say we should be grateful to him for putting up interest rates; it is a good thing. He says it is taking out premium insurance on our jobs because, if he puts up interest rates, we keep our jobs. He ignores the fact that Australians are already paying the highest prime bank rates in the world. He ignores the fact that when interest rates go up small business, in particular, lays off people and jobs are lost.

Around Australia, people are bewildered, frustrated and angry. They suffered the pain of the last recession because they were told that an economic summer would follow. After all the pain, the anguish and the suffering, they were told things would get better in the long term. Of course they are angry when we have five minutes of economic sunshine and then the economic storm clouds start rolling in again. They can see the writing on the wall; they can see the unemployment; they can see the bankruptcies; they can see the social costs; and they can see the struggling families. This is all the pain of the last few years revisited. The worst of it all is that the government has no solution. It does not recognise that there are problems.

In terms of export services to GDP ratios, Australia is ranked 21 out of 22 in the OECD. For the corresponding six months last year, the deficit was $7.6 billion. This year it is $12.8 billion—68 per cent worse. It is not only a disgrace; it is a complete disaster. Yet Senator Evans's response was that the economy was infinitely stronger and more balanced than it has been in the past and that the government would address this in the budget. The budget is not until May, and this is urgent. We need action now. We do not just need a banana getting into pyjamas.

Senator Evans asked about what we were going to do. That is a sign of a government in disarray. By implication he asked whether we would have the guts to put up taxes. Clearly, the implication is that is what he is going to do. He is going to put up taxes. What he wants to do is the same as before: he wants to crush the life out of the economy—and, sadly, the government will crush the lives of the Australian people.

Paul Keating himself said these were not just accounting figures, but this is something which touches every Australian and, above all, our children. Sadly, the current disaster is something which is mortgaging the future of the children of Australia, and the government should hang its head in shame. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to take note of the answer relating to a question about our deficit, which for successive months has been $2,300 million. I believe this is a continuing disaster for the Australian economy, more importantly for Australian workers. Imports so far this year are up $5.16 billion, or 14 per cent. Imports of consumption goods are up by 12 per cent. We as a nation simply cannot sustain these sorts of trends.

PARA.TAB: In particular I wish to address the issue of what we are doing about the deficit. The government, when challenged on these particular figures, says again and again, `Yes, but our exports are rising.' This answer is nothing short of misleading the Senate because, while exports are rising from a very slow base, imports are rising at a much faster rate. This year we admittedly had 16 per cent export growth in ETMs and about 10 per cent for total manufactures. However, this has come, as I have said, from an extremely low base.

Manufacturing import growth, however, is much greater in absolute terms. Import penetration has grown to 25 per cent of total domestic sales—up from 15 per cent in the 1970s. The manufacturing trade deficit has now grown to $35.3 billion for 1994. That is the last available figure. We should note that this is up from $15 billion in 1984 and $4 billion in 1974. In other words, we continue to import at a much faster rate than we export. I believe that the government is hoodwinking this house and the community by hiding the figures that clearly demonstrate that the situation is getting worse, not better.

In the answer that I received today from the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, he said our imports are rising. That was in specific reference to the car industry. Let me quote an article headed `Automotive trade deficit speeds up', which was in the Australian Financial Review of 20 February 1995 and written by Michael Lynch. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's automotive trade deficit ballooned out to $7.3 billion in 1994, a sharp increase on the $6.15 billion motor industry trade shortfall the nation posted in 1993.

. . . statistics clearly illustrate the full extent of the structural imbalance in which the nation's auto sector operates. Exports of cars and parts last year, at $1.539 billion, were at record levels. But so were imports, which totalled $8.881 billion.

This is the figure that Senator McMullan did not disclose to the Senate. The government does not disclose these figures to the community and does not disclose them to this house. This is the truth. This is why the trade balance that we received today is a continuing disaster. This government must take the step of taking immediate action to do something about our imports. By extending our general tariff reduction program by just one year we could raise an extra $600 million and directly tackle the current account problem.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the government must look at direct measures to tackle imports and it must look at what I have pointed out to Senator McMullan: there is inaction on the part of our trading partners in maintaining their trading barriers while Australia continues the current trend of unilateral tariff reductions. Their inaction hits our industries and causes Australian job losses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the answer given by Senator Gareth Evans to Senator Hill's question today. It is quite tragic the way that Senator Evans, the leader of the government in this place, tried to answer that particular question. It is quite clear from his answer that the government is not prepared to recognise the seriousness of the current situation in terms of our current account and the fact that we are now in a trend of up around or in excess of $2 billion on a month by month basis. It is worth examining a few figures in terms of the seriousness of this problem. We only have to look at the estimate now for this year for the total balance of payments deficit of something like $26 billion.

PARA.TAB: All Senator Evans could point at today and say was, `You people won't support tax increases.' I will deal with that particular aspect in a moment. It is worth noting that in the last five years of the coalition government, before this government came into power, the total of the current account deficit was around about what it is going to be for this year—about $26 billion. It is also worth noting that in 1979-80 the current account deficit for the whole year was $1.974 billion. We have now had three consecutive months—a trend; it was an aberration last month, but it must be considered a trend now—of $2 billion more in each of those months. As has already been stated, it was more in six of the last seven months than it was for that whole year.

Senator Evans made the comment, `You people will not support tax increases.' Let us have a look and see what the government said about tax increases when it was politically expedient for it to do so. On Lateline on 19 November 1992, Mr Keating stated, `What I am promising is not to put up tax.' On 9 February 1993 the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . let me tell you something that I thought you might have known, they've been legislated. They are not a promise, they're law.
That is in relation to the tax cuts. We know what happened to them and where they went. There was the promise by this government to pensioners. It was stated:

Labor's commitment to removing all age and service pensioners from the tax system by 1995 will benefit pensioners paid at the part rate as well as providing some assistance to retirees with incomes beyond the pension cut out point.

I suggest very strongly that Senator Evans and the government are in no position to talk about our position as far as taxation is concerned. The facts are that they have not addressed in a proper way what is required to overcome the crisis that we now have with our balance of payments. One of the major areas which one must emphasise over and over again—and we listened to Senator Spindler and his solution—is that the real reason why we are not competitive in this country and we have imports flowing in consistently is the failure of this government to address proper labour market reform. That is the fundamental problem and issue the government will not tackle, because its masters in the union movement will not let it.

PARA.TAB: It is going to be very interesting today—because the Asahi case comes down at about half past four—to see what the industrial court says in relation to that particular case and whether or not we are going to see a little bit of sanity coming into what is a fraudulent piece of legislation brought in by Mr Brereton some 15 months or so ago. Until such time as this government—if it remains in government—is prepared to address that particular issue, we will not overcome and we will not address the particular problems we now have with imports flowing into this country.

Our current industrial relations system provides a total disincentive for businesses in this nation and for the work force to get out there and improve its lot. This government is not capable of addressing the real issues that are required to get on top of this disaster that we have on our hands and reversing the trend. We will continue to see, as a result of these types of figures, pressure on interest rates, pressure on unemployment and pressure on a whole range of other aspects of the economy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cooney this day, relating to the BHP Steelworks in Newcastle.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon Senator Cook painted a very glowing picture of what is happening in the steel industry in Australia. Indeed, many of the changes in recent years have been of great benefit to this industry. It is certainly in a much more profitable position than it was before. It has moved far more into the export of product and it has become far more efficient.

PARA.TAB: I listened to what Senator Cook said and I fear that he might have glossed over an ugly reality of the development of this industry. He did mention the expansion of the flat products division of the Wollongong steel industry, and that is to be welcomed. He mentioned the expansion of the Whyalla division, which is also to be welcomed.

When he got to Newcastle, he glossed over what was happening up there by saying, `There's going to be new investment.' That is true; there is going to be new investment. What he did not do—I will follow this up and ask him some very serious questions about this—was indicate the nature of that type of investment and the effect that that will have on employment in that area.

What we have seen over the last 20 years in Newcastle, in the time that I have been there, is a steel industry that has gone from employing 20,000 people down to 4 1/2 thousand people. The steel industry has improved efficiencies a great deal, and part of the agenda of the 1980s was certainly to make industrial operations more efficient. But the minister glossed over the fact that the changes coming will probably not relate so much to efficiency as to a scaling down of the nature of the type of steel that is produced and the employment that that in turn will generate.

In Australia we have two fully generated steelworks—one at Wollongong and one at Newcastle. I fear that the Wollongong steelworks will be the only remaining integrated steelworks if current plans which are in place continue. The city is rife with rumours that a mini-mill will be established in Newcastle. This new investment could be related to the closing down of the integrated steelworks and the establishment of a mini-mill, something like the one in Rooty Hill in Sydney, which works on an electric process, which is not the usual way that steel is produced by coal.

This has ramifications right through the Hunter Valley. There will be a loss of jobs in the steel industry and, therefore, there will be a loss of jobs in the coal industry, the transport industry and a whole range of associated industries. It was very deceptive of the minister today to gloss over this fact. It was deceptive when, at a time of very high unemployment and extremely high regional unemployment, what is happening in the steel industry is likely to exacerbate this problem.

John Howard has spoken about the five minutes of economic sunlight that Australia has enjoyed recently. The sun did not come up for many areas in Australia. It certainly did not come up for the Hunter Valley. Up until the last two months, unemployment levels in the Hunter Valley consistently stayed at 15 per cent, when in the rest of the country they dropped from over 11 per cent to over nine.

Regional unemployment is rife. It is disingenuous of the minister to today gloss over this fact and pretend that in Newcastle it was net new investment when it probably would be no such thing. This industry will decline further. Unfortunately, even though the Hunter economy is diversifying at some pace, it will not be sufficient to take yet another blow to the Hunter economy by dropping employment in steel and its associated industries.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering an amendment moved by Senator Alston. The question has separately been put in respect of paragraphs 3(f) and 3(h). They have been passed as amended. The question is that the remainder of the amendment moved by Senator Alston be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We left off at the point where Senator Kernot had put to me a question in relation to the meaning and operation of this amendment. If I understood her correctly, Senator Kernot suggested that the words `those who suffer the most disadvantage in relation to access to land' invite the same sort of conflict and concern that `most severely dispossessed' caused.

PARA.TAB: I will address that question but I also need to consider Senator Kernot's other question, which was: do you read this in conjunction with amendment 25, which talks about health, housing, education and the like? The first question was put to the coalition with the comment made by the dissenting report from Senator Reynolds and Senator Lees at page 199:

SPEECH.PARA: To demonstrate the inherent unworkability of this formula, take the example of an Aboriginal community living by some form of agreement on another person's pastoral lease. On one view, they are not very disadvantaged at all in terms of `access to land' compared with, say, an indigenous commune in a densely populated part of a city. On another view, however, the group on the pastoral lease could be seen as disadvantaged in the extreme, because they are so agonisingly close to the unfettered enjoyment of their heritage. The prospect of complex and lengthy legal action, in this or many other particular situations that could arise, is all too plain.

With due respect, they have missed the point. In relation to the formula that has been expressed by the coalition you also look at those who are unable to gain substantive title to the land. Although you might have a group who have access to land, they still might deserve consideration in the event of a conflict of allocation of funds if they do not have substantive title to the land.

PARA.TAB: That is precisely the point that Senators Reynolds and Lees were making in this minority report. They were saying that if you have these people living on the pastoral lease by agreement they have the access to the land. That is true. They say that, because they have access to the land, our formula fails them. Of course it does not, because the alternative in the formula is those who are unable to gain substantive title to the land. That was raised by Noel Pearson, the executive director of the Cape York Land Council. He said that it is not just access to land that is a yardstick of merit; it is also whether you have title to the land. He cited as an example those people in Queensland who had land gazetted in their favour.

So when you look at the amendment, do not just look at the first limb of it, because there are two limbs. The group that is living on the pastoral lease might have access to land but they fall down on lack of title because they are there only by agreement with the pastoralist concerned. So they would not miss out. When you applied the amendment in its true form you could see how severely disadvantaged they were because priority is to be given to those who are disadvantaged in either access to land or title to land. I believe that answers the question posed by Senator Kernot.

Amendment 25, which deals with health, housing and education—which all go to the viability of the community—was in a different section of the bill and dealt with the policies that the ILC, the Indigenous Land Corporation, had to adopt—very different to the principle and objects of the bill. The principle and objects of the bill are in much more general terms. They are to be found at the beginning of the bill, whereas the actual policy of how you acquire interests, manage land or give grants of money or loans, et cetera, is more the nitty-gritty of it, so to speak. Therefore, you would not read them together because one is a principle and object of the bill; the other is a policy of the acquisition of land. I remind those who are concerned about amendment 25 that during the hearings there was a good deal of misunderstanding about that. The amendment talks about improving the viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, including by addressing their health, housing, educational, economic, social and cultural needs.

Now the word `or' meant that any one of them could be considered. Not all of them had to be considered, not some of them had to be considered, not the majority of them had to be considered, but at least one of them had to be considered. It could be based on the cultural, social, health, housing or educational needs.

Those are the policy aspects, but it is very different when it comes to the crunch when you have a conflict of interest in the allocation of funding and there is a dollar available and you have two very good applicants vying for that dollar. If you give both of them 50c you might not help either one of them. You might have to make a decision that one gets it and the other one does not. You may say to the other, `Come back next year.' That is an unenviable task and it is much like the discretion ministers have in the allocation of funding. This gives a principle in the bill as to how that will be done when that dilemma arises.

I indicate that you should not read that together with amendment 25. When you apply this formula you should look at the two limbs which are access to land and those who are unable to gain title to land. As I said earlier, the evidence of Peter Yu from the Kimberley Land Council was that access to land was an aspect to be considered. I will not recite again what I have already outlined to the chamber. I do believe that that assists in answering Senator Kernot's questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has consistently opposed any attempt to have the legislation include directions on the prioritising of access to land fund moneys. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech on the new bill that is currently before the House of Representatives drew attention to the unworkability and divisiveness of such a provision. When referring to the Senate select committee's proposed amendment, which is now before us today, to delete the reference to `most severely dispossessed' and to substitute a different form of words, the Prime Minister said:

PARA.TAB: The committee's solution, however—a form of words which would still seek to rank degrees of disadvantage in terms of access to land—clearly fails to overcome the objection to the original amendment. Any statutory obligation to calculate and calibrate different degrees of disadvantage is bound to generate unproductive disputation.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly how we read this provision. The coalition has really just plucked another vague and undefined set of criteria out of the air as a means of determining priority. The formulation that is on offer now will lead, in our judgment, to difficulties which are equal to those arising from the original amendment.

PARA.TAB: If the ILC is in the position, as the opposition proposes it should be, of having to apply these kinds of criteria and make sense of them, that is going to make, here as elsewhere, its operation very top heavy bureaucratically and would necessarily concentrate a whole lot more decision making power in a centralised structure. Some criteria are going to have to be developed to establish the relative degrees of disadvantage and everything else that is associated with this provision.

Then we get to the problems of definitional detail. What exactly does access mean in this context? Is it to be defined in a purely physical sense? If that is right, then contemplate this: some states, and of course the Northern Territory, do guarantee access physically to pastoral leases in their legislation. That can hardly be compared to the rights which are conferred by full ownership. Is access not to be defined then in a physical sense but rather in some kind of structural sense, if I can put it that way, as in access to land acquisition programs or access to a legislative right to claim land irrespective of whether such a claim might be successful? If that is the case and if there is some notional right of access in that generalised structural sense, then you have a situation where the Aboriginal people of New South Wales would go right to the bottom of the priority list because that state does have a land rights act and does have land acquisition funds.

Then you have the problem of how the ILC will assess, on the other limb of the equation, whether people are unable to gain substantive title to land, to use that part of the proposed new formula. Does gaining title encompass simply the ability to buy land and thereby gain title, or does it mean gaining native title through the processes of the NTA, the Native Title Act?

The difficulties in defining these principles—the difficulties that I have identified in understanding what these words are to mean and how they are to be applied—are inevitably again, as so often, going to lead to arguments and legal challenge. They are going to lead inevitably to disputation about who has the least access, who has the most access, who has something in between along some graduated schedule and who at least is able to gain substantive title to land—however you define that. The whole amendment is an invitation to litigate. It places the courts again, I suppose, in the position of defining by exclusion who can get access to the land fund through setting aside the ILC's decisions.

The truth of the matter is that all of this is just too complex to be prescribed by legislation which is inevitably going to be the subject of litigation. The diversity of circumstances of indigenous people all around the country means that there is going to be a range of priorities. It is going to involve a lot of difficult and delicate questions of judgment and balance.

For some groups, there is an urgency in returning to their land before their culture and their language are lost completely. They might be people who do have access to land already in the sense of the Northern Territory right of access to pastoral leases for the purposes of formally exercising at least some rights to enjoy the land in question and not having any substantive character about the legal recognition of those rights but, nonetheless, raising questions of definition and application of the kind that I have already referred to. You can have competing priorities cutting across particular individual situations.

So what we are saying again with utmost good faith—and we do not say this in any spirit of being cantankerous or just dismissive; I have tried to give a reasoned response to every one of these amendments all the way through this long debate—is that assessing priority in the allocation of the fund moneys should be left to the ILC board, which in the absence of legislative prescription will be able to take into account the diversity of needs of indigenous people in this country. It should be empowered to make its own decisions without unnecessary constraints which undermine its authority and make its job unworkable. That is our position and, there again, I am afraid that is where we are going to have to stick. We will vote against the amendment accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly; I do not want to delay the Senate. Senator Evans does make the point that the ILC board will ultimately have to make these sorts of decisions at its own discretion. The genesis of the wording of the modification to the amendment came not only from the evidence to the committee where, as Senator Ellison already said, Noel Pearson very articulately described at the Cairns hearings a whole series of circumstances where it would be desirable to assist certain groups in Australia to get access to land under the land fund before others. Senator Evans, I think, alluded to that when he spoke about those who should be given access as urgently as possible before they lose any more of their culture or tradition. Mr Pearson made the point that there are probably people who have been entirely dispossessed of their land and have lost a lot of that culture and tradition. It is probably in the interests of maintaining culture and tradition to find people who have not lost all the culture and tradition and who can be reunited with some land more urgently. That, of course, is addressed by the words of this modification to the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Equally, Senator Ellison referred to Peter Yu from the Kimberley Land Council. That reminds us that, when the first discussion about this controversial amendment in its initial form was first debated by the Senate, Aboriginal groups around the country held a meeting. I actually forget where it was held, but it was basically to resolve what was regarded by the media as a sort of north-south divide over this legislation. They did agree that there needed to be a principle in the bill. The Kimberley Land Council, the Cape York Land Council and the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council agreed on a number of things at that meeting: one, that this bill not be regarded as compensation for disposition and, two, that it not stop them from claiming compensation in the future.

Even though they agreed to disagree on the words `most severely dispossessed', they did agree that there should be a guiding principle. Peter Yu and Noel Pearson both stated that to the committee and supported the broad concept of assisting those with the least access to land and the least ability to gain access. Mr Pearson said in evidence that states like New South Wales, possibly South Australia and, to a limited extent, the Northern Territory already have existing legislation to give people like that access to the land. There were other states like Queensland where that did not happen and where the priority may be greater.

The point I make is that there is a need ultimately to set priorities. The board will have to do that one way or the other. The issue then at stake is whether or not there should be a guiding principle in the legislation or whether we should just leave it to the board to make those decisions month by month, week by week, claim by claim and application by application.

The coalition, after lengthy consideration and after hearing all of the evidence from the 244-odd witnesses around Australia, believes that the principle should be enshrined in the bill. I think it is fair to say that an absolutely overwhelming majority of people who came before the committee agreed that that principle should be in there. The only witness strongly against it was ATSIC. Even a number of ATSIC commissioners and ATSIC operatives on the ground around the country came forward and disagreed with the position put by ATSIC's submission. So there was overwhelmingly support for there to be a principle in there.

I agree with Senator Evans that the wording of that principle needs to be done carefully. We believe the wording, as a result of the committee's deliberations, is much better than `most severely dispossessed'. The committee and the coalition were convinced that trying to assign grades of dispossession is not only repugnant to Aboriginal people but is also probably impractical and unworkable. That we have come up with this revised wording is a reflection of the fact that the committee was prepared to do the work and listen to the voices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. I commend the modification of the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the Greens' support for this amendment. I am sure that will come as no great surprise to anyone in the chamber, but I will state briefly the reasons for it. The most important thing is that the failure to state a principle within the bill to assist in the prioritising of the very small amount of funds available across Australia means that some other different principle will have to be used in the operation of the fund. We need to make that principle, or whatever divergent principles are operating, explicit to avoid a de facto prioritising to perhaps a first come first served basis or to perhaps easier access to those groups who have already had the resources to work out what they need and where they need it and to be able to make their claims in an expeditious fashion.

PARA.TAB: If there was adequate funding to meet all the needs of all Aboriginal people who cannot gain land via the Native Title Act or by any other means, it might be a different question. We might not need to put a priority guiding principle within the aims and objects of this legislation. But, if I may say so, it is an extremely strange omission that a fund should be set out without any objects or principles that ensure that those who read that act will know the purpose of the funds being made available and what kinds of priorities might need to be exercised in case those funds were short of the amount required to fulfil their total purpose. Any failure to state those principles by which moneys will be allocated is bound to generate ill feeling across the Aboriginal community.

Repeatedly in the consultations that the committee took, there was anxiety as to how the extra $21 million was to be allocated—whether it was to go to every person at $124 per person per year, to every state at $2 million to $3 million per state, or divided between all states except perhaps New South Wales, which has a land council, or the Northern Territory, which has a land rights act. That anxiety was already present amongst the people who did support the need for some guiding principle.

As has already been stated, the whole use of the phrase `most severely dispossessed' had become so detached from the context in which it was expressed, which was where there is a conflict that this kind of prioritising should be taken into consideration. That emotive usage of it by those who opposed any guiding principle being placed in the bill at all did allow many people to feel gravely concerned. Nevertheless, they all understood that when there was so little money to go around some kind of explicit guidelines would be useful and helpful.

We believe that the amendment that the opposition has come to as a result of the committee hearings is a twofold thing: it is a sign of their goodwill politically to look at the concerns and it is also a worthy inclusion in the bill itself. While Senator Evans's view is that it is all too complex and there is an invitation for litigation, I repeat what I said earlier—that stating a principle to which the ILC can adhere to and be seen to adhere to will protect it from litigation provided it takes all reasonable steps to ensure that it has endeavoured to make a determination which relates to the purpose of the fund. After all, we were told that the purpose of the fund was to assist those who have been dispossessed of their lands. They were the Prime Minister's words and that was one of the reasons why we used those words and agreed to those words in the principles.

There are two possible reasons why the government is remaining adamant about this. One is that it may be that it wants to prioritise those groups that are more aware of what lands they need—they can actually see their country; it might be a country fund, not a land fund for dispossessed people who will not gain by native title—those who can see their country but cannot own it and who may already have a very well-founded belief that they should be assisted to help buy back that land from whatever leasehold or freehold it is under and regain their culture. I do not blame them for that one bit. But the government cannot win both ways. It cannot pretend that this is a land fund for all Aboriginal people who have been dispossessed and who will not benefit from native title if what it is really intending is for a small segment of those people to be able to gain. If it wants to do that, then it should state a different principle rather than simply leaving it unstated.

The second reason why the government may be so adamant about not having any prioritising principles in the bill is that it does not mind that the acquisition needs of Aboriginal people may well be swamped by the management needs of the land they already hold and also of any lands that may be acquired through the fund. That is one of the matters. This guiding principle that it may well be that groups which, as the Tasmanian Aboriginal centre proposed, already have land should not get more lands before other groups who have no land at all may be interfering with the government's desire that it actually use the majority or as much of the fund as is available to meet the existing management needs of indigenous held lands as well as the management needs of lands that might happen to be acquired in the first few years of the operation of this fund. Neither of those two reasons is adequate to leave at a blank. If the government does not agree with the guiding principle, it should state what its guiding principles are and put them on the table because it is not adequate to simply leave them out.
Amendment 3(g) agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—How does the committee wish to deal with the remainder of the amendments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am wondering whether it might be appropriate at this point to go back to the first part of these amendments and place before the chamber my amendment that was constructed in response to Senator Evans's concern that there might be some anomaly. I need to state here that I was not convinced by Senator Evans's argument but I believe that this amendment that has been circulated in my name sufficiently addresses it so that it leaves it out of the equation.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to discuss it in any great detail. I just indicate that the Greens supported the amendment that the opposition put up. If the chamber is willing to support our amendment to add on to the opposition's amendment, I am more than happy to go with that. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of Senator Campbell's substituted amendment No. 2, add the following amendment:

PARA.TAB: "(c)Clause 3, page 26, proposed subsection 193(5), line 21, omit `The Consolidated Revenue Fund', substitute `Except in respect of administrative expenses referred to in subsection (1), the Consolidated Revenue Fund'.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal by Senator Chamarette goes some way towards clarifying what was previously left in a wholly unsatisfactory technical fashion. The draftsmen, whose advice I have taken, are by no means persuaded that you have succeeded in doing that. The reasoning gets a bit complicated but it is linked with how you in fact read 193(1), which another part of your amendment amends by adding to the formula the expression `+$AE'.

PARA.TAB: Then it becomes a question of whether or not you have been successful in your amendment before the chamber now in, in effect, removing the `+$AE' from that formula for the purposes of the point you want to make or whether rather you are stuck with that formula because of the chapeau language of that subsection which refers to the amount worked out using the following formula and the key phrase there being the amount. It may be that you have not succeeded in doing anything other than perpetrating further confusion.

However, I think the intention of what you are trying to do is clear and it may conceivably be technically adequate for that purpose. I have to say that there are enormous reservations expressed in fairly robust terms to me by parliamentary counsel about the technical adequacy of other parts of the proposed amendment, but it is not my task to try to clean that up here. You have to have your own confidence in your own amendment if you are going to vote for it.

The short point I want to repeat is that, however successful you may or may not have been in cleaning up the technical problem to which I drew attention, you still have some other problems of a serious kind, as we see it anyway , with the clause. You have still inhibited obviously the ILC from using any of the land fund moneys for administrative purposes. It is stuck with, it is confined to, such other moneys as are appropriated for administrative expense purposes. That appropriation is manifestly not accomplished by this legislation; it has to be accomplished each year by a new exercise by the parliament in appropriating $3 million or $3 million plus for that purpose. So the first problem is that you are in the hands of a cooperative parliament if the organisation is not to be stymied from the outset.

Secondly, you have the further problem of the possibility for various reasons of overruns in administrative expenses in any year, which again throws the ILC back at the mercy of the parliament and government of the day for some extended supplementary appropriation to enable it to get through that particular year. In general, it does cut across completely the principle of administrative autonomy which has been the touchstone for all similar commercial corporations and it really is a pretty heavy-handed feat of paternalism to apply this constraint in the name of giving the ILC a new funding opportunity. What you are really doing is applying a new constraint of a paternalistic kind. So whatever the technical adequacy of what you are trying to do may or may not prove to be, for all those other reasons we oppose the clause as proposed now to be amended by Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I ask the minister a question? How is ATSIC funded at the moment?

—ATSIC is funded by an annual appropriation. That is perfectly true. What we are trying to do with this piece of legislation is to create a whole new regime for dispossessed Aboriginal people—to give them confidence about the viability of the land fund that will be built up over time and to enable them to have some confidence as they face their future, without the vagaries of annual appropriation regimes and all the political pressures, for and against, that work upon that. This whole legislation has been crafted to give them that degree of confidence that they are lacking at the moment. It is not a knockout blow.

—I missed the debate this morning because I was out of Parliament House, but I understand that Senator Evans raised the fact that this may, in some way, stymie self-determination. Certainly, ATSIC was a body proposed to create some self-determination, so I do not think that argument has a lot of merit. But the ultimate objective of this amendment, as Senator Evans knows, is to ensure that the funds brought down each year for the acquisition and management of land are used for that purpose and that they are not chewed up by administrative expenses.

PARA.TAB: I understand Senator Evans also said that, if they are tied up in litigation that runs into millions of dollars, that will cost the taxpayer more money. The reality is that, if that happened under the government's scheme and you had litigation worth $5 million, $6 million or $10 million in one year, the amount of money available for land acquisition or management would be reduced quite significantly in that particular year. That is what this amendment seeks to avoid. In relation to the committee's deliberations, I think the only witness that opposed the idea was ATSIC, but even—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which just happens to represent the entire Aboriginal population.

—ATSIC was one of the witnesses. There were 243 others, including Noel Pearson. In answer to what was probably a dorothy dixer from the chair of the committee, Noel Pearson said, `You'd be a mug not to agree to this.' Quite frankly, if the best argument you can create is that because parliament appropriates the money for administration, that interferes with the self-determination of the organisation, I think honourable senators would be mugs not to support this amendment.

—Could the minister outline to the committee what problems were experienced with the New South Wales legislation in respect of administration expenses? Why was it that successive governments felt the need to seek amendments to that legislation?
—I have no information about the New South Wales legislation. I am not sure of the problem to which Senator Harradine is referring. I have no immediate source of advice on that now.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—I now propose to put paragraph (2), as amended, to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a slight dilemma. Unfortunately, I was not able to race back to my seat quickly enough, but the parliamentary draftsman has proposed to us an alternative wording which we believe gets around the technical problems that have been raised in relation to the amount.
—Can you share that wording with us?
—Yes, certainly. It is not going to make very much difference to the outcome.
—Perhaps you could clarify which parts of the motion your proposed amendments relate to.
—I would very much like to, but Senator Evans now has my copy.

—If you think these proposed amendments are going to improve it technically and you have Senator Chamarette's support for them, go for your life. We are not going to accept them now, and we are not going to accept them in the House of Representatives.
—It is the principle that has not been accepted.

—You have established your principle. There will be some further opportunity in the context of this or some other bill to have another go at this. You have made your point. Frankly, I think this suffers from the same problems from which the initial drafting of (b), (c), (d) and (e) suffered. Two amounts are referred to, one of which is being appropriated indirectly through the medium of a draw down from the land fund, which is the subject of extraction from consolidated revenue. In the same clause, you have reference to an appropriation directly from consolidated revenue. The language of the drafting may not be sufficient to reflect that distinction. I draw that to your attention, but this is not the final word we are going to have on this. I am sure the two of you will cheerfully embrace this language, and you are welcome to it.
—Could I ask the proposer of the foreshadowed amendments whether they are simply intended to reflect the changes that we have already made to clause 3, page 26?
—They are intended to do that. The intention is clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —They seek to overcome the problem. Senator Evans says they possibly do not. I think Senator Evans is right: this matter will probably be revisited. Therefore, I seek leave to substitute the following amendments for the previous ones.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (b)For previous amendment No. 53, substitute:

Clause 3, page 26, proposed subsection 193A(1), line 27, omit "$25 million", substitute "$28 million and such additional monies as are appropriated by the Parliament from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for administrative expenses".
(c)For previous amendment No. 54, substitute:

TALK.START.PARA: —Having looked at the amendments, they do seem to me to be simply technical amendments to ensure that there is no conflict with what we have already adopted. Given the fact that we will probably revisit this, I am prepared to support them.
