Resolution reported; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to make a couple of points. The first point is in relation to something that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said yesterday in the House of Representatives and something I think Senator Kernot and others have said in relation to what I am supposed to have said on public radio; that is, about the coalition supposing to have done a backflip on this legislation.

PARA.TAB: On the day the committee report was tabled, I did canvass what will happen to the bill, subject to how the government responds to it. I made it clear that there are two or three alternatives. One is that the amendments be insisted upon when returned from the House of Representatives, which is something I expect would and will happen. The second is that, ultimately, if these amendments to the legislation were never made, the only hope those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people would have of achieving control of their own land, in the terms of the amendments moved by the coalition and supported by the Senate, would be, indeed, with the election of a Liberal or coalition government at the next election.

We feel quite strongly that the outstanding issues do come down to whether or not a bureaucracy has or individual communities have ultimate control of the land that is granted. I take this opportunity to describe why that is so important to us and why some of the government's objections, as put by Senator Gareth Evans here and by the Prime Minister in the other place, really are not matters that should be of overwhelming concern, nor should stop the passage of this bill, as amended, into legislation.

I turn to the amendments that were tabled by the Prime Minister in the other place yesterday, specifically being the amendments that are now the matter of disagreement between the two houses of parliament, The first one is so-called amendment No. 3, which has now been agreed through the processes of the Senate this morning. That related to trying to find out if native title existed before land was purchased. That has now, through some horse-trading on the floor of the Senate, been agreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a totally different form.

—In a different form. But ostensibly it achieves what the coalition set out to achieve in the first instance, even though the government and the Senate have found a set of words that is more precise in ensuring what the ILC would have to do prior to purchasing land—and that is a very sensible outcome.

PARA.TAB: Amendments 4 and 5, of course, just a few minutes ago were modified by the Senate to remove the contentious words `most severely dispossessed' and replace them with a principle that is broadly supported by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia, although with the exception of some people in ATSIC here in Canberra. That has just been debated and I will not re-enter it.

The next amendments, Nos 6 to 17 and other ones, relate to the provision in the bill that says that only corporations should hold the land. That is something that received widespread support and, again, as said in the committee's report, should not overly concern the government. The coalition and the senators who supported the amendment believe that to prescribe that only corporations should hold the land is unnecessarily proscriptive and rules out a whole range of other legal entities that could emerge for Aboriginal land ownership.

We heard much evidence in the committee hearings that the corporate structure, although it is culturally relevant in some cases, is entirely culturally irrelevant in others—and the Torres Strait Islander people were one particular example. But there is a range of other Aboriginal people who will continue to be dispossessed because of the wording of the clause in the original bill without amendment. It does not mean that the ILC is forced to grant land to other legal entities; it just means that it has the flexibility to say that there is a whole range of other legal entities that could be granted land. That, I think, is desirable. It actually increases the flexibility of the ILC and meets the government's own principles in relation to that.

Effectively, all that amendment No. 25 does—that is the so-called health, housing and education amendment—is to broaden the things that the ILC should take into account when granting land. We should read very carefully the transcript of the Prime Minister's speech to Hopevale last Friday on what was, until he got there, a secret visit—because I spoke to a few people in Hopevale on the morning the Prime Minister was arriving there, and most of them did not even know he was coming. But let us not be too political about that because at Hopevale, the Prime Minister—if we can get through all the waffly aspects of his speech—indeed, gave true recognition to the fact that health, housing and education are important consequences of assisting Aboriginal people to buy land.

I do not think the government has ever contested that. It says that there should be some sort of strict delineation, and that this bill should only talk about land and not about other things. But, of course, the bill does talk about other things; it talks about cultural, environmental and other benefits that can flow from owning land. If we want a most—I will not say `articulate' because that is not fair to other people—thorough support for the position that health benefits can flow from the ownership of land, then I recommend to the people of Australia a reading of the transcript of Mr Keating's speech in Hopevale. He very effectively links health with ownership of land in, I think, the same way that Senator Lees referred to spirit sickness and the fact that, when people are alienated and cut off from traditional lands and their source of cultural, spiritual and traditional enrichment, their health can suffer—and the coalition recognises that.

This amendment does nothing more or less than that. As Senator Ellison described earlier in the committee stage of this debate, it certainly just asks the ILC to bear these things in mind when making its grants. It is not proscriptive, it is very flexible and it does nothing to fetter the ILC's operations.

I feel that the sorry part of the debate on this particular amendment is that it has been politicised—and possibly from both sides; it has become a bit of a political bellwether in this whole debate. But really, if we look at the guts and effect of the amendment, it should be seen as something that we should not waste too much time arguing over because it is a broad statement that most people agree with, and it certainly has no restricting effects.

Amendment 27, dealing with the ILC not to retain interest in lands after they are granted, again is something that I just simply cannot see as objectionable and I cannot see why the government is so adamant about opposing. I then move to amendment No. 32, which is the disposal of the land. The government, I think quite sensibly, links this with amendments 6 to 17 in relation to corporations being the only bodies that can hold land.

I think it was Senator Collins in the debate here last year who said that, under our provisions, an individual could be given land one day and could go out and sell it the next. This has created the illusion that these two sets of amendments together create some sort of structure that is going to see various Flash Harrys get granted land and then dispose of it the next day for personal profit.

The cold hard reality is that the ILC will make the decisions about who it grants the land to. It will decide whether to grant it to a corporation, to a trust or to some other legal structure. The effect of our amendment is to ensure that the people who are granted the land have some ultimate control over what happens to that land. That is the thrust of all of our amendments. The government says that amendment 32 will allow the land to be sold frivolously and for individual profit, but that is not what is intended, nor what would happen in reality.

Ultimately—and we were given evidence all around Australia to this effect—in some circumstances land should be able to be sold readily so that the communities can take advantage of other opportunities that might present themselves. On the other hand, many Aboriginals said, `We do need to protect land that has cultural or traditional significance to us.' Amendment 32 does nothing to stop that from happening. All it does is put the control over that decision making into the hands of the Aboriginal landholders, into the hands of the community and into the hands of Aboriginal people, as opposed to being in the hands of a Canberra bureaucracy.

If the landholders want to ensure the land is not sold without ILC permission, that can be achieved by way of a caveat on the title. Again, it would be a decision made by the Aboriginals themselves. It puts the control into their hands. If they want to ensure that that land is never sold without ILC approval, then that is something that they can determine for themselves. We think that is preferable to allowing the ILC to have ultimate control over the land in all circumstances.

I think the idea of placing trust and responsibility in the hands of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander landholders is very important. We would genuinely and sincerely ask the government to revisit the effects of both amendments 6 and 17 and subsequent amendments relating to allowing only corporations to own land, and we would ask it to revisit the effect of amendment 32, which gives the power to determine what happens to that land to the individuals, the corporations and the communities—the Aboriginal people—as opposed to a bureaucracy here in Canberra.

I certainly do not believe that you create self-determination by giving self-determination to a new bureaucracy and giving it that independence. Ultimately, self-determination is about empowering the Aboriginal people, their organisations and their communities. Without amendment 32, you do not do that. You give self-determination to a bureaucracy, and giving self-determination to a bureaucracy is very different from giving self-determination to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia.

Again, I cannot see how the government can oppose amendments 33 and 35. I can see that it may strongly want the ATSIC chairperson, or that person who holds that office from time to time, to be on the board. But my understanding of amendment 33, which was passed last year, was that it does not preclude that person from being on the board; it just says that they should not be on that board as of right. Equally, I cannot see how the government can possibly oppose an amendment that states that the board should be broadly representative of the Aboriginal communities.

In fact, one thing that arose from the evidence to our committee—and the evidence was absolutely overwhelming—was that there was this distrust by Aboriginal communities right throughout the country that they were not being properly represented by bodies such as ATSIC. That was not entirely surprising. It is not a criticism of ATSIC; it is a classical problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that we adequately represent white Australians?

—I was actually going to say the same thing, Senator Kernot. Senator Cooney made the point very well when he spoke to the tabling of the committee report that, whenever you seek to set up some sort of democratic structure, there will be those who feel that they are not being represented by it. I am sure there are millions of Australians out there who do not believe that everything that happens here in Canberra, even with our very best intentions, is in their best interests. That is all I am saying. I am not surprised at that evidence. I am not personally criticising ATSIC on that aspect, nor have I.

PARA.TAB: The point I am making is that, overwhelmingly, the people who gave evidence to the committee said, `We want an elected board; we want to be represented by the board; and we want it to be broadly representative.' People who have read the report will note that we proposed a better alternative structure. The committee proposed an indigenous land council which would be a body broadly representative of Aboriginal people and that the board itself would be the more day-to-day executive of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

I note that a number of the government's advisers who travelled around Australia with us are here in the Senate today. I hope that they will have told the minister and the Prime Minister about the overwhelming feeling of those who gave evidence, and that we have proposed a structure. It was obviously a matter which was too hard for us to deal with through this process, but there was an overwhelming feeling from the witnesses, and it was represented in this report.

I know that Senator Kernot particularly was not very happy with the process. She has a massive gripe with the way the Senate select committee undertook its operations. I am not going to respond to her because I was personally and deeply offended, but she is entitled to her view. I think that, if she carefully read the transcripts and looked at the way we went about our operations and if she spoke to some of the witnesses who came forward to us and warmly received what our committee was doing and commended us for the way we did it, she might perhaps recant from the views she has expressed. I will say no more about that.

This was something that was so strongly supported that I cannot see how the government can continue to oppose it. With the national and regional strategies, even those who came along to the committee and put the ATSIC position almost pro forma, when asked by people like my colleague Senator Ellison whether they thought that the regional strategy should be the foundation stone of the board's operations, the ILC's operations, and whether they agreed that the national strategy should come after and reflect what happens in the regions, overwhelmingly supported those propositions.

I cannot ever see how the government could oppose it, especially when we bear in mind that Senator Gareth Evans came across here with a proposed amendment which says, `Let's wipe out the national strategy altogether; let's not have one.' I just wonder why the strategies should not reflect the regional strategies. It makes a lot of sense to the people out there. Clearly, that commonsense does not prevail here.

Amendment 63, which provides for extra information to be put into the annual report, is something that I would expect the government to see as fairly incidental, but it is something that is hard to argue against. One other amendment is the important one that says that the ILC should be required to consult with traditional owners, as they were originally called. We were convinced by the evidence that that should be changed to those people with historic and traditional links to the land. Again, that was something that was just so strongly regarded as crucial to the sensible operations of the ILC that there was virtually no opposition to that idea.

Indeed, many of the witnesses to the committee said that, if you do not have that sort of consultation, then you will create a conflict and potential violence, as in the recent case—I think it was the day before our hearings in Adelaide—in Marree where there have been disputes between competing claims. Even the government said that it would attend to that as a matter of course and it should not be prescribed in the bill. That was something that was so overwhelmingly regarded as crucial to the proper operations of the ILC that it should be prescribed.

The government's own record on consultation on this very legislation has created mistrust in many Aboriginal groups. The government may say it does not respect the fact that we spoke to something like 244 witnesses and that it does not respect the views of all of those people, but the reality is that there is mistrust out there. There is a feeling that Aboriginal people are not listened to, that they are not spoken to, that they are not consulted with and that they are not part of the process. Again, that is not something that is surprising to us. There are probably lots of people out there who feel that they are very remote from the processes of this parliament. Aboriginal people are probably not orphans when it comes to feeling remote from the processes of government in Australia—be it state, federal or even local.

Aboriginal people believe that it should be prescribed in the bill that people with traditional and historic links be consulted. They do not trust us. They do not trust the government. They do not trust the ILC when it says that it would do this anyway but do not tell it to do it. When we say to Aboriginal people that we are from Canberra and that we are there to help them, they do not really take that very seriously.

I believe that all of the outstanding disputes between the two houses of parliament, as reflected in the government's second bringing of the bill into the House of Representatives, are matters that need not be fundamentally disagreed to in the two sides of this argument. They are not so fundamental that they cannot be discussed, negotiated and agreed to in the way that matters like amendment No. 3 have been agreed to. That was agreed to on the floor of the Senate today. We have come a hell of a long way through this process to get virtual total agreement.

I guess the main outstanding issues are the principles in amendments Nos 4 and 5 as amended—the fact that corporations are allowed to be granted land under only the government's unamended bill, the disposal of the land and the consultation with people with historic links. These are things that I believe are extremely workable. I do not believe the government's arguments that they are unworkable. I believe that ownership of the land can be protected where it needs to be protected by the amendments to the bill. It is fundamentally wrong to restrict to corporations land-holdings by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Many people out there do not want corporations to be the legal entity by which they hold their land.

The government would be dispossessing those people. It is saying that it will not give them land unless they are a corporation. The government would be continuing the dispossession by doing that. It is discriminatory; it is wrong. I cannot see why the government has such an enormous problem with this. If there were a spirit of cooperation, these things could be solved. I certainly hope that that spirit of cooperation will emerge over the next few days or weeks.

Forcing people to own land as corporations because we believe corporations create some sort of higher accountability is patently incorrect. In recent years we have seen in normal public companies that accountability cannot be obtained—even with the most onerous black-letter law. As we have seen with the Australian Corporations Law, we cannot legislate for accountability. Corporations have not necessarily been successful under the Corporations Act or the previous state corporate codes. Of course, in the case of many Aboriginal corporations again accountability has not been achieved just because there has been a corporate structure.

Ultimately, the problem of accountability can be solved by ensuring that those who hold land are accountable to themselves, their brothers, their sisters and their communities by putting responsibility into their hands. That ultimately will be what solves those sorts of problems that have been raised.

I conclude by commending that this bill be read a third time. The coalition has come a long way on the land fund bill from when it first heard about it. The coalition has moved from being very dubious about the land fund bill to embracing it as a concept and to supporting, as we are about to do, the third reading of this amended bill. I genuinely encourage the government to look very carefully at where there may be agreement on some of the outstanding issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is not at all surprised that the opposition should now have moved to a stance of supporting the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill on its third reading because the bill we have before us is a very different bill from that with which we began. It is a bill which is now, as a result of the process we have been through—after some 31 hours of debate, 26 of them in committee—in our judgment fundamentally flawed in a way that simply does not justify or could not countenance the government supporting it.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that I am a little puzzled by Senator Campbell's speech. I have known for a long time that there are two Senator Evanses in this chamber—me and Chris Evans. I have known for some time that there are two Senator Macdonalds—Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator Ian Macdonald. I did not know until a few minutes ago that we have two Senator Campbells. We have the Senator Campbell who went public on 9 February and said all sorts of things like `when push comes to shove the opposition will accept'—with such graces it can muster—`the government's bill' and `leave it until such time as we are—

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I get a copy of that transcript?

—I do not have the transcript; I am freely translating. He said, `Leave it until such time as we are in government and we will fix up the defects that exist.' I thought a copy of the transcript had been passed to me, but it turns out to be Mr Tickner's release. However, he does use quotation marks and he is a very reliable witness. Mr Tickner has recorded Senator Campbell as saying that the reality is that, with an election coming up in a year's time, forcing the hand on the coalition's proposed amendments probably does not achieve much. Senator Campbell basically said that the opposition would leave these things to be fixed up when and if it gets the opportunity to do so when it is in government.

PARA.TAB: Then today Senator Cambell, after making a gesture of a marginally conciliatory kind by saying that maybe there could be a process of further negotiation—this was, mind you, after 26 hours of committee debate and 31 hours altogether—said we could find some way of bridging this divide after he had just spent 25 minutes explaining in elaborate detail how wide it was. The truth of the matter is that there is a very wide divide now between the opposition and its soul mates in this enterprise, the Greens—it will be fascinating to see how they vote on this occasion—and the government on the worth and the workability of this bill.

When I spoke last by way of wrap-up in this debate back on 16 November, I identified what I described as the seven deadly sins in this legislation—seven factors about the bill, as a result of the opposition and Green amendments, which make the bill indefensible in principle, unworkable in practice or both. As a result of the further four hours of debate we have had today, a couple of those concerns have been marginally ameliorated but not to the extent of removing the sin in question from that particular description. They do remain sins because for one reason or another they create a bill that is indefensible in principle, unworkable in practice or both. Let me quickly indicate again those major concerns, which are points of absolutely no return so far as the government is concerned.

Sin No. 1 is the requirement that the ILC give priority now to those who suffer most disadvantage. True it is that is a little bit better than the previous reference to `most dispossessed' from one point of view. But, as I pointed out at great length in the earlier debate—I will not repeat it now—that is likely to cause very significant conflict in the indigenous community as to who satisfies this description. It opens up the ILC to legal challenge about who actually satisfies these criteria. It is administratively a nightmare in terms of the demands that it will create for some kind of calibration of competing claims.

Sin No. 2—and it is one that has not been addressed in any way, shape or form by the opposition or the process it is so proud of, the committee—is the reference to grants to individuals and trustees being possible. That is absolutely wrong in principle as far as we are concerned and as far as, we believe, the majority of Aboriginal people in this country are concerned. It is contrary to the whole aim of the land fund, which is to provide communal benefits. It is contrary to traditional indigenous land holding practices. It has the incidental operational disadvantage of reducing accountability; but the basic problem is the one of principle.

The third sin is the requirement that grants of land have regard to health, housing and so on. That is contrary, as we have said, in principle to the purpose of the land fund, which is to provide land as a basis for the wellbeing of indigenous people. It is not intended to address what are absolutely legitimate but quite distinct objectives of other programs—other programs which are not the responsibility of the ILC. Requiring the ILC to have regard to the implications of these sorts of factors—health, housing, education and so on—when it is making grants of land is again, we believe, to make this particular proposal very difficult to apply in practice and to open up, again, the administration of the corporation to challenge and to many practical difficulties.

The fourth deadly sin is the requirement—altered to some extent today, but not in such a way as to get rid of the basic problem—for the ILC to consult, before acquiring land, those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having traditional links or historic links to the land in question. On the face of it, it is not a unreasonable aspiration, but one that in practice will, we believe, simply be quite unworkable—leading to conflict as to who precisely satisfies the description, certainly generating extensive delays while people are identified and consulted, and certainly creating not only the possibility of inhibitions on the ILC's capacity to operate effectively commercially, but also exposure to litigation and all sorts of practical difficulties to the point of making the corporation, with this provision alone, quite unworkable.

The fifth sin goes to the business about administrative expenses. It is not a cap in quite the same direct terms that was originally proposed. It is a different sort of provision requiring a separate appropriation at what will, in effect, year by year, be a capped level for administrative expenses. We believe that is offensive in principle to the extent that it imposes an unprecedented paternalistic restriction on a statutory authority. We ought to have confidence in the boards to do what we appoint them to do and it will create—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is how you fund ATSIC at the moment.

—No, ATSIC is not restricted in the amount that it can spend for administrative purposes. That is another furphy you were determined to promote earlier on by implication and it is one that needs to be directly replied to, as I now do. ATSIC is the subject of an annual appropriation, but it is not the subject of any restriction—direct or indirect—on what part of that appropriation it can apply to administrative expenses. That reflects the reality that there does need to be flexibility if any operation is to be workable in practice. You have the further problem of being a prisoner of annual appropriations by the parliament and top-up appropriations in the event that unforseen—albeit perhaps perfectly defensible—additional expenditure is required to be made.

PARA.TAB: Sin No. 6—and it is an important one again, a deadly one—is the removal of the ILC power to control effectively the disposal of land. That is absolutely indefensible in principle because it would lead dramatically and, we believe, inexorably to the diminution of the indigenous land base, the erosion of the land base which is the whole purpose of this legislation to create. There are some gigantic accountability problems associated here with expenditure of public moneys. You are talking about potentially making very large sums of public money available simply to support private individual acquisitions of land which can then be freely traded, and utterly miss the point, which is to create a new permanent land base for Aboriginal people to be enjoyed on a communal title basis.

The seventh sin goes to the whole group of proposals relating to regional strategies and, to some marginal extent, the national strategies provision. The sin here involves not so much any problem of principle but an operational problem: a massive increase in the complexity that will be necessarily involved in the formulation of these strategies, opening up yet more avenues for legal challenges to ILC decisions and, in that context again, making the ILC, we believe, unworkable, and reducing the possibility of the capacity of the ILC to take advantage of commercial opportunities to purchase land as they arise—just generally being another whole layer of unacceptable inhibitions.

So they are the seven deadly sins. In addition to that there are several what I might describe as venial sins, if Senator Harradine will forgive me for this foray into what has previously been his domain in this chamber. I would describe venial sin No. 1 as that going to the requirement for the ATSIC chairperson identified by official designation to be removed. That requirement, which is there in the original bill, for the ATSIC person to be there would no longer be there and there would be only one ATSIC commissioner on the board rather than two.

Since ATSIC is overwhelmingly the representative body for Aboriginal people in this country, it is quite inappropriate, in our judgment—particularly given the role that ATSIC has been playing in this whole area of land acquisition and vesting in Aboriginal people and the overlap period of five years that lies ahead—for ATSIC to be treated in this way. That reflects merely a political agenda rather than a legitimate practical one so far as the opposition is concerned. Senator Campbell has made perfectly clear what he thinks about ATSIC on multiple occasions. We will not get into that debate now, but he is not its biggest fan. I think he cheerfully acknowledges that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I don't.

—You have become a statesman in your old age after all. Amendment 27, I think, constitutes what I describe as the second venial sin, and that is the business about the ILC pursuing a policy of not retaining any interest in a parcel of land which it has granted. I perhaps should say a word about this, because we have not addressed this is in the course of these current debates. It is certainly the general intention that the ILC would not, at the time of granting land, retain an interest by granting some lesser interest such as a lease where the ILC has acquired a full interest.

PARA.TAB: However, it was always the government's intention that it should be possible for the ILC to later take out an interest in land that it had granted in order to assist land holders to manage their land. For example, it might retain a leasehold interest in return for managing the land on behalf of the owners. There might be other commercial situations of that kind. It is not a major inhibition on the operation of the ILC. It is in the realm of the venial rather than the mortal; nonetheless, it is an inhibition on the effective operation.

Finally, there is amendment 63, which I described as venial sin No. 3, which goes to the ILC annual report. The bill already requires detailed information on the operations of the land fund to be provided to parliament. This really is a provision which would enable the parliament, or some opposition so minded that happened to have a working majority in one house, to impose obligations upon the land fund and the ILC which are really beyond that which is necessary to ensure full accountability. We made these points in the course of the general debate and made all of them, at one point or another, at much greater length than I have done in this third reading reply.

I make the point that all of these sins together make up a bill which, in its present form, simply cannot now be supported by the government. I repeat: we are determined to get a workable bill that is defensible in principle into place as soon as we possibly can. We are not playing games in order to use this bill to pursue other political objectives. We want a bill that works. We want a bill that is effective. We want a bill that is defensible, I repeat, in principle. We have not got such a bill at the moment. If the Senate nonetheless is minded to give it a third reading, the government will obviously act accordingly in its further consideration of it—beginning with, I have no doubt, a rejection in the House of Representatives of all the amendments to which I have referred today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have indicated all along our rejection of this fund because the amount is totally inadequate. We sought to bring in another two amendments, apart from that which sought to increase the amount of the land fund, which we believe were very important to Aboriginal people. The first amendment allowed the capacity for native title equivalent to be brought to bear on any land that was acquired by the land fund. The second amendment, which was the concern of many people, required that the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill expressly state that it was not constituting compensation and would not disqualify Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islander people from pursuing any compensation claims that they held.

PARA.TAB: Despite the fact that we do not support this fund and totally reject the inadequacy of it, we have continued our attempts to improve the bill in the direction of concerns addressed by many Aboriginal groups around Australia. Those groups indicated through submissions, contact with us or contributions to the committee which travelled around the country that this government designed and apparently ATSIC approved bill did not reflect their needs and aspirations.

We believe that the Senate has arrived at an amended bill which is far superior in its response to those concerns than the original bill proposed by the government. We would like to support the bill in some ways. We certainly prefer it to the original unamended bill, but it falls far too short of what we consider to be the minimal requirements. The bill does allow greater self-determination to Aboriginal communities and greater flexibility in their holding and managing of land. It is more explicitly respectful of traditional and historical links with land and the different kinds of disadvantages experienced by all Aboriginal people as the result of white occupation of their land.

However, if this bill is passed, it will bind Aboriginal people to a pittance of the land fund not just for the 10 years for which it is set up but forever. It may keep the government off the hook in respect of its human rights obligations to the original owners of Australia and it may give the appearance to the international community that justice has been done, but make no mistake: justice will not be able to be done and the government's moral obligations and also those of this parliament will continue into the future.

The Greens cannot support the bill, but we do not feel totally comfortable about that. We are opposing the third reading stage of the amended bill for two reasons. Firstly, out of the lesser of the two evils—the two evils being this amended bill or the government's legislation as reintroduced and as originally devised—the amended bill wins. Secondly, while it is by no means what we support, we do not necessarily want to deny those few people who will gain from the $21 million a year more which is being allocated to the land fund.

We will not be supporting this bill and thus the government has the opportunity to indicate whether it is prepared to respond to the requirements of parliamentary democracy and to hear the voices of all the Aboriginal people who have felt excluded not only by the government's consultation process in determining the bill but also by the government's refusal to tolerate any amendments presented in the Senate which reflect their concerns.

It is apparent from the extraordinary action of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the House of Representatives yesterday in pre-empting Senate process by presenting the land fund bill for a second time that the government is stubbornly persisting not only in its disregard of the democratic process of the Senate but also, and worst still, in using the highly questionable political prod of the double dissolution threat to try to force its way through.

If the Greens voted against this bill now, we would be assisting the government in proving its highly dubious case. We would be sharing its highly dubious role in this place. We will therefore place on the public record that the Greens will be abstaining from this third reading vote in order to leave the failure of this bill in the hands of the government and those who agree with that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me put on the record the fact that the Democrats want to have the opportunity to vote to establish a land fund for Aboriginal people. Let me also put on the record that, in the course of our 30 hours of debate, some quite reasonable amendments have been made. But I also think some totally unacceptable amendments have been made. Unfortunately, it is the matters of big principle, in my view, which fall into the unacceptable category.

PARA.TAB: Let us remember that the purpose of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill is to set up a structure to facilitate the acquisition of land and its maintenance for indigenous people who do not benefit from native title. Let us leave aside the comments about whether or not the amount of money is adequate. Most of us believe that, in terms of addressing the huge need that is out there, it is not an adequate amount. The Democrats cannot vote for the bill in its amended form, but it is not over whether ATSIC has one or two commissioners on the board or over the renaming of the title of the bill or over the place and function of regional strategies. We cannot vote for this bill due to our strongly held views on three key principles. I do not need to go to the seven so-called deadly sins. There are three really clear areas for the Democrats.

The first area is the attaching of conditions such as those relating to health, housing and education to acquisition and maintenance of land. We feel very strongly that this conflicts with the fundamental notion of citizenship rights. We should not be attaching or qualifying purchase or acquisition of land in any way, in my view.

The second area on which we disagree seriously is, I suppose, the cumulative effect of a couple of amendments which we believe have the serious potential to erode the very purpose of the bill, to erode a land base. Those two amendments are the grants to individuals and their right to dispose of the land. We can point to an example in Alaska, I think—certainly in North America—where at the end of a certain number of years no land was left and the whole purpose of the legislation was defeated.

The third area is the way in which the coalition and the Greens have sought to have the land corporation give priority to the most disadvantaged. I agree that that sounds fine in practice, but I feel strongly that it is similarly incapable of objective assessment, as was the former version of priority to the most severely dispossessed.

I do not think it is a clear-cut matter of what constitutes self-determination and what does not. I think it is more difficult than that. But to me it comes down to a matter of collective rights to communal benefits to be held in perpetuity over the individual right to acquire and dispose of land.

I acknowledge Senator Campbell's comment that the opposition has come a long way in this debate. That is certainly true. He entreated us to consider the points of principle the opposition spent so much time debating. He expressed the hope that in the next couple of weeks we might come to a different consensus. I put a similar challenge to him: he should re-examine some of the arguments that the government and the Democrats individually are raising in this debate.

Perhaps Senator Campbell is of the view that the bill the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday, which incorporates 27 of the Senate's amendments, provides a better balance between the views of Aboriginal people represented by peak bodies and those who are not. But it seems to me that no land fund bill will adequately represent and satisfy the views of all Aboriginal people or all of us here in this chamber.

I guess the final consideration that has guided the Democrats is that we cannot agree it is better to have nothing than to have this land fund in this form as amended by the amendments incorporated in the House of Representatives bill which was introduced yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say that you can agree or cannot?

—I cannot agree with the view that it is better to have no land fund than to have the government's original model. That is why, given those three basic points—the citizenship rights; the potential for the erosion of the land base; and the priority to the most disadvantaged, and the way in which I feel that that is equally incapable of objective assessment—the Democrats cannot support this amended bill.

—That creates an interesting situation. I am disappointed to note that the Australian Democrats will not support the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994, even though it does not satisfy some of the major points that they feel strongly about.
—It works against them.

—Yes. In Senator Kernot's view, it works against them. Even so, this piece of legislation has been introduced by the government in the House of Representatives. It was debated in the House of Representatives and came here. It has been said that it was debated over a number of hours in this chamber.
—Thirty-one.

—It was debated for 31 hours in the chamber. Senator Kernot, Senator Chamarette, Senator Chris Ellison, Senator Ian Campbell, Senator Gareth Evans and a number of others have sat here through almost all of those hours. They have debated, listened and responded on a number of occasions with suggestions, even as late as today, to try to improve the legislation.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the Senate discussed and debated the proposition of sending it to a committee, which it did. That committee expended many hours and days of work in going around Australia and trying to gain the viewpoints of Australians of both Aboriginal descent and otherwise. It came up with a report, as a result of which there have been some amendments to the amendments that were moved and adopted in this chamber.
I ask the Senate: is all of this going to waste? Is all this effort going to be to no avail? I thought that we are supposed to examine and review government legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are supposed to improve it, not destroy it.
—We are not destroying it. We have attempted, firstly, to review it and, secondly, to improve it.
—You have failed.

—Senator Gareth Evans may not think we have improved it. He may think that we have committed seven sins. Senator Evans, we are all sinners. We do not have it on our own, because at times the government is also guilty of transgression. We have not, because what we have done we have done with the best will in the world. We have done it in good conscience in an attempt to improve the legislation for those people for whom it is meant to benefit.

PARA.TAB: One thing that worries me about this whole situation, particularly the one that has developed in the last two days, is that it has become highly political. That is the last thing I thought we needed when dealing with this question concerning Aboriginal people. After all, the constitution was changed by an overwhelming vote to give certain powers to this parliament and to recognise the position of Aboriginal people.

There was the landmark High Court decision in respect of Mabo. People like me, who have had a long history of understanding and support for Aboriginal aspirations, were very pleased with that landmark event. I remind the Senate that, when we came here, one of the first things we did was adopt a resolution in support of Aboriginal people. On that occasion, I quoted Miriam-Rose Ungunmerr-Baurman, an Aboriginal artist in the Daly River, as saying that the period of grieving must give way to a future of joy and inspiration, the period of despair must give way to a future of vital action and the period of grim endurance must turn into a period of vigorous growth. I thought we should be doing just that: setting the stage for vigorous growth.

One of the saddest reflections of where we are at this time in our society is that the number of Aboriginals employed in Australia is lower now than the number employed in the Great Depression. Admittedly, some who were employed in the Great Depression were employed in slave labour situations, which I am not advocating. However, one thing that will empower Aboriginal people is gaining creative employment. One thing I thought would come out of this ILC is the provision of moneys for the acquisition and management of land that would enable the further employment of Aboriginals in a situation where they would have dignity and control.

I am very disappointed—I cannot say that the situation is hopeless—with the sorts of attitudes that are now developing. The best thing for the Senate to do is to adopt the resolution, adopt the third reading and send the legislation back to the House of Representatives. It is noteworthy that fewer people were in the House of Representatives during the committee stage debate—and they had a very poor and short committee stage debate—than were here in the Senate. From time to time a number of honourable senators have come into the chamber. As we know, we have all got other things running concurrently. At present I should be at a meeting of another committee but this, in my view, has taken precedence.

I would suggest through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Senator Evans listen to what Senator Campbell says. Senator Campbell seems to have come a good way on this. Maybe I have got him wrong, but from what he has stated—and there is some difference about that—the opposition has come a long way on this matter. The government is taking a bureaucratic led attitude which I do not think is appropriate in these circumstances. I feel that we should adopt this legislation having regard to what the opposition has said—that if there is any way that the remaining areas of difficulty can be resolved then let us see it. But do not just use this as a political football, as I believe it has turned into, because of the circumstances of yesterday—introducing another bill into the parliament when we have given the government's bill our due consideration and when we have spent hours doing it. I am not prepared to vote against the third reading.

There are some things that I have been considering as a result of what has been said in this chamber even today. One or two matters might need some alteration and are the sticking points at this point of time, but I am certainly not prepared to vote against the third reading. I am prepared to vote for the third reading in the hope that the legislation will be given proper consideration by the House of Representatives under the benign guidance of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up the point Senator Harradine has made in that the correct legislative procedure both of this place and the other place is that this bill should go back to the other place and be considered there. There is absolutely no call for the introduction of this land fund bill mark 2 which we hear about in the other place. I do not believe there is any precedent for such a move. I believe that the process up here has been correct and entirely proper. Senator Harradine asked: has everything we have done in relation to this matter counted for nothing? I do not believe it has and I think history will judge in hindsight that the events which have taken place have been quite proper and in the interests of good management of legislation and representation of the interests of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country.

PARA.TAB: No-one can doubt that the debate which took place in this chamber last year on this matter was lengthy. No-one can refute the fact that the Senate committee engaged in extensive consultation. Is there any reason why it should not have? Is there any reason why the committee should not have travelled around the country and taken the views of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people? There is absolutely no reason why it should not have done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was purely a delaying mechanism, and you know it.

—It was only through that that we have one of the most comprehensive committee reports given to this Senate in relation to matters touching on the affairs of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islander people. It was from that that we changed some of our amendments and said yes, we were wrong on the most severely dispossessed and yes, we were wrong in one or two other aspects about the way we looked at things. Traditional ownership was not a way to look at it; it was looking at the historical and traditional links of people. We did change our minds. We went to that inquiry with open minds and we reacted on the evidence that we heard, unlike some other people, who said that was a cynical exercise in trying to prolong matters. It was the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who said in the other place, `In all the circumstances, with the Senate declining to deal further with the amendments and with the request rejected and returned to it from the House of Representatives, the government considers there has been a failure to pass the bill.' If that is not a political point, I am a Dutchman.
—Racial hatred!

—You can call me Rip Van Winkle. What the Prime Minister was saying there was: we will treat this as a trigger. He was the one who was introducing this—not us, not the coalition. We went into the reference to the committee on the basis that Senator Evans considered it a trigger because it was a failure to pass. But that did not scare us off. The double dissolution was not a question that exercised our minds on this point. What did exercise our minds was the flagrant lack of consultation, which was the case and you know that.
—Rubbish. You're re-inventing history. There was a massive amount of consultation, and you know it.

—Yes, I have heard the Prime Minister say that. I missed one day's hearing, and that was in Launceston; I was on the rest. Unless I am deaf, dumb and blind, by far the majority of witnesses said they had not been consulted. If you think that you had wide consultation on this, then I am afraid you have been on a different planet. There was before this committee repeated evidence as to lack of consultation. When you are dealing with a discrete group of a community which is disadvantaged, as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are, then you make extra effort to consult with them. That was just not the case.

PARA.TAB: Two letters were written to people in Darwin, as I recall. One was to the Northern Land Council and one was to the Chief Minister. That was incredible. They were the two letters of consultation that were written to Darwin—the whole city of Darwin, which has a large Aboriginal population, not only in the city itself but in the region it serves. That was what we found in this committee. There was no question of prolonging it. It was dealt with expeditiously. This committee reported, I think, only two days later than the day it was ordered to report. We sat for two solid weeks over the Christmas break and one day prior to Christmas. That is not the action of someone who is procrastinating. It did not prejudice in any way the government or the people whom this legislation is intended to benefit. In fact, it gave them an opportunity to say something, so much so that 244 witnesses were given a chance to say something and place it on the record for history so they could make their mark towards how this bill should be framed.

So I say to the government: if you were dinkum you would scrap the other bill, have a look at this bill in the other place and then resubmit it to the Senate accordingly, but not usurp the normal process and introduce an identical bill in the other place. There is no call for that. That is a trick, a political move to try to visit upon the coalition some pressure just because of this double dissolution aspect. It will not wash with us.

Finally, I say to Senator Harradine that this whole process has been worthwhile. I note that in your other bill—your bill that you say is so good—you have adopted amendments which were put by the coalition, some of them even canvassed by the committee. So, in hindsight, history will say, `Yes it was a valuable exercise, that debate; yes it was a valuable exercise, that committee'—because you yourself have adopted in part the recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak at this stage of the debate, but I will quickly put on the record my reaction not to Senator Evans's rehashed speech from December on the seven deadly sins—he has indicated the prognosis for some of them is not death but maybe something a little bit less—but to what Senator Kernot said. Senator Harradine referred to the overwhelming support of the Australian population in 1967, which is nearly 30 years ago, to the amendment to subsection 51(xxvi) of the constitution. This ensured that this parliament had the right to make special laws for the people of any race—it took out the words `other than the Aboriginal race'—in any state.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the government would regard this as a special measure. We regard those citizenship rights that Senator Kernot is talking about as citizenship rights. The reason we have special measure legislation, both under our constitution and under the international covenants that prescribe these things, is that we require special measures to ensure that some racial or other minority groups actually achieve those citizenship rights. I do not think Senator Kernot would say that most Aboriginals enjoy those citizenship rights. We require a range of special measures, all of which the coalition has supported over the decades and is supporting now, and land is one way of achieving that.

The other point I will refer to is the general concept of what happened in America in the last century. Senator Kernot will have viewed the video Contrary Warriors that has been floating around which goes into some detail about the effect of the 1887 General Allotments Act, particularly in the state of Montana where they split up blocks of land into 160 acre sections and gave them to individuals. The Americans made a mistake nearly 100 years ago by prescribing in legislation a form of ownership to the Crow Indians in that state that was entirely inappropriate and inflexible and the effects were disastrous.

What is this government doing nearly 100 years later? It is prescribing—and I am very disappointed that the Australian Democrats are supporting this—a form of ownership that may well be appropriate to some but entirely inappropriate to others. This government, with the support of the Democrats, has not learnt from the mistakes made by the people in America nearly 100 years ago which forced a form of ownership onto people that was not appropriate in all the circumstances. Again, the provisions in relation to the sale of the land equally apply there.

There is nothing in the amendments that the coalition has moved that excludes what the government wants to do. Senator Kernot has said that she believes that there are three deadly sins—that is, the issues in relation to health, housing and education, corporations and the sale of land; she does not agree that there are seven deadly sins so progress has been made there. Our amendments are inclusive. Our amendments include flexibility and all of the options and put them in the hands of Aboriginal people.

It is the government's legislation, which has the support of the Democrats, that excludes all of these possibilities. Nothing in our amendments excludes giving land to corporations and ensuring the ILC has the final say in whether they sell it or not. With our amendments it would be an inclusive bill that gets a third reading. The government's bill is exclusive. I urge the parliament of Australia to support an inclusive approach to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of the renegotiated comprehensive double taxation agreement between Australia and New Zealand. The bill will insert the text of the agreement into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953.

The bill will also make consequential amendments to that act and to a number of other acts. These consequential amendments flow from the fact that the double tax agreement replaces the existing agreement with New Zealand and covers fringe benefits taxed under the Fringe Benefits Assessment Act 1986.

The agreement was signed on 27 January 1995 and replaces the double tax agreement which was signed on 8 November 1972. As with the earlier agreement this agreement allocates taxing rights over all substantial forms of trans-Tasman income flows.
In terms of comparison with the existing agreement, the renegotiated agreement:

PARA.TAB: includes provisions to deal with:

SPEECH.PARA: the taxation of income from real property and from the alienation of property generally;
the taxation of other income, being a sweep-up article;
the possible double taxation of trans-Tasman fringe benefits; and
a general strengthening of anti-avoidance meas ures.

PARA.TAB: removes:

SPEECH.PARA: the force of attraction principle in relation to permanent establishments; and
the special rule on the taxation of interest payments to associates.

PARA.TAB: reduces:

SPEECH.PARA: the withholding tax rate on royalties from a maximum of 15 per cent to a maximum of 10 per cent of the gross royalty payment, and

PARA.TAB: reflects:

SPEECH.PARA: an agreed approach to the taxation of branches of Australian insurers operating in New Zealand.

Details of the new agreement were announced and copies made publicly available at the time of signature. The agreement has met with a generally favourable reaction from the business communities of both countries and from other sections of the community with trans-Tasman income flows.

The Government believes that the agreement will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment and the wider relationship that exists with New Zealand under the Closer Economic Relations Agreement.

The agreement will enter into force on the date on which the two countries exchange diplomatic notes advising each other that all domestic requirements to give the agreement the force of law in the respective countries have been completed. In Australia, these requirements include the enactment of enabling legislation by Parliament.
It is not possible to accurately predict the eventual effect of the agreement on the revenue, but it is not expected to be significant.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I understand that there was a division in the Senate just now which, for the first time in 17 years, I missed because I was distracted in entertaining a delegation from Hungary that visited this chamber earlier today. I was in the presence of House of Representatives members and, whilst hearing bells, I understood them to be for the House of Representatives. I apologise as it is unprofessional for me to have been so distracted from the bells.

PARA.TAB: I support the coalition in the division that I inadvertently just missed, and I ask whether it is possible, even if by leave, to put the question again so that the outcome can be correctly determined by those senators who are actually able to vote on the matter. I genuinely support the coalition's position and apologise again, not only to my leader but to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and to all senators that, for the reason I have just indicated, I missed that division.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Teague's distress is evident and, I believe, genuine. There is a convention in this place that where people have missed a division through misadventure of some kind or another of a reasonably plausible kind it is allowed for the matter to be put again. I might say that we have all suffered a bit of misadventure in this case. Our misadventure happens to be the absence of Senator Devereux lately of our ranks, who is overseas at the moment, unpaired, and who would unquestionably have been here voting on our side of the equation producing the result we just had. So be it. We have to tolerate that. Equally, we have to bear with such fortitude we can command the likely result of this division now if Senator Teague does take part in it. So we will not stand in the way of the matter being recommitted.

—by leave—I did point out to this chamber two years ago that when this happened once before and five Liberals missed a division—they all hit the door—this was misadventure. When there was misadventure on our side some months later, we had no grace from those opposite. We had to move 12 divisions to rectify the situation to reflect this chamber on the industrial relations bill. Senator Cook was the one with carriage of it. I just put that on the record.
—What happened? I don't remember that.

—I made the speech at the time. I pointed out the example and I repeated the principle that night, as I had previous times, that votes in this chamber should never be affected by misadventure. We are consistent on that.
—What was the misadventure?

—The misadventure was that there was a one-minute division bell and some people were not able to get back in time. It was partly our fault because a minister is always under instruction if there is what we call a mickey mouse division, if I can put that on the record, to interrupt debate to make sure it is a four-minute bell so that ministers can get back here. That is the only point I make. The last time this happened there was no graciousness. We moved 12 motions and had a division on every motion to reflect the will of the Senate. I just hope the graciousness that our leader has shown today is repeated when misadventure occurs on other occasions. That is the only point I make.
—by leave—I thank the government for its tolerance in this matter. I hope it now feels better about it.

DEBATE.TITLE: CLASSIFICATION (PUBLICATIONS, FILMS AND COMPUTER GAMES) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 11 October 1994, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the opposition will be supporting the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994. The bill proposes to provide the classification of publications, films and computer games for the Australian Capital Territory. When this is through, it will form part of a national system for classification and enforcement of these classifications.

PARA.TAB: The bill's main purpose is to establish the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board to administer this particular act. Classification decisions are to be made in accordance with the national classification code which is set out in the bill and guidelines to help apply this code. The bill does give effect to community concern about X and R rated material on computer, video and film. Overall, this bill is a triumph, I think, for cooperative federalism on the regulation of material that can harm and disturb.

This country has, I believe, one of the best censorship systems in the world and I think it is regarded that way. It began in the early 1970s and very early on it was set up to balance what are perhaps two conflicting principles; that is, the rights of adults to see material they want to see and obviously the right of children to be protected. The conflict between these principles I believe overall has been resolved in a reasonably satisfactory way in regard to the public exhibition of material, particularly in cinemas, particularly with the application of the R classification.

We have considerable concern about the way in which this material is in the video stores; the way in which that, in turn, has got into the hands of minors, and there is widespread evidence of that; the way it has affected the Aboriginal communities, particularly in the Northern Territory, in very unfortunate ways, and we have had evidence before the community standards committee of that; and the way in which paedophiles have used the material for seduction and the unfortunate effects of that on society. But we now have a national approach and we have seen evidence, particularly over the last two years, of a considerable amount of cooperation between state and federal Attorneys-General in the way in which this act or the whole area of censorship is to be administered in this country.

We have, as a committee on community standards, made a number of recommendations to the government on additional reforms apart from what is here at the moment. I think it is very unfortunate that the government has not taken up those particular reforms and the committee has once again urged that the reforms initially put forward in the computer games area a little over a year ago and now restated in our latest report on film classification be adopted.

Before I outline what those reforms are, I will just give an example of why such reform is needed. A few years ago a film called Salo came into this country. It is a horrific film. It has been banned in most countries; it was banned in Australia 17 years ago. But when it came before the OFLC it was initially, by majority decision, decided not to classify it as R, but the Film Review Board overturned that decision. I think this points to the nub of what is still the problem in the censorship area.

What we have done is set up a system that is not really representative of what the community feels is needed in this area, and we have also taken out some degree of parliamentary scrutiny of the process. In the report of the community standards committee we did recommend that these two things again be put into the legislation initially and, as the government has not done that, we would urge the government to review that decision.

When I first read this bill I was very disappointed to see that the current structure of censorship pretty much stayed the same. What the committee had recommended was that we have a chief censor and a deputy chief censor who are drawn from the community. The person who is currently the chief censor would become the chief executive officer and he would perform a role something like the head of other statutory authorities in terms of administering that particular area but that the actual final decisions as in a chief censor and a deputy chief censor be drawn from a board that is far more widely representative than the one we have currently.

On the record in a number of committee hearings I did ask about the representative nature of the present board. It is a great disappointment to me that public servants involved tried to hide the real situation on a number of occasions. We have a board that is highly unrepresentative. If you look at the occupations of the 10 people involved up until the latest change from 20, they include journalists, film critics, teachers, lecturers in media studies, public servants, school counsellors and a fitter. If you want someone perhaps representative of the community, the fitter was probably the closest you will get out of that group. Unfortunately, when the board was reformed and it was to go to 20 people—
Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just about to make that point—when the board was to be made up to 20 people the fitter went but there are still not 20 names. We went through the latest report and the board was only up to 11. Again, it was still the same sort of group. I am sure these people are very learned in these matters relating to film but the question is: do they really reflect community standards? When we asked the Attorneys-General offices and the OFLC questions on this from time to time, they claimed that these people, by their own community interaction, form a group that is reflecting community standards. I think that is drawing a pretty long bow.

PARA.TAB: What we need to do is set up a wider group, and the committee welcomes the fact that it has gone from 10 to 20. But again, the way in which these people are selected and the types of people who are selected need to be very carefully analysed. They are all very highly academically qualified, but if you had a truly representative cross-section of the community, you would not be using academic qualifications as your first and, I suspect in some ways, only criteria for selection. So we urge that that aspect of the board's work and structure certainly be changed.

The other thing that we have recommended twice in committee reports—which is still being ignored—is that there should be a community group to review what happens with decisions of this reconstituted board. We recommended that any decisions of the board to do with classification at a particular level which were not unanimous be reviewed by this wider community group. The other part of this was that, when there is disagreement between the OFLC and the film review board, this wider community group review the decision of the board.

I think that will put in a mechanism which will solve a lot of the problems that we tend to have in this area. Suddenly, in an area that is fairly dynamic and rapidly changing, something happens—such as the Salo case—and the community gets outraged that this has happened. If these structures had been set up in the first place, those sorts of problems would not have happened. Part of the art of government is getting your structures right so you do not have to constantly set up committees and have inquiries and reviews. If you get the structure right in the first place, you stop that sort of thing.

The other thing that still disturbs us about this area is the lack of parliamentary scrutiny. It seemed very difficult to get information at times. A lot of the key information was tucked away in the back of reports; it does not come within the purview and scrutiny of the parliament. We have recommended, particularly when there are changes to the way in which we conduct the codes and review processes, that those changes actually lay on the table of both the state and federal parliaments, thus allowing parliamentarians to scrutinise the system.

Probably the most disturbing shortcoming of the system at the moment—and I really urge the OFLC to be more diligent in its approach to this—is the lack of consistency between state and federal procedures and, indeed, legislative bases. This was highlighted most dramatically recently by a case in Victoria. An adult chain called Club X was raided by the vice squad and a whole range of illegal videos were seized. The point of the story is that they got off scot-free on this because the Victorian Labor government in the 1980s had not kept up the definitions in the act to take into account newer technologies. The act talked about film. I note in the federal act that film is defined to include video, but this obviously was not the case in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr was advising the Victorian government.

—Was he really? That perhaps explains some of it. What happened is that they got off scot-free. This is important because this company was completely flouting the censorship rules in this country. They had videos on the shelves that were seized by the police, and this is documented by the police and the story has been written up in the press. They had material that would have certainly been banned by the OFLC had it been classified.

PARA.TAB: One of the tapes was of actual torture. A girl had been captured in California and she had been sexually tortured. This incident had been videotaped, and the videotape appeared in these adult shops in Melbourne. The title of the tape was Tortured Tits, and this poor, unfortunate person not only had the terrible experience of going through such an ordeal but then had it displayed through these shops.

When the police seized the material, they discovered that most of the material was completely unclassified. The shop must have known that a raid was coming, and they rushed around and tried to put stickers on the tapes. They actually put the literature classification sticker—the class 1 and class 2 stickers—on videotapes, which, of course, does not apply.

The police seized thousands of tapes, along with invoices and documents. They took this material away, worked out their case to prosecute this group and went to court. A lawyer for the adult shops discovered a loophole in that the Victorian government had not changed the act to take into account the changes to the type of technology. Video is a series of electronic dots—it is not film technically—and it was not included in the definition. The judge threw out the case, restored all the films to these video shops and awarded them $200,000 in compensation.

That shows that we can have a system that does not have proper scrutiny because the Public Service is not exercising due diligence to see that there is consistency between a state and federal act. It is not a big job. All you have to do is go to the front of the act and look at the definition. If you looked at the definition of the federal act and the definition of the state act, you would see that they did not line up. That is the problem.

We have a federal system, but I urge the OFLC to be particularly diligent in administering this act by searching, in a pro-active way, to see if there are loopholes. What we do not want happening yet again, as that case showed, is someone who is trying to make a fast buck finding holes in the regulatory regime in this country. If that happens, we will just go on having Senate inquiry after Senate inquiry.

The community standards committee that reported on this bill was set up four years ago, in 1991, to do one job, which was going to take about three months. What we discovered were these sorts of loopholes in the system that I mentioned. In particular, areas of the Public Service—particularly, in that case, Telecom—were not exercising due diligence. As time went on—and we were looking at fantasy phone calls at that stage—we discovered a whole range of other problems in the system. Four years later, it is coming up again and again. There are further problems in the system. The latest one we have heard of is that we could have shown on pay TV live tape from road accidents and police sieges, fed straight through into TV sets. Normally, all the film goes into a television studio. It is edited—obviously following certain guidelines, such as the FACTS code—and then a snippet which is not too offensive is shown that night. Under this scenario direct footage will be allowed to go straight through to the screens of pay TV viewers. We can imagine some of the horrific scenes, dealing with road accidents, police sieges and other disasters. Small children can see this if, as we discovered—particularly with the overseas experience—the decoding devices are not effective in preventing a proportion of children seeing this sort of material. So this is of great concern to the committee.

Obviously, bulletin boards are also a huge problem, and this is the next challenge for the committee. I am reminded very much of the advice of a very experienced staffer I had when four years ago I first got on this committee. She said, `You'll rue the day you got on this committee; its work will just go on and on and on.' Over the last four years that is precisely what has happened.

The committee could wind up and finish its work if we had in place in this country a proper regulatory regime for the area of censorship. I think the bill we are considering at the moment is a step in the right direction. But, again, I would urge public servants to be very diligent and pro-active in making sure that what they are suggesting in law is actually what happens in practice in this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill, which sets up a national classification code, is a timely reminder of the need for greater public scrutiny of what is considered suitable in the areas of publications, films and computer games which are now available in Australia. A commitment by the government to ensuring that community standards and family values are not usurped by the ever increasing flood of pornography and unacceptable material which appears to be creeping into every facet of life in our society does provide a glimmer of hope for many Australian families.

PARA.TAB: Recently, we saw the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) declare the need for a family based television channel which would reduce the amount of violence, horror and sex which invades our daily television broadcasts. This same Prime Minister, who in this way wants to be seen to be taking the high moral ground, ironically has allowed his government to ignore the increasingly unacceptable level of violence, sex and horror on the ABC and the SBS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I welcome Senator O'Chee's concurrence in that claim. In spite of these problems, a cooperative approach between the states and the Commonwealth on the need for uniform legislation in Australia with regard to the classification of publications, films and computer games has developed. But this conformity seems to be publicly driven.

PARA.TAB: Last year, this government—in particular, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch)—gave carte blanche for the controversial film, Salo, to be shown in Australia. I note that my colleague Senator Tierney a few moments ago also referred to the issue of this film.

On 5 August 1994 I wrote to the federal Attorney-General, following the public outcry and distress about Salo being shown in South Australia after it had received an R(18+) classification by the Commonwealth Film Censorship Board on 18 December 1992. Peter Duncan MP, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General, replied by letter dated 22 September stating:

SPEECH.PARA: That decision was appealed to the Film and Literature Board of Review which, on 13 January 1993, upheld the appeal and directed the Censorship Board to register the film with a `For Restricted Exhibition' (R18) classification and the consumer advice `Disturbing Adult Concepts and High Level Violence and Sex'.
