That was it. That was how concerned the federal Attorney-General was about the content of this film and the process used to give it an R classification.

PARA.TAB: In July 1994 a constituent of mine in South Australia raised the issue of the disturbing content contained in the film, Salo. What I understand to be an accurate description of degrading forms of behaviour and acts perpetrated in various scenes in this film which he detailed in his letter are too filthy and too abhorrent to repeat in this place. But there can be absolutely no doubt that such presentations should be banned completely.

When this Labor government allowed this film to be shown in my home state of South Australia, Mr Richard Read, a Victorian crown prosecutor for 14 years who has prosecuted many violent sex criminals, had this to say about it:

SPEECH.PARA: Salo is, without exception, the most horrific sexually violent film I have ever seen. Two of the people I was with when I saw it (at the request of the Herald-Sun newspaper) were police officers and both of them had to leave the room as they felt ill. It escapes me how Salo meets any of the statutory guidelines and I agree that we must await the copy-cat torture crimes of innocent children.

That is what Mr Richard Read said about a decision for which this government is responsible. Yet we have the Prime Minister strutting the stage saying that he wants a family television channel. What absolute hypocrisy from this government; what hypocrisy from this foul-mouthed Prime Minister!

PARA.TAB: Should this legislation be passed, and I hope it will be, I will be among the first to call for this film, Salo, to be banned in Australia under the government's new RC—refused classification—category. The government's proposed RC classification deals directly with publications which:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . describe, depict, express or otherwise deal with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a way that they offend against the standards or morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults to the extent that they should not be classified; or
described or depicted in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a minor who is, or who appears to be, under 16 (whether the minor is engaged in sexual activity or not); or
promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime or violence—

a very accurate description of the film, Salo. In South Australia we saw the former state Labor government—in this case, Attorney-General Chris Sumner—coming out publicly and actually defending this film, Salo, on the pretext that it served a useful purpose in our community as a measure of protecting our civil liberties. What a joke! I struggle to fathom the former South Australian Labor Attorney-General's thinking in his defence of the film, Salo, and in allowing it to be shown. I was very glad that the new Liberal Attorney-General, Trevor Griffin, overturned that decision when the film was attempted to be shown again later.

PARA.TAB: This bill will establish the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board. The government in its second reading speech has also indicated that the Law Reform Commission recommendation for community consultation will be adopted. Given the Salo controversy, there is sufficient evidence to suggest that the existing board has become desensitised to the increasing levels of violence and pornography in our society. Consequently, this proposed community input is indeed welcome.

The arguments for regular reviews of the boards' membership and tenure are obvious. One must query the ability of any censorship board member to judge acceptable community standards, when desensitisation over time must be an inevitable consequence attached to this role. This was one of the recommendations of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies. Recommendation 11 of that committee stated that the length of tenure of censorship board members needed review.

Clause 51 of the bill, which sets out the terms and conditions of appointment to the Classification Board, provides that a member, other than a temporary member, may be appointed for up to five years and may be reappointed; a member's total period of appointment may not exceed seven years. Clause 76 of the bill similarly sets out the terms and conditions of appointment to the review board, also with a maximum term of seven years.

The Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, in presenting the government's response to the community standards committee recommendation 11, stated that the Law Reform Commission's recommendations regarding tenure have largely been adopted. The existing tenure periods are three years, with a further three years, and a maximum appointment period not exceeding six years.

It seems to me that the tenure period has actually been increased with a term of five years, with a provision for reappointment and a maximum not exceeding seven years. This should be contrasted with evidence given to the committee during its public hearings where community groups requested a tenure period of two years. We have a situation where we currently have a maximum tenure period of six years, the community wants a tenure period of two years—and the government has extended it to seven, thereby increasing the capacity for members of this board to be desensitised and make false judgments about what ought and ought not to be available on television and other communications media. In that respect this bill does nothing to improve the situation; in fact, it worsens the situation.

This bill will have little effect in cleaning up the mess we are in if changes are not made on the censorship board which reflect a more appropriate degree of suitability of films, publications and computer games. If the government does not examine board membership and further review the tenure of board members, this bill will be nothing more than Clayton's legislation, paying lip service to the issue with little else on offer than the politically expedient portrayal of the Labor government's touted concern for families and protection of our children. That is the real concern about this legislation: that it is about creating a perception and an image and denying the reality that this government is doing nothing about the pornography, unacceptable films and other programs that are becoming more and more evident on television and other means of media communication.

On the one hand, the Prime Minister wants to give the impression that he is concerned about family standards and values; on the other hand, his government—the government for which he as Prime Minister must take primary responsibility—appoints people to the Office of Film and Literature Classification Board who refuse to stand up and be counted when it comes to maintaining decency. The Attorney-General and the government should move to ban the film Salo. It recently refused to do this despite public condemnation. Only if it does this will it prove its commitment to the stated aims of this legislation.

The other point which I want to make concerns the amendment to this bill which excludes from the definition of `computer game' material on computer bulletin boards. The omission of paragraph (a) and thus the exclusion, it is stated, will enable the classification board to classify computer games on computer bulletin boards if there is some requirement to do so under other Commonwealth, state or territory legislation. Attorney-General Lavarch, in reply to a question on 12 October 1994, said that part of the reason for this exclusion was that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government clearly—and no doubt the Opposition—is not interested in having any laws which would unreasonably intrude upon the privacy of the telephone system.

The Attorney-General went on to say that, because of both cost and intrusion upon the sanctity of the telephone system, he considered unrealistic the recommendation of the task force that a censorship regime be applied to bulletin board traffic.

PARA.TAB: A further argument which has been used for this exclusion is that the percentage of the Australian population who access the international computer network via a modem is currently only four per cent. In most instances, this low percentage would be relevant. However, in Australia, there are currently some 500,000 Internet users, and the Internet is the fastest growing telecommunications network globally.

The Journal of Economic Perspectives, volume 8, No. 3 published statistics as at March 1994 showing that the Internet, the largest network with an estimated 15 million users, has had a 600-fold increase in only six years. The traffic of the network is currently increasing at a rate of six per cent per month. This growth is quite extraordinary. The Attorney-General has recognised that Australia is the second greatest user in the world of this technology.

The danger for our children, many of whom are much more computer literate than their parents, is simply that by using a personal computer connected to the Internet they can gain access to specific pornographic bulletin board services such as Kinknet and Throbnet, often without the knowledge or permission of their parents. Pirated software and sexually explicit material, including interactive adult games and entire libraries of X-rated pictures, apparently can be found on some bulletin boards. It is not beyond the realm of possibility for children to unlock and gain access to this material.

The authors of the Internet Complete Reference, published by McGraw-Hill in 1994, rank the most popular Usenet discussion groups on data which includes the number of messages posted to particular groups. According to the authors of this reference, the fourth most popular discussion group is called Alt.Sex, which covers a wide range of sexual topics and interests. Five of the 10 most popular groups, that is 50 per cent, are described as sexually explicit. Computer technology advances do make it difficult to prevent minors from gaining access to pornographic material. This is even more relevant with the tightening of legislation in this area. Bulletin boards are the one remaining conduit for marketing pornographic information. This loophole is a fact which cannot be ignored.
An article which appeared in the 8 October 1994 issue of the New Scientist magazine entitled `Network Confidential' explains that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . virtually uncrackable `public key' encryption has made available, to one and all, a method of cryptography programs such as PGP (the name is short for pretty good privacy).

The article also explains the two-key system required to encode and decode messages by means of a private and public key. However, the trail of the two-key system and newest methods of encryption do draw attention to the material.

PARA.TAB: A more sinister and insidious method of cryptography, when examined in the context of the transmission of pornography, is the ability to compress and incorporate in digitised pictures material which can then be unlocked by code. This material is not obvious or detectable to the user who is not looking for it or does not know what to look for. The New Scientist article goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Hiding messages in seemingly innocent pictures or texts is an old technique. But in the era of computers, it has become cheap, easy and undetectable.

This technology therefore is a powerful tool for those who know how to manipulate and control it. The Dutch government in early 1994 attempted to ban coded messages outright, but withdrew that proposal in July 1994. France now requires that all cryptography be licensed, that the licensee has a legitimate reason for using it and that the government be given a copy of the private key.

PARA.TAB: The United States decided that cryptography is acceptable provided that it held the keys to a trapdoor in every system and sponsored a computer chip called `clipper' as an industry standard. Industry experts tried and failed to crack the clipper and it had been declared safe. However, recently it took a cryptography expert only 28 minutes on a common workstation to render the trapdoor unusable. The dual issues of privacy and censorship are not easily reconciled, but I urge the government not to rest on its laurels in relation to computer bulletin boards classification. This issue has been and is being addressed by other governments. Given the Attorney-General's acknowledgment that Australia is the second largest user of the Internet, perhaps the time has come for a more detailed consideration of this issue.

I simply conclude by saying that I hope this legislation will have some beneficial effect on restricting the expansion of opportunities for pornography to be viewed through our various media. If the government really wants to convince the community that it is fair dinkum in its approach to families and children on this issue and it is not, as I said earlier, merely trying to create the perception that it cares about families, and is thereby trying to match the undoubted and recognised commitment of the Liberal and National parties to family values and family standards, then it needs to go further than is provided in this legislation—much, much further. In particular, in a practical way in terms of decisions that have to be made immediately, that film Salo needs to be banned. More importantly, the government needs to deal with this issue of bulletin boards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer briefly to some matters that have not really been included in the legislation, and one that has, because I believe that this is the appropriate time to raise these issues. This bill seeks to implement recommendations from a 1991 report of the Law Reform Commission on the feasibility of establishing a national scheme covering films and publication classifications, and it recommends that there should be a rationalisation of state laws to create a national scheme. The Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies has also looked into the matter, urging in 1993 that computer games and videos be brought under the national censorship system. Some of those committee recommendations have been dealt with and others have not.

PARA.TAB: I wish to raise four particular points at this point. The first one is not dealt with in this present legislation but it relates to the matter under our consideration at this time, and that is the repeated suggestions that the non-violent erotica classification should replace the X classification. The X classification has led to a misconception in the community that such films contain extremes of violence and sexual violence and illegal sexual behaviour, like child pornography. At the same time the X category currently allows material with certain activities which may be inconsistent with community standards, such as aggressive behaviour, demeaning sexual dialogue or sadomasochism.

I point out to my colleagues in the chamber that the Australian Institute of Criminology, in its paper entitled Australian Institute of Criminology: Trends and Issues Paper No. 9 of 1987, showed a sampling of what was contained in PG, M, R, X and refused-classification videos and presented to us—I have discovered this to my surprise—the fact that X-rated videos contain less violence than any other category of film or video that it looked at. In fact, M-rated videos contain the most violence. R-rated videos contain the most sexual violence.
Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has quite helpfully pointed out that it is not simply violence or sexual violence that we are concerned about but demeaning behaviour. I think that this is one of the strongest arguments for replacing the X classification with a classification which specifies that there is to be no non-violent erotica and removes those demeaning components—demeaning sexual dialogue, sadomasochism or aggressive behaviour. My view regarding this is that it is indisputable that there is a very popular perception within the community that non-violent erotica should be available to adults—not children but adults.

PARA.TAB: I also cite the Australian Broadcasting Authority. It announced that in some polling there was strong support—70 per cent—for X classified material containing scenes of actual sex between consenting adults being made available to adults, with video being the preferred medium. Whether or not that is a situation which I might agree or disagree with, I do not think any of us can fail to note that the popularity of such material and its current availability under the X classification mean that unduly demeaning and violent material is available.

Also, a black market has arisen where material is available that would have been refused if it had been submitted for classification under the non-violent erotica category. I believe the police and enforcement agencies need to concentrate on the more extreme material and work together to promote a freedom from those kinds of rackets.

We have the anomaly that, because the ACT and the Northern Territory have X-rated videos available in restricted areas only, mail order black market rackets can occur. I ask for greater consideration of the issue that it may be better to relabel or reclassify material as non-violent erotica with some modification to the guidelines and also of the issue of improving the age of participants to be 18 or over. This would allow us to have, I believe, a more realistic adjustment to both the demands for this material in the community and a control over what is made available or floating around Australia.

The classification of material should reflect community standards. It is clear that the majority of people would like to see non-violent erotica available to adults even though they may not wish to obtain it themselves. What should be of greater concern is the level of extreme violence in films, videos and computer games as well as the sexual content of computer games. Computer games in particular—which are interactive, intensive and repetitive—have the potential to adversely influence the minds of young people and should come under increasing scrutiny.

The second point I wish to raise is that, if we were to have non-violent erotica classification for films, that classification and the R classification should carry health education messages that allow people not only to learn from the materials that they are seeing and to counteract both the violence and the demeaning behaviour contained in films but also to promote a healthier approach to sexual material.

The third point I raise is that classification costs at the moment are inequitable. The current position is that the fee for classification is based on the duration of films alone. That is inequitable because it has no regard to the nature of films and the extent of their distribution, nor the cost or the likely profits to be earned. So what we may have is an art film with very limited distribution having the same fee requirement as a blockbuster film which has wider screening and generates large profits. The fee structure for classification of films should, I believe, reflect the diversity of films and their different types of audiences.

Finally, I wish to comment on an aspect of this bill which I believe is very important, and that is providing for the independence of board members. I believe that it can be stated that in more recent times board members have become engaged in policy making and advisory roles to the minister. This has the potential to erode the independence of board members in their primary role of classification. It raises the possibility of political pressure being applied on future classification decisions. That is an undesirable state of affairs.

We certainly support the fact that the director should be the only person taking on a Public Service role, as recommended by the Senate committee. The limited tenure of such a position is also valuable because it allows a rotation of office and also a capacity to be more responsive to community needs and views. In conclusion, I understand this bill has the support of the Senate. I put on record these matters, which may receive consideration at a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill, but before I do that I will mention a few points apropos of what Senator Chamarette has said. I have probably seen more X-rated, R-rated and other videos than anybody else in this joint because I have been on the committee dealing with such material since about 1985.

PARA.TAB: The Joint Select Committee on Video Material indicated that much of the X-rated material treats women as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its targeted audience and reduces persons to objects or occasions of sexual pleasure. It also in many cases deals with sexual harassment situations which would in fact have the condemnation of all. I am sure Senator Chamarette was not referring to that type of X-rated material. I hope she was not.

Senator Chamarette also quoted the Institute of Criminology. The article she referred to was written by none other than Dr Wilson, who criticised the Meese Commission and quoted Nobile and Nadler. I discovered that Nobile and Nadler are the Editor and the Deputy Editor of Penthouse magazine in the United States of America. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an order of the Senate agreed on 27 February requesting documents associated with the granting of the 1994 woodchip export licences issued in December 1994. With regard to the request for advice the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, received from his department, these have not been included in the documents I am tabling. It is the government's view that such advice, which sets out alternative courses of action or which contains sensitive policy advice, should remain confidential to the government.

PARA.TAB: With regard to advice the Minister for Resources received from the Minister for the Environment, Sports and Territories (Senator Faulkner), these letters have already been tabled in the parliament. In relation to any other advice, I table advice provided by the Australian Heritage Commission to the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall. I inform the Senate that some documents that fall within this class have not been included in the documents I am tabling. These are copies of legal advice prepared by the Attorney-General's Department for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and, as such, attract legal professional privilege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This annual report is an interesting report, because the work of the IMF is one of the things that are surrounded by mystery for most people. I must admit that, on reading the report of the Treasurer (Mr Willis), one is not necessarily that much enlightened on the operations of the IMF at the end of the perusal of the document. It is interesting, though, to note some of the things that the IMF has been doing. In particular it has been providing advice to a number of countries to deal with problems of adjustment, principally problems to do with growth, although there are some countries that have had more difficult problems than that. For example, the IMF has provided assistance in terms of advising Germany on how to handle recovery and advising the Chinese government in relation to issues of growth.

PARA.TAB: The IMF also assists countries in transition. I would like to make some comments about the situation in Vietnam and Cambodia. I suppose I should preface those remarks by making the comment that it is easy for the IMF to give advice; the difficult thing is to persuade the people of a country to necessarily follow the advice. One of the observations I made at the end of the 1980s dealing with Latin America was that there were remedies for the Latin American crisis, but the question was whether people were going to accept those remedies. Countries that are in transition, such as Vietnam, require a certain degree of political courage, inasmuch as governments have to make decisions which are politically difficult. It then follows that you also need a certain degree of courage and willingness to cooperate from the community at large. That is just as difficult.

Countries such as Vietnam are coming to realise that the years of communist rule were wasted years in terms of economic advancement and that communist countries across the world, it does not matter where they are, have been shown at the end of the Cold War to be economically backward. In comparing them with other countries that were in a similar stage of development at the beginning of the Cold War, it is shown very clearly that communism has failed. The socialist experiment was a failure; yet these governments often require some degree of encouragement to accept that and to accept that it is time to embark on a more liberal economic course than the one which has been in use in these countries for so long.

Having said that, the difficulty, and it is a difficulty which is being experienced and observed in Eastern Europe as much as anywhere else, is that the people who have for so long lived in an economic system which was a fiction—nobody can say otherwise that the economic system in Eastern Europe was a fiction—have a lot of difficulty adjusting to economic reality because, in many cases, economic reality brings substantial pain. The longer a country has been a communist country, the harder it is for it to break out of the economic fiction. That is why we find in some eastern European countries a resurgence of people saying, `We should have a communist government.' Those people are dreaming of a time which can never come back and which never really existed in the first place.

At the end of the day, the willingness of people to change quickly is the key determinant. If people are wanting to compromise change in these countries, then the process of change becomes much slower and it entails much more pain. I hope that we will see substantial change in countries such as Vietnam and Cambodia. Cambodia, of course, also has political problems. There are other countries in the region which have been subject to governments of less than satisfactory economic persuasion. We hope, too, that changes will occur there, just as we hope changes in human rights will occur. When we talk about human rights, one of the biggest factors in deciding whether a country enjoys full and proper human rights is the level of its economic self-sufficiency and the standard of living enjoyed by the people. Obviously, when they have a higher standard of living, they put more of a price and value on human life. That is something we should all look forward to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak on the annual report to the parliament under the International Monetary Agreement Act 1947 of the International Monetary Fund. It is that time of the year again. This report is actually a great improvement, in our opinion, on previous ones, which have been far more general and descriptive. This one at least gives some taste of topical issues. Has anything changed? It appears from this report and general information on International Monetary Fund statements that it has not.

PARA.TAB: We have the IMF presented as a major tool in helping countries develop, yet Australia's representation to the IMF is still under control of the Treasurer, who may be interested in seeing increased economic activity but is singularly uninterested in equity, sustainability or most legitimate goals of the wider community both in Australia and globally. As such, I guess we show ourselves as being quite different in our opinion of the benefits of taking IMF advice from what was given just then by Senator O'Chee.

As a high point, last November, at the 50-year anniversary of the World Bank, formed at the same time as the IMF, Michel Cadessus, managing director of the IMF, heavily criticised national minimum wage and condition regulation, unemployment support programs and restrictions on lay-offs and the dismissal of workers. The elimination of these things are liable to be included among the social policies the IMF uses its power to impose, along with a reduction of social infrastructure. The World Bank also seeks to impose such structural adjustment as a condition for its assistance. It was also revealed in Madrid that the World Bank receives more money from developing nations than it gives—so much for developing nations needing the World Bank to improve their position. These are good reasons to question the role and continued existence of these institutions.

In regard to Australia's role in the IMF, the Treasurer, Mr Willis, said at the same meeting that no measures should be taken to integrate environmental or labour standards into trade. The IMF not only tends to be a fundamental economic decision maker on the global stage but also has the ability—and uses it—to erode national measures in countries that borrow, imposing draconian `structural adjustment' policies on subject nations. Just think about it: when the economies are good, it says, `Cut government spending,' and when the economies are bad, it says—surprise, surprise!—`Cut government spending.'

The IMF and, indeed, other institutions such as the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank where the Treasurer is our representative have been heavily criticised by the non-government international development community for these programs. Most recently there has been a strong campaign to end these institutions as counterproductive to genuine, equitable and sustainable development. When the purpose of Australian support for these institutions has been questioned, Australian representatives, especially from development and aid divisions within Foreign Affairs, often answer that they should not be ended, that `we' need to work within and to make them more green and more just.

It appears, however, that the Treasurer and, through Treasury, the Australian people are working in exactly the opposite direction. We are working to ensure that nations have austerity programs imposed on them, to ensure that social services, basic health and education services, provision of clean water and so on are cut in order to pay for debt often imposed to pay for poorly conceived and heavily prescribed development programs advocated by these same agencies. At the same time, it is demanded that they open their economy to foreign investors anxious to exploit rather than to build and to foreign imports such as cars and alcohol which do nothing to increase productivity, and that they lift capital flow controls and so assist capital flight. This is structural adjustment.

I note on page 27 of the report in the section on the enhanced structural adjustment facility that there has been increasing recognition of `the importance of addressing social issues'. This is whitewash. As the statement of the managing director to whom I referred earlier indicates, the IMF is not interested in social safety nets. It is a smokescreen to deflect critics of the IMF. While the moves towards increased social responsibility are to be applauded, they are likely to be too little too late.

The IMF was created to regulate currency exchange. It was created after World War II to avoid the disastrous speculation that followed World War I. Its effective role ended with the floating of most currencies in the period around 1980. The IMF has not achieved the purpose it was designed for. It is not doing wonderful things to assist development in those nations which need it most. Whilst it is possible that the IMF might have done an Ebenezer Scrooge type transformation if the ghosts of Christmas past, present and future visited it since the Madrid meeting, I believe it is time to consider whether the IMF still has a role to play in today's world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report from NBEET and its Australian Research Council monitors the progress of the Institute of Advanced Studies at the Australian National University and checks that targets are met for collaborative activities with other universities. The Australian National University, in particular its Institute of Advanced Studies, is one of the great institutions of this country. It is a research body which attracts world-class scholars and which produces world-class results. It has in its ranks a number of Nobel Prize winners and Nobel Prize nominees. It is an institution which was started in the 1950s. It is one of the great achievements of the Menzies era. The institution developed initially under the guidance of Howard Florey. Since that time it has developed a wide range of research schools which are constituent to the Institute of Advanced Studies.

PARA.TAB: Over a number of years reviews of that school have been undertaken. In 1990 the Stephens review discovered that the institute had fallen off the pace somewhat on one of its key roles, which was to act as a breeding ground for researchers and people who would move into research in other universities. The Stephens review also found that the institute had fallen off the pace with respect to collaborative research projects. The review had established a number of guidelines and targets with respect to collaborative research for the institute to meet. This report shows that the institute is on target to meet the percentage of the budget allocated to collaborative research projects by the Stephens committee.

Honourable senators will recall that the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training did carry out an investigation into the Stephens committee report. We did find the report wanting in many ways. It was particularly unfortunate that the Stephens review found that the government had attempted to carve up the Institute of Advanced Studies. There was an attempt back in 1991 that partially succeeded in moving the John Curtin School of Medical Research out of the Institute of Advanced Studies. In the end, the finance of the school was moved from the DEET budget to the health budget. Our committee, after conducting an extensive hearing, found that that should not have happened. It should have stayed as part of the Institute of Advanced Studies.

One of the great strengths of the institute is that it has a number of constituent schools which interact with each other. For example, people in the biological sciences school interact very much with the people in the medical school. The administration of the school's funding is hampered by having two government departments involved. It is something which we hope the government will revisit some time. The last time I checked, the university was not very happy with this arrangement.

At the time we thought it was part of a plan by the government to dismantle the institute. Some people thought that the time for this sort of institution had passed. Under the Dawkins grand, unified national system, the idea was to create universities that looked as alike as possible. The Institute of Advanced Studies sat oddly in that scheme of things. It was an institution that was totally devoted to research; it was totally devoted to excellence. It was not in the pattern of the other universities. We all suspected that Mr Dawkins really did not want it there. But it has survived, and indeed thrived, following the Dawkins years. This report is testimony to that.

I wish to raise one small criticism about the distribution of collaborative research monies. It is still focussing very much on four of the big seven universities. Over 40 per cent of the funds go to those universities. The money really needs to be distributed across a wider range of universities. The collaborative work and the excellence that come out of that need to be distributed. That will be of great benefit to a wide range of universities. I commend the report to the Senate and wish the Institute of Advanced Studies well in its pursuit of excellence.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! The consideration of government documents has now concluded. I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to refer to a letter that I have received from a company called Sea Air Travel Pty Ltd of 403 Grange Road, Seaton, South Australia. It is a letter from a Mr Francesco Tigani complaining that I have acted disgracefully by libelling this person in relation to some matters relating to prosecutions and a relationship with Mr Francesco Labozzetta. That is not Mr Antonio Labozzetta, who is involved in Australian soccer; it is Mr Francesco Labozzetta, who I understand is his cousin.

PARA.TAB: The reason I raise this issue is that I am intrigued when people like this write letters to members of parliament, sending copies to one's leader, which are simply full of total, dishonest nonsense. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: RE: Comments made in the Senate 7th December 1994
I and my wife, Maria Tigani, are the directors of Sea Air Travel Pty Ltd.

Sea Air Travel has been an established travel agency business in Adelaide for over 27 years since 1968. During that period the business has been conducted under various entitles, initially as a partnership of my wife and I, then as business name for F Tigani and Co Pty. Ltd. and since 1986 as a business name for the Company Sea Air Travel Pty. Ltd.

All of these entitles have only involved my wife and I as principals and no other person. My wife and I have been the only directors and shareholders of both F. Tigani & Co. Pty. Ltd. and Sea Air Travel Pty. Ltd.

Your speech in the senate made certain derogatory remarks of a Mr Francesco Nocola Labozzetta. You went then on to make assert that Mr Labozzetta was an owner, for a period of three years of Sea Air Travel business in South Australia. You have been horribly misinformed as Mr Labozzetta has never been involved with Sea Air Travel in South Australia. To the best of my knowledge, Mr Labozzetta has never been involved in any travel business in South Australia.

In the same speech you then went on to say that the family involved in running Sea Air Travel in South Australia was involved in drug dealings. Again you have been badly misinformed. The NCA investigation that you refer to involved a number of families.
Families in at one least sense or another; I am not quite certain which sense Mr Tigani has in mind. It continues:

In court proceedings (not involving criminal charges for drugs) an assertion was made that one of the families was involved in drugs. However firstly this did not refer to my family. Secondly the family involved has no involvement whatsoever in the Sea Air Travel business. Thirdly the asserties made was never proved and not repeated in those proceedings.
He then calls on me to publicly withdraw.

PARA.TAB: It is intriguing that someone would assert that these entities only have been involved—Mr Tigani and his wife as principals and no-one else—and that Mr Francesco Labozzetta has never been involved in Sea Air Travel. I have here under the business names act an application for registration of the business name of Sea Air Travel Service of 403 Grange Road. The applicants as shown on this form, which is dated 22 May 1969, are Francesco Tigani, who has written me this charming letter, and Francesco Nocola Labozzetta, who, according to Mr Tigani, does not exist in South Australia, has never existed and has never been in partnership with Mr Francesco Tigani.

I presume that this is the same Francesco Tigani who wrote the letter. Obviously, he has had some incredible memory lapse. Not only that, we have a statement regarding a change of persons in relation to whom the business name is registered. The business involved is Sea Air Travel Service of 403 Grange Road. On 5 June 1972, certain persons ceased to carry on business under that business name. As I have properly said, Francesco Nocola Labozzetta then ceased. Unless my mathematics are appalling, 1969 to 1972 is three years. I asserted that Mr Francesco Labozzetta had been involved in this business for three years. Perhaps Mr Tigani cannot count as well as having a bad memory. It is extraordinary that people write this kind of nonsense when the facts are self-evident.

What is also extraordinary to me is that Mr Antonio Labozzetta, in some newspaper articles and on a television appearance, claimed how he wrote to the President, as I recall it, denying that he had any association or involvement with Sea Air Travel in South Australia. He said that, once again, that terrible fellow Baume was disgraceful in suggesting that he would be involved with this business, the Tigani family or whoever is involved in the NCA report—I commend it to Mr Tigani if he has forgotten about it—for 1990-91. As you are well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that report deals with the remarkable story of these families and the extent to which the various members of them were prosecuted. Some people say that the penalty did not fit the crime; others do not. They were prosecuted in respect of various tax matters relating to the remarkable way that they appeared to earn money which did not appear to relate to their stated businesses. I think that is a polite way of dealing with the matter.

It interests me that Antonio Labozzetta claimed I was talking absolute nonsense by saying that there was any link with Sea Air Travel. How dare I suggest that any member of his family was involved. I have copies of La Fiamma newspaper. I picked them at random, because this advertisement appeared for many months. I have here—I will table them—copies of advertisements that appeared on 18 August 1994 and 25 August 1994. They state this:

SPEECH.PARA: Fratelli Labozzetta trading as Marconi Travel—

which is the company I referred to earlier this week when I dealt with the annual report of the Australian Soccer Federation. In that instance, I told the chamber that the annual report of the Soccer Federation revealed that something like $240,000 in travel business had gone to this company in the normal course of business by the Australian Soccer Federation while Mr Tony Labozzetta was a commissioner or director of the Australian Soccer Federation. I said that I thought that was not a terribly wise thing to do, irrespective of whether it was in the normal course of business, because there is the clear potential for a conflict of interests.

PARA.TAB: In this advertisement, there is a special tour. One has to get in while one can; it costs only $5,490. It says that those who want to deal with this matter who are in South Australia should contact Sea Air Travel. The phone number for those interested in dealing with the Tigani family is (08) 356 3266. It strikes me as extraordinary that there is no link whatsoever and that gratuitously the Labozzetta brothers would promote in their own advertisements this company with which they have no associations and with which they have never been involved. I suppose one could say that at least they are not promoting another travel company owned by Francesco Nocola Labozzetta, which also exists in Sydney. I am just intrigued that the travel agency business is such an interesting one for such an interesting group of people to be so heavily involved in it.
I want by way of advice to suggest to Mr Tigani that, if he wants to blackguard me by writing to my leader, it would be a good idea if he got his facts right. I stress his comment:

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that in the circumstances you should publicly withdraw your comments in so far as they effect Sea Air Travel in South Australia and/or my families.

I assure him that I will not withdraw those comments. Furthermore, I express my distress that when inquiries were made of the South Australian Soccer Federation about how one should book to go to the World Cup in America it referred people to Sea Air Travel. I wonder why the South Australian Soccer Federation would have any such links with this organisation in view of the background, which can be demonstrated by looking at the NCA reports, of its principals and their capacity to write such nonsensical letters which are simply false in every material fact. I seek leave to table the advertisements and the letter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the adjournment tonight in relation to John Hewson's resignation from parliament last Monday. I was somewhat stunned to read Alan Ramsay's column in the Sydney Morning Herald today in which he pointed out, somewhat regrettably, that my colleagues Senator Baume and Senator Watson were the only two speakers outside the leadership group to comment upon John's resignation. I guess my lame excuse is that I was on sick leave on Monday night.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity tonight to pay tribute to John Hewson's service to his party, this parliament and the people of Australia. As the Labor Party would acknowledge, it is an enormous achievement to lead one of the two major parties of this country at federal level. It is an achievement to lead what is, in my view, the greatest and most successful party of Australia—the Liberal Party of Australia. John did that for the third longest period after Menzies and Fraser; he led it for over four years. That achievement will always stand John Hewson in good stead and will always be remembered.

The Liberal Party exhibited an extraordinary degree of unity and sense of purpose under the first three years of John Hewson's leadership. Everybody in the party acknowledges that after the 1980s, when the party had some difficulties, there is much to be said for the incredible esprit de corps, sense of purpose and unity that existed between 1990 and 1993 under John's very strong, dedicated and disciplined leadership.

I have some personal relations with John in the sense that I was flattered and honoured to be invited by John to be his chief of staff when he first became leader in March of 1990. It is a phone call I will long remember—the difficulty I had in saying that I had at that point decided to stay in South Australia and seek Liberal preselection for the Senate, and was therefore not in a position to accept what I regarded as the great honour it would have been to be his chief of staff.

In my quieter moments I often reflect on what might have been had I accepted that position. With all due modesty I am not sure that I could have done anything about what eventually happened in 1993, but it is odd to reflect on what might have happened if I had taken that job. I decided to stay in South Australia, seek Liberal preselection and run the federal campaign in South Australia for the 1993 election. I did that with great pleasure, working very closely and campaigning with John. The result in South Australia did prove that Fightback was saleable. It is said now that it was a totally unsaleable document, yet we had the best result in South Australia federally for 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had the State Bank to help.

—I acknowledge what Senator Schacht says; we had the bank. But if Fightback is the dog that it is often said it is, there is no way that we would have destroyed the Labor Party in South Australia in the last federal election. We reduced it to four miserable, lousy little seats. We could not possibly have done that if Fightback was the unsaleable document which everybody says it is.
—Their bad federal representation, too.

—Exactly. Their low quality federal representation contributed to their pathetic result in South Australia. I believe that the last election was winnable with Fightback. I think we proved that with the Fightback document.
—I beat you every time we went head to head, Nick.
—We thrashed you in 1993 and we thrashed you again in 1993. The Labor Party is now reduced to a miserable rump in South Australia, and that is partly your legacy, Christopher Schacht.
—But you weren't there.

—I was there, Christopher Schacht, and you know that very well. I am here to praise John Hewson, not to listen to you belittle me, Senator Schacht. I believe that it is a tragedy that John Hewson did not win the 1993 election and that he is not Prime Minister of Australia today. There is absolutely no doubt that Australia would be in much better shape if he had won that election and if he were now Prime Minister. Every Australian would be much better off. It is ironic that today we have had another reminder of that with another disastrous set of balance of payments figures. The election in 1993 was a disaster for Australia, brought about by the appalling campaign run by the Labor Party. For it now to complain about certain tactics in Canberra is the ultimate in hypocrisy.

PARA.TAB: I personally regret that John and I had something of a falling out after the 1993 election. I formed the honest and objective view that it was in John's best interests to resign the leadership of the party—to stay in parliament but to resign from the leadership because he had won the position and achieved his position in politics as the champion of a set of beliefs. I honestly thought he should resign the leadership to continue championing those beliefs, and he could not do that as leader of a party that had just lost an election under his leadership. So I thought it was in his best interests to resign from the leadership. He happened not to agree with that and as a result was not all that pleased with me.
I was not aware of the extent of that displeasure until John went on the PM program in only November of last year and said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have always thought that Nick Minchin has a distorted view of reality and politics.

There are probably many others who agree with that, and no doubt Senator Schacht thinks that. In the circumstances I understand why John reached that view about me but I still hold to the view that it was in John's interests to have resigned and not stayed in the leadership after 1993. I think he would have gone out, in a sense, more of a hero.

PARA.TAB: In concluding I want to congratulate John honestly and sincerely and as much as I can on his achievements in politics. He achieved much more than most of us ever will in politics in a very short time. He did make an enormous contribution to the party. He did wake Australia up to the kinds of economic reforms that are needed in this country. While Labor remains in office for at most another 12 months I hope it will pursue an economic reform agenda. Most of Fightback will ultimately be implemented in Australia one way or another and in time. I particularly want to congratulate John on the quality and dignity of his resignation speech. It was a great speech and one that will long be remembered. I honestly believe it is a tragedy that he is not currently Prime Minister.

I am personally delighted that he and Carolyn have a baby on the way. I know the tragedy and the difficulty they have had in creating a family. As someone who has experienced some of those difficulties, I express great personal joy that that has happened for John and Carolyn. I wish them all the very best in John's post-parliamentary career.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to delay the Senate very long tonight. I am taking the opportunity to speak on a couple of matters. Firstly I want to make a correction to the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.3) of 1995 which was presented to the chamber earlier today. I do not want to talk about the contents of the report but make the correction on the record that in appendix 2, which has details of the meetings of the committee that occurred on 3 February 1995 and 6 February 1985, my name is omitted from the list of those members in attendance at the meeting. I put that on the record because I am surprised that such an omission has occurred. I drew to the attention of the secretariat last night the fact that there was an omission in the drafts and I had expected it to be corrected prior to presentation.

PARA.TAB: I am going to use this opportunity while I am on my feet to read into the record two letters and to make some comment on the second one. The first letter I want to read into the record comes from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, sub-office of Tanjung Pinang, Indonesia. It is addressed to me. It proceeds:

Thank you for your letter of 17 January 1995. It was also a pleasure for me to meet with you and your wife during your visit to Galang. I appreciate your taking time off during your holidays to visit Galang and make a first-hand assessment of the challenging situation of Vietnamese and Cambodians in Galang. I hope your observations made during your visit will help you to better explain the situation of Galang to your colleagues in Australia.

For your information, the property (Citizen watch, black and silver cross and gold cross and chain) of Mr. Pham Tan Canh which you handed over to me during your visit was hand carried to Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, by a UNHCR staff of Sub-Office Tanjung Pinang during a UNHCR monitoring mission to Vietnam on 24 January 1995. The property was then handed over to directly to Mr. Pham by the Head of the UNHCR Working Group in Ho Chi Minh City, Mr. Imran Riza. I enclose a copy of the original Australian Red Cross letter which Mr. Pham signed in front of Mr. Riza stating he had received his property.
I also enclose a copy of an American NGO delegation mission report, as you requested in your letter. Excerpts of this report are being translated and disseminated in Galang.
Best regards to you and your wife.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter was signed Brian Lander, officer-in-charge. I put it on the record that when Australian Red Cross found out I was going to Galang in January they had in their possession a watch and some other property of a boat person who came to Australia and who was later sent back to Galang. They asked me to return that property to him if I possibly could. I did endeavour to do that but I was overjoyed to find that when I arrived at Galang the particular individual concerned had, for himself, made a decision to start rebuilding his life and had offered himself for voluntary repatriation to his homeland, Vietnam. He had departed from Galang island in Indonesia by the time I arrived there. I am very pleased to put on the public record the efforts the Australian Red Cross has made to get this property back to the individual concerned.

PARA.TAB: The second letter I will read into Hansard also relates to Galang. The letterhead reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Tin Lanh
Protestant Church
Galang Refugee Camp—Indonesia
PO Box 22 Tanjung Pinang, Riau Indonesia
The letter is dated 8 March 1994 and is addressed to:
Diaconess D.E. Fletcher
Administrator S.E.A.A.C Inc
4 Troks Court Glen Waverley 3150
Australia
The letter reads:
Dear Mrs. Fletcher.
Greetings in the love of our Lord Jesus Christ.

I have just got your address from my Christian congregations. They told me that you are very concerned about the boat people at Galang. I appreciate your benevolence in providing letters of sponsorship for them.

Hereby I would like to inform you that letters of sponsorship is helpful to those who are refugee. They are eligible to be resettled to the third countries. The refugees who do not have any relatives, badly need letters of sponsorship. So your support is very meaningful to the refugees.

But to those who are not refugees letters of sponsorship is meaningless. They must be repatriated to their home land (Cambodia or Vietnam). By giving them papers of sponsorship means that you give hope and expectation to be resettled. They have been wasting their time awaiting for nothing. This reality is badly contrary to the plan/policy of UNHCR and the Indonesian government. It is a serious obstacle to repatriation programme.

As a pastor and shepherd of boat people at Galang, I have to share you my more moral responsibility for the sake of their future. Please stop giving papers of sponsorship if you are not sure they are refugees. If you need, we are ready to assist to whom your sponsorship meaningful and helpful.
I look forward to hearing of you and may God richly bless you.
Thank you.
Sincerely yours,
Pastor Hasoloan Tambunan.

It is not my grammar because it is a direct quote from the letter. I read that letter into the record because I was greatly distressed when that letter was brought to my attention when I was in Galang. The unfortunate circumstance on that island at the moment is that all the people who are held there have been screened out as refugees. They are not eligible to take up the offer of sponsorship.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that there are people in Australia who are giving false hope to those people who remain on the island. This has caused a lot of distress on the island. The people there see that they have yet another chance to resettle in a third country, but, of course, that opportunity is not there. Australia is not able to help. Australia has done an enormous job in resettling boat people from many parts of the south-east Asian region. Those people are leading very productive lives in this country. Unfortunately, many of their colleagues continue to vegetate in refugee camps in South East Asia.

It concerns me that organisations, such as the one that this letter was addressed to, ought to know better. They should not be giving hope to those people when that will not be fulfilled in the end. It reflects badly on organisations if they go ahead and give false hope to people who feel that they are in dire circumstances. I urge that no more letters of sponsorship be sent to Galang island because no-one else can be repatriated to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I seek leave to table, under the Business Names Act, along with the documents I tabled a few minutes ago, two applications. One is an application for registration of a business name and the other is a statement of change of person in relation to whom a business name is registered.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin's remarks about the resignation of Dr Hewson reminded me of something. I also noted the article today written by Alan Ramsay. In the circumstances, some acknowledgment should be given to the resignation of John Hewson.

PARA.TAB: John Hewson and I have a connection. He married his second wife and I married my wife in the same church—the Gartrell Memorial Church in Adelaide. I married in that church in 1970. The reason I married in the Gartrell Methodist Church, as it then was, was that my best man's name was Gartrell. It seemed as good a church as any to be married in. I understand Carolyn chose the church because it was the local church where she grew up. That is the only social connection we have other than both he and I were elected at the 1987 election. The only other thing that I can think of that we have in common is that for a short period when he was shadow minister for customs—in May, June and July of last year, before he was dismissed from the frontbench—I attempted to speak to him on a couple of occasions about customs issues and was not able to make the connection.

I think it is appropriate that a couple of remarks be made about John Hewson's career. From our side of politics, we believe that he made a classic political mistake, and economic mistake in the circumstances, by proposing the GST which was the fundamental part of Fightback. I also think John Hewson's other mistake was that he concentrated overwhelmingly on one issue, an economic issue. I suspect that if, at the time he was leader, he had accepted the challenge of the Prime Minister in 1992 in relation to such issues as the republic and the Australian national identity, proposed those sorts of changes and engaged in a positive way in that debate, the election result in 1993 may have been much closer and he would have had a much greater chance of success.

TALK.START.PARA: —It couldn't have been much closer.

—You lost by 15 seats which is a pretty big loss. I understand that John Hewson had a very open mind and was quite positive on social issues and issues of national identity. I think he made a mistake in trying to buy too much acquiescence or quietness within the Liberal Party by allowing the John Howards and the Bronwyn Bishops of this parliament to run amuck on constitutional issues and claim their support for the monarchy in an extremely negative and backward way. I think John Howard will have great difficulty in the next election, which will be in the next 12 months or so, trying to claim himself as a man of the future when he only harks back to policies of the past.

PARA.TAB: Though I believe John Hewson's economic policies were misguided, I do think it has to be acknowledged that he was willing to put forward a detailed economic prescription for Australia. He took his ideas into the marketplace of politics and was willing to fight them out. I believe he ought to be given due credit for that. Time will only tell what people think. Historians will speculate what may have happened if he had won the election. I think his troubles would have only just begun if he had won the election.

I think he lacked the political skill, although he had an economic prescription, to get such a massive economic program through this parliament and accepted in the Australian community. That would have been really testing for any politician in Australia's history, even those with the greatest of political skills, but it certainly tested John Hewson.

I pay tribute to the fact that John Hewson chose to announce his resignation formally in the parliament. I think Alan Ramsay is right in what he said. He made the speech in parliament and he did not, as he was fully entitled to do and was able to do, send a letter of resignation to the Speaker and never be heard of again in the forum of the parliament. I think that is a lesson for all of us. If we get the opportunity—and some of us may not because we may be defeated at an election and not have that choice—to make a resignation or parting speech in the parliament, I think we ought to take it. I think John Hewson should be congratulated for using that opportunity, even though there were probably plenty of people, particularly on his side, who wished he had not. As Alan Ramsay pointed out, it is significant that so few on his own side spoke. I think that is disappointing for John Hewson and disappointing for the parliament.

I note that Alan Ramsey pointed out that, by resigning when he did, John Hewson is not entitled to a permanent pension, a gold pass and all the other emoluments available to those who serve at least nine years in parliament. If he had gone to the next election and then was defeated or if he had been defeated in the preselection in two months time, he would have been eligible for a pension.

I have to point out, of course, that many of us do not have the luxury of John Hewson's personal wealth, which means that this might not have been a consideration. There are many of us in this place who do not have access to personal wealth of such size, and a pension is a consideration after we leave parliament. But, just the same, he could have easily sat it out for another 12 months and collected the pension. I think that ought to be acknowledged. I think that says something about the character of Hewson doing it his way.

I noticed a long time ago in my younger days, when John Gorton was defeated for the leadership of the Liberal Party, that the ABC program This Day Tonight—the precursor to the 7.30 Report—at the end had a montage of scenes of John Gorton's political career overlaid with Frank Sinatra singing I did it my way. Despite the fact that he will be remembered as not being a good politician and for losing an election everyone said he should have won, I suspect that in some ways John Hewson would be quite happy to say, `I did it my way in the Liberal Party'. I think that is rather a glib reference and a very glib analysis of what really was going on in that election campaign. The issues were wider than just saying that he should have won what was considered an unlosable election.

I think that, above all else, we ought to acknowledge the fact that John Hewson had the courage, however he did it, to convince the Liberal Party to put up a major economic package with all its flaws. He did it; he went out in the marketplace; he lost. I think the last two years in this place were pretty uncomfortable for him. It is acknowledged that, once you lose an election like that, you are on a treadmill that is going backwards in a sense. He lost the leadership and then he lost his frontbench position. Some of those instances showed that he did lack political skill, but you cannot deny the fact that he had his own sense, his own way and his own quota of courage to put the case.

I want to acknowledge that—even though I have never said more than about three words to John Hewson. The only time he ever mentioned me, he deliberately mispronounced my name of Schacht into another variation that has more to do with lavatory humour. I thought that actually did him more damage than it did me, and it again showed a lack of political skill and judgment. But it was of no consequence to me. Anyway, I finally wish him and Carolyn success with the forthcoming family and wish him well in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply rise to express my disappointment at the tone of Alan Ramsey's article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. Because you do not jump to your feet in this place and pay tribute to a past leader or past colleague, it does not mean that you do not have the right feelings towards him or her or that you have not been happy with his or her leadership. I use this example: do you have to tell your wife and children every day that you love them? If you do not do it that day, does that mean you have stopped loving them? I believe that Alan Ramsey was out of order in this article by pointing out that only two people mentioned John Hewson's departure.

PARA.TAB: I can say that I was proud to be part of his team leading up to the 1993 election. I was very happy to sell our policy. In Western Australia, as you know yourself, Mr President, the coalition did extremely well. We polled a record, I believe, 54 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. We took two seats from the government and were within an ace of taking another seat, the prized seat of Swan held by Mr Beazley—the difference was something under 200 votes. There was a very similar situation with Mr Gear in Canning, and we reduced the majority in Brand to 2.8 per cent. So I believe that we sold the policy in Western Australia. They accepted the policy, and we certainly did well.

I certainly wish John Hewson well in his departure. I agree with those, including Senator Schacht, who said that he made a very dignified exit from this place. I wish him and his wife well. I would also like to pick up the point that Senator Schacht made that he deliberately mispronounced his name. I would not say that he deliberately did that, Senator

SPEECH.PARA: Schacht, because my name and your name can be hard to pronounce at times. The first day I was here I looked at your name and immediately worked out, `Schacht' as in `yacht'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well done.

—That was it. Anyone who has had anything to do with language can work that one out. I hope that the minister does not hold a grudge against John Hewson forever for that because he could have quite easily had a slip of the tongue as people do with my name. Again, I wish him well in the future. You never know, he may be back one day.

PARA.TAB: The following documents were tabled:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Higher Education Funding Act—Determinations—1995 Nos T1-T4.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 10 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many briefings have the Queensland authorities given to the federal authorities concerning Commonwealth offences relating to former Senator Graham Richardson and matters pertaining to Operation Wallah and Operation Hacker 6.
(2) Were Commonwealth offences identified during any of these briefings given by Queensland authorities to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) or the National Crime Authority.
(3) On what specific date was the AFP informed by Queensland authorities of further information relating to possible Commonwealth offences.
(4) On what specific dates were the Minister and the Attorney-General informally or formally advised of this information.
(5) Has the Prime Minister been advised of this information; if so, on what date was he advised and who provided this information.

(6) Has the Minister, the Attorney-General or the Prime Minister been made aware of the nature of these allegations relating to possible Commonwealth offences involving former Senator Graham Richardson and matters relating to Operation Wallah and Operation Hacker 6.
(7) What is the precise nature of the possible Commonwealth offences involving former Senator Graham Richardson.
(8) What action has the Minister and the Attorney-General or any other member of the Federal Government taken to ensure that the AFP investigates these possible Commonwealth offences.
(9) Who, and what internal departments has been given responsibility within the AFP to carry out the assessment of the criminal investigations passed on by the Queensland authorities.
(10) What time limit has been given for this assessment.
(11) When will the results of this assessment be provided to the Minister.
(12) Can an assurance be given that the findings of this assessment will be released publicly.
(13) Were the alleged Commonwealth offences committed during any stage of former Senator Graham Richardson's service as a Federal Minister of the Commonwealth.
(14) Can an assurance be given that the Commonwealth Government has not been compromised in any way concerning these matters.

(15) Has the AFP been informed of possible Commonwealth offences committed by any other serving or past Federal or State Members of Parliament or Federal or State Ministers of the Crown as a result of the Operation Wallah investigations or subsequent inquiries.

(16) Have Queensland authorities recommended to the AFP that investigations be carried out into possible Commonwealth offences relating to any Commonwealth department or agencies as a result of Operation Wallah or Operation Hacker 6.
(17) Which Commonwealth departments or agencies have been identified.
(18) What is the nature of the alleged Commonwealth offences that have been identified.

(19) Has the AFP provided any assistance to the Criminal Justice Commission, Queensland Police and New South Wales Police Service subsequent to the most recent briefings held in relation to Operation Wallah or Operation Hacker 6 investigations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(19) As I have said in responding to earlier questions on notice from Senator Chapman on this issue, the AFP is currently assessing certain allegations relating to possible Commonwealth offences before a commitment is made to undertake a criminal investigation. Until the AFP concludes its examination, it would be inappropriate for the Government to make further comment.

This position is in accordance with longstanding practice followed by both sides of politics. There are sound reasons for this policy. It is necessary so that the conduct of a criminal investigation is not prejudiced. Its is also necessary so that due process is afforded to the people or organisations subject to the allegations.
It is in the interest of the administration of justice that the AFP be left to do its job.
